Chamberlin started immediately as a freshman for coach Clarisa Crowell in 2025 and delivered an impressive campaign until a midseason injury sidelined her for the rest of the season. The Wausen, Ohio, native started 20 of her 26 appearances, slashing an excellent .321 average, 17 hits and 11 RBIs.

The five-foot-eight catcher also flashed her glove with a perfect 1.000 fielding percentage, including nine assists and 68 putouts. Before arriving at Happy Valley, Chamberlin ranked as the No. 22 overall prospect and No. 15 catcher in the 2024 class, so she holds massive upside and potential.

However, she faces steady competition as Seidel delivered the most impressive season of her collegiate career in 2025, reaching new single-season career-highs in every statistic. The Hilltown, Pennsylvania, native was the primary catcher after Chamberlin’s injury and started 33 of her 43 appearances.

The senior finished last season with a steady .247 average, 23 hits and 15 RBI. Seidel was also impressive defensively, boasting a 1.000 fielding percentage, with 10 assists and 156 putouts, second most on the team.

As both Chamberlin and Seidel bat and throw right, their playing time likely won’t be decided based on which opposing pitcher the Nittany Lions face. If Crowell wants a heavier bat in the lineup, I’d lean towards starting Chamberlin.

While Chamberlin’s sample size is smaller, she delivered a .528 slugging percentage and three home runs in that time span compared to Seidel’s .409 slugging percentage and four home runs in more games.

Despite this, I could see Crowell starting Seidel because of her experience. With half of the pitching staff being freshmen, Crowell might want a steady presence behind the plate.

Another argument for starting Seidel would be letting her carry last season’s momentum into 2026. If Crowell doesn’t give Seidel many opportunities in the beginning of the season, her bat may go cold when she’s inserted into the lineup.

Penn State also might want to ease Chamberlin back into playing full-time after her injury last season. It may help to have her not be the primary catcher right away, and instead get some reps and build confidence behind Seidel starting.

I ultimately see Crowell mostly splitting the starter role between the two catchers to start the season, and don’t see there being a clear-cut primary catcher until Big Ten play begins in March. The loaded nonconference schedule to begin Penn State’s campaign is the perfect opportunity for Crowell to swap around the catchers and ultimately decide who the starter is for the rest of the season.

The Nittany Lions have doubleheaders on Friday and Saturday, so I expect Chamberlin and Seidel to split starts this weekend. However, Sunday’s matchup against Auburn may give some insight into who might be the starter, as that’s the only game of the day.

It will be interesting to see how the starting catcher position shapes up throughout the season, and either way, each player is talented, so Penn State should have no problems filling the role.

MORE SOFTBALL CONTENT

title: Column | Revelations in Rome
author: Annelise Hanson | The Daily Collegian
description:
“Your worst sin is that you have destroyed and betrayed yourself for nothing.” Dostoevsky’s words followed me through my head as I marveled at the marble and gold throughout the Vatican Museums on my way to the Sistine Chapel.

I carried the question with me, for how long have I, my generation and American society traded creativity, originality, wonder, depth and art, for noise, dopamine, immediacy and optimization?

The withering of self. We starve our artists and fund our corrupt corporations, rewarding nothing but the dull hum of endless scrolling. Aching for serenity that we sold for nothing. Betraying and destroying ourselves for our own atrophy and nothingness.

I tilted my head back and let my eyes rest on Michelangelo’s “Creation of Adam.” Four years I thought, four years of devotion, discipline, of surrender to something greater than efficiency or profit, but for impact, legacy, and sheer awe. And now, centuries later, millions every year come to stand beneath his ceiling in silence, moved by his work.

I noticed the small distance between God’s finger and Adam’s, and remembered how I once filled sketchbooks of my recreation of this very movement. I tried to understand this space and how it separated man from divinity, and that maybe in that space there’s a pause, and it’s the very sin we have indulged that separates us. Rot. Decay. Superficiality.

Perhaps God and Adam never touch because sin is separation. And maybe this is ours, the slow betrayal of ourselves, the abandonment of what makes us alive, all for nothing at all.

Rome felt very intimate to me. I imagined Julius Caesar walking the same streets, and my time reciting monologues from Shakespeare’s play. Maybe once his sandals struck the same stone. I thought of the Colosseum, and of the crowds who once gathered there, amused and ravenous for violence and the spectacle of humans being torn apart by wild animals.

I wonder when humanity decided suffering could become a form of leisure, and when gladiators were puppets, and death, a sport where lives were so easily disposable.

The only distance between ancient Romans and me was time. If we stood face to face, we would share no common language or meaning, just creatures from the same species.

And still this city gave us carbonara, amatriciana, and cacao e pepe. As much as Rome revealed to me, it reminded me I would miss this country, this version of myself and that I’m already mourning the moments I’m still inside of and grieving time that has not passed yet.

Back at Penn State, nearly every hour of my day is booked. I have always been fast-paced and busy by nature. In America, productivity is a virtue, and burnout serves as evidence. Here, I have no extracurriculars. No job.

Life here is slow, and what's the rush? I wake up earlier and rest. I can live with intention and explore my nature without expectations. I walk where I need to go without panicking about pace, and I possess more of the most valuable asset, which is time.

I stroll and hear music spill into the streets, opera singers, musicians playing cello. The beauty here is authentic; it doesn’t run on a schedule or wait to be noticed, it just simply is.

I love it here, and I always knew I would.

Our real sin is that we’re willing to forget what it feels like to be fully alive. To know tranquility, and choose speed anyway.

I am learning how rarely we allow ourselves this kind of presence. When I return, I hope I continue to channel the version of myself whose learning time isn’t something to conquer, but something to live inside of.

MORE ABROAD COLUMNS

title: Staff Predictions | How does Penn State softball stack up entering 2026?
author: The Daily Collegian Softball Staff
description:
Penn State softball embarks on a new campaign after a record-breaking 2025 season, and the anticipation is high for a team with maximum opportunity to improve its standing in 2026.

Here’s how our staff sees the season going.

Gianna Dowling: 35-18

With lots of experienced talent on both sides of the ball, I believe Penn State will improve from 2025 and put itself in a position to make an NCAA Regional appearance for the second time in three years.

I think the Nittany Lions will go 2-3 in their opening weekend at the NFCA Leadoff Classic, falling to Missouri, BYU and Auburn. However, I think the blue and white will follow with an undefeated weekend at the Houston/HCU Invitational.

I have Penn State earning key non-conference wins over Houston, Pittsburgh, Notre Dame and Oregon State.

The Nittany Lions open Big Ten play with a tough outing, taking a West Coast trip to face preseason No. 5 Oregon. I think the blue and white will leave Eugene winless, but will bounce back with a series win over Wisconsin in its Big Ten home opener.

The other three conference series that I see Penn State coming up short in are those against Northwestern, Ohio State and Nebraska, who, along with Oregon, all finished top-five in the Big Ten rankings in 2025.

Ultimately, I think Penn State will finish conference play with a 13-11 record to put themselves in the middle of the standings and potentially make a run in the Big Ten Tournament.

Brielle Gari: 30-22

As softball season begins, the Nittany Lions look to improve. I believe in their improvement as well.

Having the first month of the season in nonconference tournaments, I believe it will give the blue and white wiggle room to figure out what works best for their squad. The do’s and don’ts early on in the season against smaller programs.

For the opening weekend, I would say Penn State goes 3-2. Falling to BYU and Boston College. As well as in the following weeks to UCF and Pitt. Facing off against Notre Dame in the SpaceU classic will be an interesting watch, as it will preview how the Nittany Lions fare against the Big Ten.

In the final week of February, Penn State travels to Knoxville for the Tennessee Invitational. Facing off against the home team, the Lady Vols, this will be the Nittany Lions' test in potential postseason play against a powerhouse SEC program.

Going into the conference series matchups, I think the blue and white will split the series 50-50. Having success at Rutgers and in Champaign against Illinois. But having some difficulty on the road in Eugene, Oregon, or for the Big Ten regular season finale at home against Nebraska.

It's all about consistency that leads to improvement. Last year, the longest winning streak the Nittany Lions could hold onto was 5. Against conference opponents, consistency is key. Penn State must do well within the conference to make it to the Big Ten tournament.

Ashley Beres: 36-17

The Nittany Lions head into the new campaign with hopes of reaching the NCAA Regionals for the second time in three seasons after missing the postseason in 2025. With a plethora of returners and key players back from injury, I see Penn State having a successful bounce-back season.

The blue and white will go 3-2 at the NFCA Leadoff Classic, winning favorable games over Boston College and Eastern Kentucky, while also pulling off a season opener win over Missouri.

I think Penn State rides the momentum and follows up that road trip by going undefeated at the Houston Invitational the next weekend. Following those games, I see the Nittany Lions going 4-1 at the SPACEU Classic, with their sole loss coming against UCF.

The Tennessee Invitational offers the blue and white its first big test of the season against preseason No. 4 Tennessee. I don’t think Penn State pulls off the upset in either game, but the Nittany Lions will win their other three games in this invitational.

I have Penn State sweeping its first home series of the season before traveling cross country for a tough trip against Oregon State and preseason No. 5 Oregon. The Nittany Lions will start the road trip strong with a win over Oregon State, but will drop two of their three games against the Ducks in Eugene.

However, the squad will bounce back with a series win over Wisconsin in the Big Ten home opener. I think Penn State will pull off some upsets in conference play and position itself for a shot at a run in the Big Ten Tournament, finishing in the middle of the conference.

MORE SOFTBALL CONTENT

title: Caribbean Student Association, Delta Sigma Theta organize fundraiser for families impacted by Hurricane Melissa
author: Jacob Godshall I The Daily Collegian
description:
On Oct. 28, 2025, a category five storm, Hurricane Melissa, hit the southern coast of Jamaica. The storm caused significant damage, and took a toll on the county’s infrastructure, food production and housing.

It also took a toll on human-life, with at least 45 confirmed deaths caused by the storm, as of Dec. 2, 2025.

The storm was the largest to make landfall in Jamaica since Hurricane Gilbert in 1988, and brought with it extreme rainfall and winds of up to 300 kilometers per hour. It hit Jamaica as a category five storm, before weakening and moving on to Cuba and the Bahamas.

Now, three months after the hurricane, restoration and aid efforts continue in Jamaica. Here, the Epsilon Gamma chapter of the Delta Sigma Theta (DST) sorority has teamed up with the Caribbean Student Association (CSA) to raise money for two families in affected areas. The goal is to raise around $2,000, according to CSA President Camren Boyogueno.

“The idea is to give $1,000 to each family so that they would be able to take that and apply it to whatever they may need to, for help with restoration of either their homes or their resources,” Boyogueno, a fourth-year studying neuropsychology, said.

The storm caused damage to homes and food supplies, as fishing was disrupted and agriculture was damaged, according to Boyogueno. The country’s main airport in Montego Bay was also damaged, making transportation of both aid and people more difficult.

Boyogueno said the best way for the average student to help is to “be informed,” and “donate if they feel inclined.”

Antoinette Slaughter, a member of DST, said her family in Jamaica experienced the damages firsthand.

“My family was directly affected regarding their housing, and there was damage in the house,” Slaughter, a third-year studying nursing, said. “Obviously having your shelter damaged is extremely heartbreaking.”

Slaughter said providing aid to some of these areas can be difficult, as many of them are rural, so “to reach every single family is very difficult.”

Chad-Daniel Salmon, an international student from Jamaica, also said the current infrastructure and geography of Jamaica can make aid difficult.

“When you have especially extended rains, winds and stuff like that, and you're surrounded by roads, a lot of greenery, you might have a lot of trees blocking roads, you might have rivers overflowing into communities and you might have landslides where pieces of the road are just falling away,” Salmon, a fifth-year studying mining engineering, said.

In addition to these short term impacts, other aspects of Jamaican life have been impacted, beyond just physical damage to roads and houses, according to Salmon. School disruptions are now a problem for many Jamaican students, as damage to their homes and schools has forced them to work to help repair.

“Even though, yes, the island might technically be open for some people, their day-to-day is still not there,” Salmon said.

Salmon said it’s important to view hurricane effects in a different “framing.” While many organizations and aid-providers only consider short-term impacts like damage and loss of resources, he said it's important to also consider and take into account long-term issues.

“I think especially when it comes to news cycles, people love to show the videos of things like the roof missing, or the kid with no clothes or the kid who's looking at their home and it's not there anymore,” Salmon said. “But at the end of the day, we also have to realize that these are people with whole lives and whole systems around them that they were using to survive, live and grow. In terms of when you cover storms, while it's important to look at the immediate damage, it's also important to think about how their life has been disrupted beyond just the damage that they are seeing in front of them.”

Trinity Benford, a member of DST, said it’s important for organizations and people outside of Jamaica to be aware of what is happening, and willing to help.

“I feel like we hear a lot about things that happen and then we kind of forget about them, when in reality, people are living in these situations much longer than we hear about them,” Benford, a third-year studying agriculture and biorenewable systems management, said. “So being able to gather non-profits that are actively working to help Jamaica, and being able to join efforts is something that we really wanted to help do.”

Those interested in contributing can do so here.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: No. 14 Penn State men’s volleyball looks to break losing streak against Saint Francis
author: Keira Albert | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 14 Penn State is gearing up for a busy weekend against Saint Francis as it looks to take back some wins.

The first match of the series is the THON Match from Rec Hall at 7 p.m. Friday, but the Nittany Lions will hit the road for the next game, which will be played in DeGol Arena at 6 p.m. Friday.

After taking back-to-back losses against Hawai’i last weekend, the blue and white have officially lost four straight games. Remaining at No. 14, the Nittany Lions have the chance to get some wins under their belt as they face the unranked Red Flash.

After a couple of tough matches, the odds could be in favor of Penn State.

These two are no strangers to one another. Last season, the teams met twice. And both times, the blue and white left the court with a 3-0 win. Similarly, the teams met twice in 2024, and Penn State left the victor both times.

Despite the four-game losing streak, it hasn’t been all bad for Penn State.

Currently, the Nittany Lions are No. 13 in the NCAA in blocks per set. With players like Owen Rose and Gaige Gabriel, both of whom rank in the top 50 in the stat, the blue and white definitely have the one-up in this area of play.

However, Saint Francis edges out Penn State in aces per set. Currently, the Red Flash are No. 23 in the NCAA in that very category, whereas the Nittany Lions trail far behind at No. 33.

Serving has seemed to be a consistent struggle for the blue and white. Last weekend, it only produced seven total service aces across two matches. More notably, it came up with a total of 29 service errors across both games.

While Gabriel has eight service aces so far, making him runner-up for the most of the squad, he leads the Nittany Lions in service errors with 29 on the year.

In order to have a different outcome than the last four matches, it is crucial that the quality of the blue and white’s serves increase.

Defense has been strong for the blue and white. However, libero Ryan Merk has been consistently reliable. With 60 digs on the season, the redshirt senior ranks No. 22 in the NCAA in digs per set, currently averaging about 2.14 per set.

Merk isn’t the only defensive talent for Penn State. Rose and Gabriel have a combined 56 blocks on the year. Sean Harvey follows close behind with 17 blocks this season.

Harvey has been having a strong season so far, and poses a threat to any team that he faces.

The redshirt sophomore leads the team in points with 108.5. But where he really makes himself known is in kills. With 94 on the year, he leads by almost double that of any of his other teammates.

But, Saint Francis has Brady Stump, who currently has 87 kills on the season. It’s also important to note that the Red Flash have played one less game than the Nittany Lions so far.

Stump also leads Saint Francis in service aces with 12, which matches Penn State’s leader, Rose.

The 4-4 Nittany Lions have a chance to get back on a good note this weekend. If history repeats itself, the 4-3 Red Flash could be tacking a couple of losses to their record this weekend.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: Column | James Franklin’s legacy as Black coach won’t be lost in rocky end at Penn State
author: Avery Hill | Football Editor
description:
Entering the four-month mark since James Franklin was fired from Penn State, much of what’s discussed among the Penn State fanbase is a sense of anger, disappointment and resentment.

At a shallow level, I get it. Twenty-one losses against AP top-10 teams, one Big Ten championship, a three-game losing streak to conclude his tenure coaching one of the biggest brands in college football. But what’s often ignored is what he did do.

Among other successes, Franklin 's tenure at Penn State made him a modern-day pioneer in an area he holds near and dear to his heart — being a Black coach. That should never be forgotten.

At Penn State, Franklin won 104 games, a tie with Rip Engle as the second-most in program history. He also won four New Year’s Six bowls and brought Penn State to a preseason ranking it hadn’t seen since the late 1990s, an accomplishment even if it all unraveled after three games.

Additionally, Franklin is the winningest African American head coach in FBS history. He’s also the first and only African-American head coach to win a Big Ten title among other notable achievements.

But these accolades, and other on-field statistics only scratch the surface on what Franklin has done as a Black head coach.

The Langhorne, Pennsylvania, native long made it a goal of his to become the first Black head coach to win a national title. Of course to be able to do that on an individual level is important to Franklin, but the impact it may have on other coaches cements his legacy even more.

At the 2025 Orange Bowl media day, he noted the marker of 16 of 134 FBS coaches being Black — a number that has shifted a bit with 136 teams and the firing of coaches like Sherrone Moore.

It was a relative increase from the 6 of 127 FBS coaches when Franklin was the offensive coordinator at Kansas State under fellow Black head coach Ron Prince.

But that increase starts with coaches giving qualified minorities a chance. Franklin did so when he hired Charles Huff, who was on Franklin’s staff at Vanderbilt but never landed a major, full-time position coaching job until he became Penn State’s running backs coach in 2014. Huff went on to take three head coaching jobs.

Even for Huff’s current stop, Memphis, Senior Vice President and Director of Intercollegiate Athletics Ed Scott said Franklin, along with Nick Saban, gave a firm recommendation for Huff.

“What truly sets him apart is his character and integrity,” Franklin said according to Memphis.

Then there’s Terry Smith, who left a 2-10 Temple team where he coached the wide receivers, and was hired by Franklin as cornerbacks coach.

He may have never, and may never, get a shot to be a full-time head coach, but his time as an interim and his role as associate head coach made him one of the more respected, and highest-paid, assistants in the business.

That in its own right is an accomplishment in Black coaching history as according to a 2023 article from the Journal of Intercollegiate Sport, “Black coaches were disproportionately responsible for signing higher rated recruits than their White counterparts.” Said responsibility comes from what’s usually a position coach, a typically underpaid role.

And also with a look through the Lasch Building, the diversity, from all shapes of life and all positions, was evident; Franklin’s a man who wants to give a chance to the most qualified.

But, that didn’t mean it was all perfect.

As the big personality in Franklin fought a passionate, but critical fanbase, many seasons didn’t go by without a “Fire Franklin!” chant of some sorts.

Even in what I’d consider a mishandling of his responsibilities as head man, walking off of the podium when asked for comment on the accusations of rape committed by his former players Jameial Lyons and Kaveion Keys, Franklin had his fair share of incidents that hurt his resume and perception.

But, said turn in perception, regardless of severity of the incident, is a microcosm of the fight Black coaches have fought for a long time.

“I’m sick of us having to be perfect to get the job,” legendary Georgetown basketball coach John Thompson Jr. said in 1998.

Black coaches have often been far behind the ladder when it comes to making the big step.

For Franklin, that started as a non-Division l collegiate player, and included a player/coach job in Denmark that he told Inside the Lions’ Audrey Snyder he laid asphalt during.

It took Franklin 16 years to earn the big shot, though it’s worth noting the sort of systematic privilege as a former quarterbacks coach that was promoted to offensive coordinator got him the opportunity even fast. He also got an 11-plus-year leash — a dream for many others.

But it didn’t change his end at Penn State.

The boos, curses and toxicity made Franklin a subject of pure resentment from a fanbase that, despite his successes, are likely rooted in a feeling of him not doing enough and not appreciating enough.

It’s a setback in his journey that, coincidentally, came in an NFL season that saw Mike Tomlin be fired and no Black coach be hired.

But it’s also a message that Franklin, and many others, aren’t done fighting. As Franklin makes a home in Blacksburg, Virginia, he continues to push for a fair shot for all.

But he isn’t, and can’t, start from ground zero. Despite the darkness — some to his fault and some to others’ — created during his end in Happy Valley, Franklin’s tenure is a marker for true success for a Black coach at the collegiate level.

It shouldn’t be overshadowed.

MORE BLACK HISTORY MONTH STORIES

title: State College police share details regarding McKenna’s arrest
author: Mia Debelevich & Grace Levy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Editor’s Note: This story was updated Thursday morning to include additional details after the Collegian acquired the criminal complaint.

The State College Police Department has released a statement stating they’ve filed criminal charges against Gavin McKenna for aggravated assault Saturday night.

The police department said the incident occurred at 8:45 p.m.. McKenna allegedly “struck a 21-year-old male in the face,” which caused “facial injuries requiring corrective surgery.”

Police were dispatched to Mount Nittany Medical Center to speak with a patient who had been assaulted, according to the criminal complaint.

The 21-year-old's jaw was wired shut, his face was allegedly swollen, there was dried blood on his lips and he was missing a tooth.

Police also said he was in “substantial pain” and “unable to speak.”

The victim was with two friends who allegedly both witnessed the assault, and both told police the victim was punched twice on the right side of his face by McKenna following an “exchange of words” between the victim’s group and McKenna’s group.

State College Police reviewed security camera footage which showed McKenna allegedly left Doggie’s Pub shortly before the incident occurred, according to the criminal complaint.

Police located blood on the sidewalk near where the assault allegedly occurred, as well as security camera footage showing McKenna punch the victim twice.

McKenna was arraigned and released on $20,000 unsecured bail. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for 8:30 a.m. on Wednesday, Feb. 11, at the Centre County Courthouse in Bellefonte.

Police said no additional information will be released because the case remains active.

MORE CRIME AND COURTS COVERAGE

title: Matt Campbell says Penn State had a ‘grand slam’ by hiring RBs coach Savon Huggins
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Savon Huggins completed Matt Campbell’s first staff at Penn State when he was hired as running backs coach in January.

Huggins and Campbell said they both felt they were a match for each other. Campbell said he could tell the respect Huggins had while holding the role at Boston College.

“Says a lot about his character, who he is, what he's about, and it shined through in the interview process,” Campbell said at the National Signing Day press conference on Wednesday. “We felt like we had a grand slam in terms of getting Savon to come on board and his family. They fit us culturally, and I certainly believe they fit the Penn State way of doing things.”

Huggins, who joined the Eagles in 2022, helped the running game go from 63.4 yards per game in his initial campaign, to 199.5 in the next.

This past year, Huggins guided running back Turbo Richard to 749 yards and nine touchdowns on 145 carries. Huggins said he had opportunities to leave, but wanted to find the “right people” before making a jump to a new school.

“It had to make sense,” Huggins said. “It's a family decision for me. I got three children, so family is very important to me. I want to be in an environment where it makes sense for my children, the school they go to, and the leadership in terms of the head coach, in terms of the staff, the continuity. I mean, those guys have been together for a long time. That says a lot about coach Campbell.”

Campbell joked that he asked Huggins, a 2011 247Sports composite 5-star running back, if he had any more eligibility left to play. Huggins played at Rutgers, rushing for 842 yards and nine touchdowns across 32 games before missing his senior year due to injury. He finished out his college days at Northern Iowa.

Campbell pointed to Huggins’ collegiate career as one of the reasons why he’s excited to have him on staff, saying Huggins coaches because of what he learned through his collegiate journey.

Furthermore, Huggins said he feels himself and Campbell view the recruiting process the same.

“He’s looking for high character young men, not only from a player standpoint, but from a coaching standpoint,” Huggins said. “If he wants to make sure that these young men are being led, he has to know that the coaches that are leading them are the right people.”

Huggins brings recruiting ties to the New Jersey area with him as he was a graduate of St. Peter’s Prep. He said he’s a “relationship person,” and it stuck out to him that he was asked by Campbell about his family before any football-related topics during the interview process.

Campbell showing he also cares about building relationships made Huggins feel they were “aligned” with what each of them were looking for during the hiring process.

“Obviously we talked ball and talked about holistically from a recruiting standpoint, all the other things,” Huggins said. “But he really wanted to know the person, and for me, that's heartwarming in this profession to find a leader in that position.”

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women's basketball earns first Big Ten in overtime thriller against Purdue
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State entered Wednesday’s game against Purdue still searching for its first conference win of the season, but the Lady Lions got some star power back in their lineup after a week off. Junior Gracie Merkle returned to action after missing the last two games due to injury and made her presence known early.

The Lady Lions were resilient and fought hard for their first conference victory over Purdue in overtime 85-82.

The Mount Washington, Kentucky, native scored the first basket of the game off a missed jumper by Nyla McFadden. Penn State pressured Purdue early and forced a few turnovers and bad shots, but star guard Kiki Smith poured in some baskets and kept the Boilermakers close.

After a few minutes of no scoring by either team, star sophomore Kiyomi McMiller scored quickly off a short jumper and pulled the blue and white ahead 7-4. A few quick baskets by Purdue gave the Boilermakers the lead into the first timeout.

Purdue pressed the Lady Lions for the last four minutes of the first quarter and forced the blue and white into taking some uncomfortable shots. While the Lady Lions surrendered six turnovers in the opening frame, McMiller and Merkle combined for 15 of Penn State’s 18 points and led Penn State into the second with an 18-15 lead.

Smith became hot again and poured in a quick five points in the first two minutes, which included a wide-open 3-pointer on the wing. The two squads exchanged buckets for a few minutes, but another lapse on defense left Purdue’s Tara Daye wide open for a 3-pointer and the Boilermakers went ahead 26-24 at the 6:49 mark.

The Lady Lions took a 36-34 lead into halftime off an 11-4 run, led by six of McMiller’s nine second-quarter points. Defensively, Purdue was kept on its feet after coach Carolyn Kieger switched looks between man and zone. The Boilermakers shot just 39% from the floor, including just 3-15 from behind the arc in the first half.

Merkle was the focal point in the blue and white’s offense to start the second half, and she quickly drew the third foul on Purdue’s Lana McCarthy. However, a few messy turnovers by Penn State allowed the Boilermakers to keep the score within a basket.

Kieger’s squad forced a travel off a press at 4:42 in the third, but the Lady Lions immediately turned it over, and Daye made an easy layup down low. McMiller continued putting Penn State on her back and knocked down a five-foot jumper, and gave the blue and white its largest lead of the night at 46-41.

Purdue went on a quick 5-0 run to pull within one, but Tèa Clèante found a wide-open Moriah Murray on the right wing for a 3-pointer to stop the bleeding. However, Penn State back-to-back steals by the Boilermakers on entrance passes to Merkle led to Kendall Puryear tying the game at 50 off a short jumper.

After a Merkle foul, Smith knocked down two free throws to give Purdue a 52-50 lead, roaring into the final frame. Turnovers haunted the Lady Lions in the third, as they surrendered a whopping seven giveaways compared to just one Purdue turnover.

While Penn State’s two leading scorers held their own, the Lady Lions needed offense from another scorer to win their first conference game. Murray rose to the occasion and poured in two key 3-pointers for the blue and white.

McMiller was contained in the second half by Purdue, but she drove downhill and flipped in a timely layup, giving Penn State a 64-59 lead with 4:25 left.

However, the blue and white stalled offensively, and the Boilermakers forced the Lady Lions’ 18th turnover of the contest. McCarthy’s basket off the steal pulled Purdue back in front 65-64 at 2:43.

Just as she’s done all season, McMiller was the offensive star down the stretch. She found Tea for a critical 3-pointer, then drove down on the next possession for another layup. McMiller’s 10th basket gave Penn State a 71-67 lead with 55 seconds left.

Out of the Purdue timeout, Smith made just one of two free throws and then fouled McMiller on the other end. In the bonus, McMiller stepped up to the stripe with 27 seconds left with a chance of icing the first conference win for the Lady Lions. The Silver Spring, Maryland, native delivered two clutch free throws and gave Penn State a 73-68 lead.

Smith hit a timely 3-pointer out of the timeout, and McMiller was soon shooting free throws again with 15 seconds left. McMiller made the first, but missed the second, which set up a backbreaking 3-pointer by Nya Smith to tie the game at 74 with .4 seconds left.

After Merkle’s miss from down low, Penn State entered overtime after some last-second heroics by Kiki and Nya. After a Purdue miss, McMiller drove and dished it out to the corner for a McFadden 3-pointer to put the Lady Lions up 77-74.

However, the Boilermakers punched right back after Murray committed a foul on Daye in the paint, who converted the and one to tie the game at 77 with 3:33 left.

After a stretch of minimal offense from both squads, fatigue set in; Penn State desperately needed a basket to break the tie. McMiller got doubled and tried forcing a pass to Merkle in the paint, but the ball was knocked away into the hands of Murray. Yet, Murray was wide open in the left corner, and she drained the 3-pointer, putting the Lady Lions up 81-78 with 36 seconds left.

McMiller made two clutch free throws with 24 seconds left to keep the lead 83-79, but Daye converted a critical and one to pull Purdue within one with 17 seconds. Viktoria Ranisavljevic converted two free throws and an empty Purdue possession on the other end gave Penn State its first conference win.

Up Next

Penn State returns to action against Michigan State at Rec Hall, Feb 7.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: ‘I was familiar with the culture’ | Why D’Anton Lynn decided to return to Penn State
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
D’Anton Lynn had returned to the Lasch Building just once since he graduated from Penn State in 2012. As a defensive assistant for the Buffalo Bills, he came to Pro Day in 2015.

That stood until Matt Campbell came calling to offer Lynn the defensive coordinator position, a role he had just turned down the prior offseason. He took it, returning to Penn State facilities that look much different than they did 11 years ago.

“I feel like everything's a family decision at this point, and me and my wife just felt like we were more prepared this time around,” Lynn said. “And then the more I talked to coach Campbell on the phone, he really kind of reminded me of why I went to Penn State, just from what he was going to do with the culture here. So I was just excited to be on board.”

Lynn said it was still a difficult decision to pack everything up and move cross country, as his wife is from Los Angeles, where he and his family have spent the last three years. And he has three children under 3, complicating a big move even more.

Lynn also had a hard time leaving his players at USC that he’s been with for the past two seasons, and Campbell said his defensive coordinator gave up some things “financially” to join his staff.

But the familiarity Lynn has with his new destination has helped mask some of that as guys like Director of Talent Acquisition Alan Zemaitis and Director of Player Development Jordan Hill have been around since Lynn’s playing days.

“Just all the Penn State people that were here, like some people I played with, some people were on staff, but I just knew that I was familiar with the culture. I think that helped,” Lynn said.

Lynn has received support from his former Penn State teammates as well since taking the job. He said he’s been speaking with former roommate Matt McGloin the most, who lives “right down the road” and “will be out here a lot,” according to Lynn.

The adjustment to actually coaching for the Nittany Lions, though, is still fresh for Lynn. He’s been working on getting to know the staff and players but hasn’t had a lot of time to do so with the coaches on the road recruiting the 2027 class.

Terry Smith has been a big help for Penn State’s new defensive coordinator in that regard by telling him about players that don’t have much on tape as Lynn works to nail down his scheme.

Smith and Lynn’s previous relationship helped Campbell feel even better about the hire, and other trusted colleagues echoed positive sentiments about the former USC playcaller. His scheme and success as a defensive coordinator spoke for itself as well.

“I think the thing that I love about D’Anton Lynn is his variability, his ability to have consistency,” Campbell said. “And I think you see a confidence that his defense plays with. And you saw that at UCLA, you saw that at USC and the improvement that they were making during his time there. But you also saw the ability to structurally dictate and navigate the pace of the game at times.”

What Lynn’s not going to do, though, is bring his scheme from USC to Penn State and force the players into it. As work begins in a few weeks, Lynn will begin to implement his philosophy and make sure the on-field product is consistent each game come the end of August.

“We want to really just build around what these guys do best,” Lynn said. “So I try not to just be a system guy where, ‘this is what we're going to do no matter what.’ Let's really see what these guys do best. Let's build a scheme around that. And we just try to really emphasize it's more about how we play than as far as what we do. The scheme can change week to week, year to year, but as far as how we play, that has to be the same.”

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State Notebook | Cael Sanderson reflects on match against Nebraska, evaluates pair of wrestlers
author: AJ Piazza | The Daily Collegian
description:
After Penn State’s 26-12 victory against Nebraska, the Nittany Lions will hit the road and travel to Ann Arbor to take on Michigan.

Before this matchup Cael Sanderson met with the media to discuss a handful of topics.

Here’s what he had to say.

Recapping Nebraska

The match between Nebraska was interesting with two Penn Staters giving points to the other team. Nebraska didn’t really attack and was on defense for most of the match. Penn State has been preparing for that for a while.

“We’re obviously preparing and stuff, it's not anything new,” Sanderson said. “Anytime you have a good wrestler or you play a good team, people are going to try to figure out how to beat you and sometimes that’s the best shot.”

During the match, Braeden Davis and Levi Haines were two wrestlers that let their emotions get the best of them. Davis gave the Cornhuskers another point while Haines let Christopher Minto start with a 1-0 lead.

“You want discipline, it’s obviously a success principle, something that you got to have in all aspects of wrestling and your lifestyle,” Sanderson said. “When actions are not what we want them to be I don’t think that’s necessarily a good thing … anything that happens as a head coach, that’s on me. We’ll learn.

Marcus Blaze and Rocco Welsh

Marcus Blaze has gone underlooked, Sanderson said. He currently ranks at No. 4 at 133 pounds and has an undefeated 16-0 record. Blaze has multiple ranked wins and continues to look like a potential national championship contender.

“I think he’s just a tremendous competitor. He stays in such good position as he’s competing,” Sanderson said. “I think he’s maybe a little under the radar if that’s even possible because he’s really really good. I mean I don’t know what else to say.”

Rocco Welsh had a slow start to the season, but has been on a roll after defeating the then-No. 1 wrestler in Angelo Ferrari from Iowa. In a tough 184 pound weight class, Welsh now finds himself at the top.

“I think he’s a student of the game. He’s a great competitor and I think he’s getting more and more comfortable like he knows that this is where he belongs,” Sanderson said.

Hitting the road

Penn State hits the road to Ann Arbor to face the Wolverines. This will be a homecoming for two Nittany Lions as Braeden Davis and Josh Barr are Michigan natives, who will likely have their family and friends at the match.

Sanderson seemed excited to hit the road and likes how it could affect his team for the long run as the season continues.

“I think being on the road. It’s almost easier because you’re in a hotel, you’re isolated. It’s fun to go wrestling in other people’s arenas,” Sanderson said. “We’re just happy to compete.”

title: Penn State men's hockey Gavin McKenna charged with aggravated assault
author: Grace Levy
description:
Penn State men’s hockey player Gavin McKenna was charged with felony aggravated assault following an alleged altercation that occurred in downtown State College on Saturday night.

McKenna is the projected No. 1 overall pick in the 2026 NHL Entry Draft. He came to Penn State from the WHL’s Medicine Hat Tigers on a large NIL contract. Since joining the Nittany Lions McKenna has put up 32 points in 24 games.

Prior to the alleged incident, McKenna scored three points in Penn State’s outdoor hockey game at Beaver Stadium.

McKenna is awaiting preliminary hearing.

Penn State athletics is aware that charges have been filed but declined to comment any further.

title: Olympic preview | Tessa Janecke, Team USA’s path to the Gold Medal Game
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Eight years ago, Maddie Rooney made a stick save against Canada’s Meghan Agosta in the sixth round of the shootout in the Gold Medal Game, giving the United States its first win in the event since 1998. In her fourth time representing her country at the Olympics, Hillary Knight finally earned a taste of gold.

In 2022, Team Canada played spoiler and prevented the United States from winning in back-to-back Olympic Games. Marie-Philip Poulin put the Canadians up 3-0 in the second period and never looked back.

Now, after over 1,400 days, Knight is back for the next time to represent the United States at the Olympics for the final time in her career. She’ll travel to Italy with a few new teammates, one being Penn State’s captain, Tessa Janecke.

Janecke looks to capture the third gold medal of her career, the first at the Olympic level. The Orangeville, Illinois, native previously won two gold medals at the IIHF World Championship, the second coming after her medal-clinching “golden goal.”

Preliminary round

This year, the United States begins its chase for gold in Milano-Cortina in a group similar to the one it faced in 2022: Canada, Finland, Switzerland and now Czechia, who were placed in Group B at the Winter Games in Beijing.

During the last Winter Games, the Americans went 3-1 in the preliminary round with their lone loss coming from the Canadians.

This year, Janecke and Team USA will kick off this round of pool play on Thursday at 10:40 a.m. EST against Czechia. Competing in the event for the first time in history four years ago, the Czechs split their four games in the preliminary round before falling 4-1 to the United States in the quarterfinals after a three-goal period from the red, white and blue.

The next two games will come against Finland on Saturday and Switzerland on Monday. In 2022, Kendall Coyne Schofield and Alex Carpenter each scored twice in a 5-2 win over the Fins, and Alex Cavallini recorded a 12-save shutout in an 8-0 win over Switzerland.

The preliminary round concludes on Feb. 10, a date Americans and Canadians have circled on their calendars, when the two play each other.

Team USA hasn’t beaten Team Canada in a preliminary round in any of the last three Winter Games. Going back to the 2014 Games in Sochi, the United States is 1-5 against its neighbors from the north, its lone win coming in the 2018 Gold Medal Game.

Quarterfinal round

From this round forward, everything is left up to seeding. Team USA has an advantage being in Group A, a group containing teams that are referred to as the top in the world. In 2022, they finished second in the group behind Canada with nine points, but would have advanced regardless.

Looking at Group B, Sweden is projected to be one of the top finishers, earning it the sixth seed.

Assuming the United States falls to Team Canada again in pool play, they would finish as the No. 2 seed and would play the No. 7 seed. That seed could be filled by Japan, who appropriately enough are ranked seventh in the IIHF rankings.

Should the host Italy pull off some upsets in the preliminary round, it could also sneak into the No. 7 seed. That would set up a game for Penn State fans to watch as the Nittany Lions' captain Janecke would face teammate Matilde Fantin.

Semifinal round

The United States has reached the semifinal round in every Olympic appearance. All but once have the Americans advanced to the Gold Medal Game. Their lone loss in this round was in 2006, when Sweden won in a shootout, shocking the nation.

In each of the last two Winter Olympics, the United States has faced Finland in the semifinals. Rooney recorded a 14-save shutout in a 5-0 win in 2018, and Knight recorded two points in a 4-1 win in 2022.

Gold Medal Game

Despite the six games needed to play to reach this point, it’s one that most think the Americans won’t have an issue facing. Besides the off-year that was 2006, the United States has reached the Gold Medal Game at each Winter Olympics, including 1998 when it captured the gold in the first year women’s hockey became an event.

Its foe in all of those games has also been the same: Team Canada. As expected, the Canadians have a stacked roster that features Poulin, Brianna Jenner and Julia Gosling — who each rank top-10 in points in the PWHL — and Jocelyne Larocque, who has captured two Olympic gold medals already.

If the United States can pull off the upset just as it did in 2022, it would give Janecke her first Olympic gold medal and make her the first player in program history to win a spot on the highest stand of the podium.

MORE OLYMPICS CONTENT

title: Penn State track and field's Handal Roban, Boh Ritchie earn weekly honors
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another week, another set of honors for Penn State.

Handal Roban and Boh Ritchie were both named Big Ten Athletes of the Week after their performances at the Penn State National Open last weekend.

After running two historic marks this weekend, Handal and Boh have been named Big Ten Athletes of the Week! 🔗https://t.co/vLAA8AR5Ey#WeAre #PSUTF pic.twitter.com/HkeXBEIjEY— Penn State Track & Field/Cross Country (@PennStateTFXC) February 4, 2026

Roban broke the men's 800-meter record in his first indoor 800m of the season, running a 1:44.91. His time crushed Isaiah Harris' time of 1:46.08, which was set during his national championship-winning year.

While Ritchie didn't break the record in her respective race, she ran the No. 2 mark in the women's 800m in 2:01.61. Two weeks before, the New Zealand native also ran the No. 2 mark in the women's 600-meter.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: Penn State women's hockey's Kendall Butze tabbed AHA's Defenseman of the Month
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
In last Saturday’s contest against Robert Morris, Kendall Butze recorded an assist on a Danica Maynard goal. It was the 85th point of her career, giving her the most career points for a defenseman in Penn State hockey history.

After a stellar January, Kenny is your AHA Defenseman of the Month! 🔗 https://t.co/E8mHsIZtfo#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/A97fNQEEBk— Penn State Women’s Hockey (@PennStateWHKY) February 4, 2026

During the month of January, Butze scored three goals and tallied seven assists for 10 points with a plus-minus of plus-7 and 13 blocked shots.

Just days later, Butze was named the AHA’s Defenseman of the Month. It is the second time in her career that the Cleveland, Ohio, native has won the award. She won the award for the first time in November 2024.

It is the third time in program history that a Nittany Lion has won the award.

Butze and the Nittany Lions will be back in action at 5 p.m. on Friday for Game 1 of their series against the Lindenwood Lions.

MORE HOCKEY CONTENT

title: Penn State women's lacrosse earns preseason Big Ten honors
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Anticipation is building as the Penn State season begins in three days.

On Wednesday afternoon, three Nittany Lions were named Big Ten Players to Watch, including Erika Ho, Sydney Manning and Roquette Allen, while the team was ranked No. 5 in the Big Ten preseason poll.

The Big Ten Women's Lacrosse Preseason Poll and Players to Watch are HERE! 🥍 Check 'em out 👉 https://t.co/hp90BI0UAi pic.twitter.com/UxUh1BZ9Hz— Big Ten Lacrosse (@B1GLacrosse) February 4, 2026

Ho returns to Penn State after her dominant junior year, where she led the team with 49 goals.

Manning has been a solid starter for the blue and white the last two years, averaging a 42.4% save percentage while starting in every game. During her freshman year, Manning was named Big Ten Freshman of the Year.

Allen joins Penn State for her freshman year as the team's only four-star athlete. Coming out of Lone Tree, Colorado, Allen was previously committed to Syracuse before rejoining Treanor at Penn State.

While the Nittany Lions enter the season ranked 23rd in the nation, they enter the conference as No. 5 behind unanimous top-seeded Northwestern, Maryland, Johns Hopkins and Michigan.

MORE LACROSSE CONTENT

title: Penn State men’s basketball set for road test against No. 2 Michigan
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
After finally picking up a win in the Big Ten, Penn State’s next challenge is a hefty one: the second-ranked team in the nation.

For the second time this season, the Nittany Lions square off against Dusty May and Michigan on Thursday. Tipoff is scheduled for 6:30 p.m.

When the Wolverines visited Happy Valley back on Jan. 6, the blue and white nearly upset May’s squad.

Penn State took it down to the last possession after overcoming a 15-point deficit, but failed to knock down a game-tying or winning shot, and lost 72-74.

Though the blue and white faithful were just a matter of seconds away from storming the court, the Nittany Lions won’t have the legion of blue to back them this time around when they head into one of the most difficult places to play in the country: the Crisler Center in Ann Arbor.

Michigan’s lone loss on the year came at the hands of Wisconsin just four days after the Wolverines took down the blue and white.

Since that loss, the maize and blue have won six-straight, including key victories over then-ranked No. 5 Nebraska and in-state rival No. 7 Michigan State in the past week.

Penn State improved to 10-12 on the season after snapping an eight-game losing streak and picking up its first conference win against Minnesota on Sunday.

The Nittany Lions last won in the Crisler Center in Jan. of 2020, in Juwan Howard’s first season at the reins. The Wolverines hold a 40-17 all-time series lead over the blue and white and are nearly perfect at home, holding a 24-3 lead in games played in Ann Arbor.

Its loss to Michigan a month ago was just the start of a slippery slope for Penn State. With its first 11 conference opponents holding a combined record of 70-50, the youngest team in the Big Ten was bound to face challenges.

However, the Nittany Lions’ remaining schedule gets lighter, with their remaining six opponents having a combined record of 27-38.

Penn State freshman Kayden Mingo, who hit the game-winner against the Golden Gophers, is the third-highest scoring freshman in the Big Ten, averaging 14.1 points, 4.7 assists and 2.1 steals per game.

Mingo was dealing with a broken nose and did not play against Michigan when the Wolverines came to State College last month.

Ivan Juriċ, who didn’t play on Sunday against Minnesota because of an illness, was Penn State’s leading scorer against Michigan a month ago, dropping 20 points and grabbing four boards.

Josh Reed and Freddie Dilione V are coming off one of the best games of their careers against Minnesota, with Reed falling just shy of a new career-high and Dilione, the only returning Nittany Lion starter from a season ago, matching his career-high mark of 25 points.

Six-foot-nine Yaxel Lendeborg is the Wolverines’ leading scorer, averaging 14.7 points and 7.2 rebounds per game. He is coming off a 26 point double-double performance against the Spartans.

Sophomore Morez Johnson Jr., a transfer from Illinois, has also been a key piece of the offense for May and Michigan this season.

Johnson is shooting 68.8% from the field and has five 10-plus rebound games this season. The 255-pound big man netted a career-high 29 points against USC earlier this year and also led the Fighting Illini in offensive rebounds as a freshman.

In three years under Mike Rhoades, Penn State has four wins over top-15 ranked teams and one over a top-10 team.

On Thursday, the Nittany Lions seek Rhoades’ first-ever top-five win and second top-two win in program history.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State notebook | Matt Campbell talks new staff, Rocco Becht on National Signing Day
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
When Matt Campbell took the podium in Beaver Stadium for the first time, there were just two signees in the 2026 class on board for Penn State.

A little less than two months later, Campbell has bumped that number up to 15 with a mix of former Iowa State signees and a few others as he works to rebuild a roster that lost 50 players to the transfer portal.

Campbell spoke with the media for the first time since his introductory press conference on Wednesday for National Signing Day, touching on the craziness of the last two months, Penn State’s new quarterback and more.

Here’s what the Nittany Lions’ first-year coach had to say.

The last two months

Campbell was tasked with navigating the transfer portal, adjusting to a new home, recruiting and retaining current Penn State players all in just two months. He’s taken over jobs before at Toledo and Iowa State, but the portal was vastly different in 2016 when he became the Cyclones’ head coach.

That change made the last two months a “whirlwind” for Campbell, so he relied on what he learned the last 10 years at Iowa State to get him and his staff through.

“The landscape that we're in is so completely different. And that's not a positive or a negative, it's just different,” Campbell said. “And I think what Iowa State taught me is you have to go in and you have to figure out what is going on, what are the positives, what are the areas of growth, and how do you make the right moves moving forward? And I think that's what I learned from my Iowa State experience — that you don't have all the answers.”

While those were the similarities from 2016 to 2026 for Campbell, he expressed how the differences, such as the transfer portal, were difficult. Still, his vision for Penn State helped guide him through.

“I think the difference, obviously, was probably the player acquisition piece,” Campbell said. “How do you build a current team to move forward? How do you build a foundation? And again, there's probably some areas that you wish you didn't have to deal with, and then there's probably some other areas you're really grateful that you had the ability to deal with.”

New coordinators

Campbell elected to bring in Taylor Mouser from Iowa State to be the Nittany Lions’ next offensive coordinator, a position where fans are searching for success after three seasons of subpar offensive play.

Mouser only has two seasons of offensive coordinator experience, but Campbell felt comfortable having him make the jump to the Nittany Lions, as he considers Mouser “one of the up-and-coming bright minds in college football.”

“I think no matter who we played, where we played, what it played, I think we really gave ourselves a great opportunity to have great success offensively,” Campbell said. You've watched him really kind of mature in terms of who he's become as a playcaller, a great leader of people. Again, when you put the coordinator title to any of these coaches, I think you're expecting a gentleman and somebody that's got unbelievable leadership ability in the ability to align and unify a group, and Taylor's done a great job of that.”

As for the defensive coordinator spot, Campbell spoke with Jon Heacock, his defensive coordinator at Iowa State, after the last game of the 2025 season. There, Heacock told him he might be done coaching football.

Fast forward to December, and Campbell tried to see if Heacock wanted to continue coaching for him, but the long-time defensive coordinator decided it was time to retire. So Campbell went to the drawing board, zeroing in on USC’s D’Anton Lynn.

“The first name that we came up with was coach Lynn,” Campbell said. “From talking to some people that I have great respect for even in house, of some of our own coaches that had come with me, just felt like that was the number one target for the style of defense we wanted to play. For somebody that understood Penn State football, that wanted to be here, that wanted to be a part of this program, that had a passion for Penn State. I felt like that was critical.”

Rocco Becht

Another piece that Campbell worked to keep with him was quarterback Rocco Becht. Campbell said he feels as though a quarterback and head coach need to be “tied at the hip” in today’s era of college football, and he and Becht have that relationship already.

“I believe Penn State football is integrity, character, class, excellence, grit. He embodies every one of those traits,” Campbell said. “And so to me, I just felt like that was such a critical opportunity for him to finish his career with us, and the start of Penn State football, to get somebody that I truly believe embodies what the excellence of this football program stands for, both on and off the field.”

Becht is coming off a torn labrum in his non-throwing shoulder, an injury he picked up with a few weeks left in the regular season. Campbell said Becht had to get “shot” up every Tuesday and Wednesday just so he could practice.

It’s that toughness that Campbell didn’t want to leave behind.

“He's tough and as competitive as any football player I've been around,” Campbell said. “So I think he brings those traits with him. And again, really proud of what he's about and really excited for him to continue to lead and grow within our football program.”

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Big Ten Recap | Conference classics, first wins headline jam-packed week
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Big Ten continued to display over the past week why it’s the pinnacle of sport at this level. Whether it be from thrilling performances, unpredictable volatility or just the hierarchical order that’s been tested all year long, the conference’s had it all on the hardwood in its recent games.

With that being said, let’s glance at the most important moments in the Big Ten, both good and bad.

Conference classics

The last week of Big Ten basketball may have contained some of the best play it’ll have all year.

From Penn State’s Kayden Mingo hucking up a program-needed buzzer-beater that’ll get covered later in this article, to a clash of the basketball version of the Battle of the Paul Bunyan Trophy, there’s no shortage of memorable moments around the conference.

That rivalry clash actually was one of the week's lesser climactic moments, as top-10-ranked Michigan State and Michigan looked like one of the best games of the season, but instead the Wolverines cruised to a 12-point victory in East Lansing.

Illinois put up two memorable outings, the first of which came in late Jan. 24 when Keaton Wagler contributed a single-game Big Ten high of 46 points in an upset over Purdue.

The Fighting Illini weren’t done there in showing why the Midwest isn’t just flyover states, but displays of hooping excellence, when they traveled to Nebraska and enacted another road upset, as Wagler this time contributed 28 points.

Another Midwest school contributed a classic, though this time on the west: Indiana traveled to UCLA for a one-point double-overtime thriller, decided at the free throw line. Five scorers reached 20 or more points, and five also fouled out, in a game that had it all.

Phony Trojey

USC basketball sports one of the best overall records in the Big Ten at 16-6, but when you start diving further, the Trojans begin to look like paper tigers. All six losses came in conference play, and advanced metrics like KenPom and Evan Miyakawa’s Bayesian metrics only place USC in the middle of the pack, below teams with less attractive records.

Over the past week of play, that’s only been reinforced, as USC strengthened its streak of tightly decided contests. The Trojans haven’t had a game decided by more than ten points since a Jan. 13 win over Maryland, a bottom-of-the-conference competitor.

USC's last four games resulted in a mixed record: it faced top-half teams Wisconsin and Iowa and bottom-half teams Rutgers and Northwestern. USC only defeated the Badgers and the Scarlet Knights from that stretch, with one possession deciding both games.

War is over

Inside the Big Ten, glances at the little guys matter just as much as those dominating the standings, and in a clash with 17th seed tournament implications, bottom dwellers Penn State and Northwestern faced off.

The Wildcats secured their first home conference win, to the Nittany Lions' dismay, who were embarrassed in the contest 94-73, when it looked like they had an opportunity to put up a fight entering the game.

The blue and white eventually made good on its effort to reverse a string of losses when it earned its first Big Ten win at the buzzer against Minnesota in a Kayden Mingo move that had as many spins, rotations and folds as a laundromat.

It may not be the cleanest way to earn its first conference win, but it’s needed in Happy Valley, and it's reasonable to just let them have this one. Before this win, the Nittany Lions men’s and women’s teams started 0-21 in Big Ten play.

Penn State joins Oregon and Maryland, the latter of whom thumped the Nits in January, as the teams with only one Big Ten win. The Ducks host the blue and white on Feb. 14 for a West Coast road trip, after which the Nittany Lions also visit Washington.

Sure, the top of the conference looks stacked more than ever, and there are real contenders for national honors of that batch. But with the Big Ten postseason expanded this year to include all conference participants, the order of those at the bottom matters just as much, as it positions them to make rumblings with that new opportunity.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Column | 20 missed calls: Going analog as a college student
author: Jadzia Santiago | The Daily Collegian
description:
While at home over winter break, I made a miraculous discovery: my old MP3 player, stuffed to the brim with the emo(ish) music I loved in 2016 as an oddball preteen.

Nostalgic joy aside, one of the main things I got excited about was something I hadn’t had the privilege of doing in years: listening to music without my phone or laptop — music I wasn’t paying $12.99 a month to listen to without ads, might I add!

I’ve been meaning to reduce my screentime for a while now. Too much screen time for adults can impact your eyes, brain matter and mental health, according to Stanford Lifestyle Medicine.

For those of you who are still teenagers, you aren’t off the hook. The CDC says all that (and more!) about you.

And that’s just screens alone, without all the nasty social media stuff at play.

I won’t argue that there’s no such thing as good screen time. Reading, writing or being otherwise creative, talking to friends or even just doing something mindless for a bit to unwind can be beneficial.

However, I’d argue that’s not what the majority of us are doing. Cue the image of myself at 2 a.m., bleary-eyed, hair in a terrible bun, hunched over an assignment or the social media app of my choosing.

Far from educational, I’d argue. And of course, aside from the information I just cited, there’s anecdotal (trust me, bro) evidence that it rots your brain.

This is a strong opinion for this column, but I’ll say it anyway: being chronically online makes you (royal) insufferable. You end up not only with a poor attention span, but with a poor understanding of how the real world works.

I’ve made fun of this before, but no, that girl you don’t like isn’t an “energy vampire” or a “covert female vulnerable narcissist” with “avoidant tendencies” that you need to establish “boundaries” with and “cleanse your energy” from.

Do you KNOW what those words mean? WHY are you putting them together? You sound AI-generated—

Deep breaths.

There are, of course, plenty of alternatives to the doomscroll (either through social media or, worse, through Canvas), but I’m sure we’ve all heard them ad nauseam.

Despite me encouraging myself and others to go offline, I recognize that it’s getting harder and harder to do. Social pressure to be “in the know” aside, it’s not exactly like we live in uneventful times.

Even besides that, every basic necessity has ended up on some sort of screen.

I mean, Penn State is pushing mobile student IDs, making it so students have to choose between the essentially-required-on-campus mobile id+, or the

required-to-prove-you’re-a-student-everywhere-else physical id+. Very streamlined, you see.

We seemingly live in a world where we’re required to have a smartphone with us at all times, and as such, people expect to have access to us … at all times.

Doesn’t matter whether you’re in class, the shower, an important meeting or your own personal zone, every notification requires an instant response. Your parents/boss/friend/professor won’t wait forever (more than an hour tops).

Speaking of, I can’t deny that having to do assignments entirely online significantly ups my screen time.

I’m not saying that professors shouldn’t use Canvas, as I for one like being able to check schedules, syllabi and grades. However, I find that in my classes where tech use isn’t required, I’m not only more focused but less stressed.

Despite an earlier deadline seeming more difficult, I know I’m not alone when I say that knowing my professor has my essay or my quiz by the end of class is a lot less nerve-wracking than fighting to get it in by 11:59 p.m. Nor do I have to worry about some hidden reading or assignment I missed on Canvas, a message I didn’t get or my grade tanking with no explanation until next class (or a frantic email).

One might even argue that because students can now access assignments at any time, some course workloads might have gotten heavier — and that the same might be said about work. But hey, all alleged.

All in all, I can’t help but notice we’ve become accustomed to instant gratification from our tech, and that we’ve begun to expect that same gratification from people. And who wants to turn off their phone if it’ll blow up once they turn it back on again?

So, I don’t exactly blame you for not being as analog as you might want. Not like you can use this week’s internet therapy speak to “set a boundary” with your boss or professor — no matter how refreshing it’d be to call some of them “energy vampires.”

Sorry Dr. Professional. Have you considered you might be a narcissist? Yeesh.

In your lower screentime journey (if you’re starting at all), keep it small. Trade Spotify for an MP3 and mute your unimportant notifications. Tell your friends you’ll be offline more often and allocate the time in your day for it.

Maybe one day, we can put our collective foot down with everyone who expects things from us. But for now, baby steps.

Oh, and delete TikTok, I swear to god-

MORE COLUMNS

title: Stylish at the gym: Workout outfit recommendations
author: Alli Satterfield | The Daily Collegian
description:
Athleisure has become a part of many people’s everyday wardrobe in recent years, which has provided comfort and ease while getting dressed. But, it’s left us with the question: what do we wear when working out? Since athleisure has taken over our day-to-day style, what’s left for the gym?

I’m someone who loves working out. I’ll try anything once, but I love running, weight-lifting and yoga, and I haven’t fallen victim to every single athletic-fashion trend. These are some of my staple pieces for a great workout.

Hoka

I am the proud owner of two pairs of Hoka Arahis. I have a bright blue and purple pair of Hoka Arahi 7s and a black and white pair of Hoka Arahi 8s. They are some of the lightest and comfiest shoes that have ever graced my feet, and as someone with a high arch, I can’t recommend them enough in terms of support.

They are great running shoes, and the later model has more curvature in the design of the outsole, which helps to cradle my feet and add to the rock in my stride. I love running outside in them because I feel like they push me to be so much faster.

The earlier model Arahi 7s are also insanely comfortable, but they have less of a dramatic curve in the shoe. I love wearing them on the treadmill and on more dynamic footing, like trails and cobblestone, because the flatter nature of the shoe helps me connect to the ground and feel secure.

I’ve never tried Red Bull, but I promise that my Hokas give me wings.

Aerie flare leggings

Although not for running, Aerie’s flared leggings are some of the best pants I have ever put on my body. They are very soft, but they are also able to wick sweat extremely well, and I’ve found it’s difficult to find that combination in a lot of workout clothing.

I also love the cross-over design on the waist. It looks incredibly flattering, but it also feels great. The V-shaped design allows for more airflow and comfort, while also framing features like a high-waisted legging would.

Old Navy Activewear

Brands like Hoka, Aerie and Lululemon can get a little pricey after a while, and if you’re anything like me, you work out a lot and wear down your gym clothes quickly. You don’t want to be spending a fortune on clothes that get disgusting in a matter of months. That’s why I love Old Navy’s activewear.

It’s not crazily expensive in the way other brands are. But, it offers similar designs, materials and technologies that deliver exactly what you want in your workout clothes. Plus, it seems to me Old Navy is almost always running some kind of buy-one-get-one or discount promotion that makes their brand even more appealing.

At this point, I have probably gone through 10 pairs of shorts and five pairs of leggings from Old Navy, and when I make my current pairs threadbare, I will be a return customer.

Asics quick lyte socks

As previously mentioned, I’m a runner, and I’m one who’s very picky about the way her socks feel. I don’t like them too thick because, frankly, I don’t want sweaty toes. I also have a wide foot, so I want the kind of stretch and compression that can come from thicker material blends.

These Asics socks are perfect.

I’ve now purchased multiple packages of them, and wear them any time I put any kind of athletic shoe on my feet. They wick sweat well, compress my feet and reduce soreness and stretch enough to get around my wide, wide foot. They also fit very well inside my Hokas and, when my feet start to swell from running, they don’t make the shoe feel too tight.

The free T-shirt you got from a volunteer event

Matching sets are not necessarily my thing. I love an oversized tee to exercise in. They make me feel so comfortable and, even if I’m having a low body-confidence day, I know that my large tee will make me feel my best.

Another plus is that they’re free. Athleisure can get pretty expensive pretty quickly, and if you’re shopping for a new gym wardrobe because of a New Year’s Resolution or new goal to work out more, you might not want to buy everything at once and that’s okay. Use your old pajamas, volunteer and 5k T-shirts. I promise you’ll feel like a superstar.

Enjoy your workout!
