title: Column |  What to expect entering Year 1 of Penn State women’s lacrosse under Kayla Treanor
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Anticipation is building ahead of Penn State’s 2026 season, kicking off this weekend.

The Nittany Lions are led this year by new coach Kayla Treanor, who has lofty expectations for her team every time they step on the field.

In 1-on-1 interviews with Treanor and players, all spoke of their championship mindset and desire to win the NCAA tournament this year.

While Treanor doesn’t have a championship under her belt as a head coach or athlete, she’s spent significant time playing and coaching on the biggest stage. Treanor participated in six Championship Weekends from 2013 to 2024 and, as the associate head coach, won the 2021 NCAA Championship with Boston College.

Despite this success, how will Penn State’s first season under Treanor go? Players, coaches, and some fans believe this year will be a championship season, but is that possible in her first year at the helm?

I think there are two logical outcomes for the Nittany Lions’ season — a good season or a great season. Penn State is destined for greatness under Treanor, but it’s just a matter of how long until the blue and white reach its full potential.

Treanor has the potential to earn a trip to the national championship game this year with a solid group of returners and new faces. Erika Ho led the team with 46 goals last year, Sydney Manning earned Big Ten Freshman of the Year honors as the starting goalie in 2024 and Lauren Tinson and Maggie Driver both returned for their senior year on defense.

However, a lot needs to go right for the Nittany Lions to win it all in Year 1. Treanor’s team is under completely new leadership besides Director of Operations Katie Haus, and there’s a lot of chemistry that needs to be formed to win on the highest level.

The Nittany Lions play in a loaded conference with three teams in the IWLCA Coach’s Poll top-10 and another school slotting in at No. 15.

Between the tough conference matchups and a nonconference battle with No. 6 Princeton, Treanor’s squad has a schedule built for champions. If they can capitalize on those high-ranking matchups, the Nittany Lions could earn a spot in championship weekend.

However, that great season may be less of a reality in her first year, Penn State is still capable of a good season.

The Nittany Lions should win all, if not almost all of their nonconference games. When conference play rolls around, an upset or two could very well happen in Happy Valley, especially when Panzer Stadium is rocking.

With 12-13 wins on the year and at least one win in the Big Ten tournament, the blue and white should find itself in the NCAA tournament. From there, it can likely win a game or two.

While the Nittany Lions will likely fall short of their national championship aspirations, I believe the Nittany Lions will make the tournament but win only a game or two.

MORE LACROSSE CONTENT

title: A slam Dunkin’ | Dunkin’s 2026 Valentine’s menu review
author: Avery Pelletier I The Daily Collegian
description:
With love in the air, red and pink all around and hearts all over, the feeling of Valentine’s Day is here in State College. To match the energy of Penn State students in February, Dunkin’ released their annual Valentine’s menu for the 2026 season.

With the release of seven limited time drinks and two donuts, I had the chance to test out the new flavor combinations to see if they made me fall in love with Dunkin’.

Heart Eyes Daydream Refresher

With its flavors of strawberry and dragon fruit combined with blueberry syrup, the base of the Heart Eyes Daydream Refresher was sweet and reminded me of summertime. With their signature sweet cold foam, the mix of the sweet refresher and the milky add-in on top blended together perfectly to make a fruity yet creamy drink.

The strawberry base of this drink was by far what came through the most out of the fruit flavors to the point where I wouldn’t know there was blueberry syrup without a label.

While the overall flavor was pretty good, it was slightly too sweet for personal preference and would not be a drink I could order larger than a small.

Rating: 7/10

Chocolate Covered Strawberry Daydream Refresher

Similar to the previous drink, this refresher has a strawberry dragonfruit base, but what makes it unique is the rich, chocolate cold foam on top. This drink’s flavor profile has a good balance of both the bitterness of the chocolate and the sweetness of the strawberry flavor.

Like its name says, this drink’s flavor tastes like the classic Valentine's treat, chocolate covered strawberries, and was overall my favorite drink. While on the sweeter side, this flavor truly embodies the flavors many associate with this time of year.

Rating: 8/10

Toxic Ex-Presso Cloud Latte

The Toxic Ex-Presso Cloud Latte not only had the most creative name out of the menu, but also the most typical coffee flavor.

The taste of the bitter espresso combined with mocha syrup and the velvety chocolate cold foam, at first taste, this latte was very enjoyable. The two types of chocolate flavors were not overpowering the coffee, but brought out the richness of the espresso.

However, the aftertaste of the raspberry syrup added in this drink was where the flavors fell short. The strong coffee taste that chocolate brings out in espresso did not blend but clashed with the raspberry aftertaste.

While I liked it at first, the clash of the fruity and coffee flavors led me to not enjoy this drink as I drank more of it.

Rating: 5/10

Blush Spritz Refresher

Continuing with the strawberry pattern, this strawberry dragonfruit refresher was similar to the others, but what made it stand out was the addition of sparkling water to the base that led to a fun spin on the traditional Dunkin’ refresher.

Since the others had sweet cold foam to balance the sweetness of the fruit flavor, the “Blush Spritz Refresher” was a bit too sweet and tasted a lot like drinking a strawberry lollipop. The flavor may have been good but I could not see myself drinking more than a few sips.

Rating: 4/10

Sweet On You Cloud Latte

The name of this latte may have been very clever, but this was my personal least favorite of the seven drinks.

Even though the espresso complemented the caramel and sweet cold foam in the drink, the coconut syrup completely overpowered the other flavors. Even though I do not love coconut, I think if there was less syrup, it could have complimented the other flavors instead of tasting like drinking the syrup plain.

Rating: 1/10

Buff Chai

Usually I am not a huge fan of chai drinks, but this was an exception. It was enjoyable and the biggest surprise of all seven drinks.

With its strong spice flavors, there was no mistaking this drink for any of the others. However, the spices combined with the rich protein milk — the only drink to have it — created a flavorful yet filling drink that kept me sipping.

Not only were the spices unexpectedly delightful, the protein in this drink added an overall boost.

Rating: 7/10

The Perfect Matcha

While I wanted to believe the name of this drink, I feel as though this matcha did not live up to the title of being “perfect.”

The base of this drink is a standard matcha green tea with milk mixed in, and the sweet cold foam mixed on top makes the consistency of this drink overall thick and fluffy.

The taste of this drink however was where it fell flat. Not only did it have less Valentine’s spirit than other options, the matcha flavor was very strong and could have benefited from added sweetener.

Rating: 4/10

The Donuts

I originally anticipated a drink to be my favorite menu item, but the special donuts were the highlight of it all. Both of these donuts come in the shape of a heart, but they had red, pink and white sprinkles on top, matching the theme of the Valentine’s season.

The infamous Brownie Batter Classic Donut had an airy cake base and was stuffed with a rich chocolate filling that tasted exactly like brownie batter. The ratio of donut to filling was very good and for such a liquidy filling, the donut was not at all soggy.

The Cupid’s Choice Classic Donut may not receive the same acclimations online as the brownie batter did, but I think Cupid himself would approve of this donut. Filled with Bavarian Kreme, which was slightly tart and complimented the sweet donut base making a great, not too sweet option. The ratio of this donut was better than a standard Boston Kreme and similarly did not get soggy for the amount of cream in it.

Rating: 10/10

Final thoughts

Overall, as someone who prefers coffee as their source of energy, this menu was not necessarily my overall favorite. However, for those who skip the espresso and cold brew, this menu offers lots of different fruity and sweet options for a caffeine boost to help get through the day.

title: ‘A winner before anything’ | Penn State star Kayden Mingo’s winning mindset started at young age
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Kayden Mingo grew up playing basketball in his backyard while getting coached by his father, who made it a priority to instill a winning mentality into his son.

“When I was younger, that's the one thing my dad always implemented, whether it was football, basketball or baseball,” Mingo said in October. “That's just what my dad always told me, the most important thing is winning the game before anything. That's what I'm trying to do.”

Now, Mingo is the starting point guard for Penn State during his freshman year, making a game-winning basket in a 77-75 victory over Minnesota on Sunday. He’s the Nittany Lions’ highest-rated recruit in program history, and even though the team is 10-12 this season, that win-first mindset still flashes in his play.

Mingo’s known to be mature beyond his years within the program, always looking to improve and taking it upon himself to accomplish that. He had 12 second-half points in a close contest against the Golden Gophers after having just two first-half points.

Mike Rhoades said he called Mingo during the team’s day off on Monday and asked if he had ever made a game-winning shot like his layup versus Minnesota before. Mingo said “not like that” and making the basket felt “good,” according to Rhoades.

“Kayden can score the ball and make plays, and we all saw that, made the game-winner, but winning is most important to him,” Rhoades said Tuesday. “I think he's had that well before he got to Penn State. I hope we can magnify it even more.”

Before he could play AAU ball and during those backyard sessions with his father, he said he remembers some of the drills his father had him do, recalling one that involved making 10 straight left-handed layups.

“I remember those days just going back there and struggling,” Mingo said. “But eventually, I stayed consistent, and then I was able to play AAU. From there, it just took off.”

The Farmingdale, New York, native played for the PSA Cardinals during his AAU career, which is a grassroots basketball program based in New York City that competes on the Nike EYBL circuit.

During the 2024 season, while playing for the PSA Cardinals, Mingo averaged 18.1 points, 3.9 rebounds, 3.3 assists and 2.3 steals per game. He was named Nike EYBL Defensive MVP by The Circuit in the spring of that year, leading his team to a 19-6 record.

Alongside his AAU days, Mingo attended Long Island Lutheran High School (LuHi), which helped lay the foundation for his development as a player at a high-major college.

“I feel like I left my mark there, confidently and humbly,” Mingo said. “I feel like I was in a very good situation at LuHi, and it prepared me to come here, even though there's a lot more I learned here and a lot more experience I have with basketball.”

Mingo sat around the top of the recruiting ranks at the end of his career at LuHi, getting tabbed as a 247Sports composite 4-star and the No. 37 player nationally, No. 5 combo guard and No. 2 player in his home state.

Rhoades first heard of him during Mingo’s sophomore year of high school, when he guided LuHi to a 2023 NYS Class AA Federation championship. Rhoades circled Mingo’s name after he got to see him play.

“When I started building a relationship with Kayden, I was like ‘Hey, this guy could not just be a heck of a player for us, but he could be a cornerpiece of us building this program and how we do things,’” Rhoades said when Mingo signed with Penn State in 2024. “He’s got great talent. He has a competitive edge that I sure love.”

Rhoades said he recruited Mingo as he “really cares about the right stuff.” The coach cited some college basketball players who prioritize an eye-catching individual performance over their team winning, and he said Mingo is the opposite.

Mingo capped off his high school career by earning the New York Gatorade Player of the Year award in March 2025. He averaged 13.6 points, 5.4 rebounds, 4.1 assists and 1.9 steals per game through 27 appearances his senior year.

But beyond that high, individual honor, Mingo led his team to the 2025 Throne High School National Championship, the EYBL Scholastic League championship game and a Chipotle Nationals quarterfinals appearance.

With his high school career in the books, Mingo and his winning drive arrived in Happy Valley last June. He said it took a week or two to get used to summer workouts at Penn State.

“It was different,” Mingo said of his first practice with the Nittany Lions. “It was real high intensity, and it was just different for me, since I'm coming from high school. It was very exciting going into it, and then it was great, finally getting on the court with these guys and be able to play with brothers.”

Buzz grew within the program this past offseason on his potential. Rhoades said Mingo was given the “keys to the program” during Big Ten media days in October.

Even though Penn State as a team didn’t have much outside expectations — the Nittany Lions were ranked No. 18 in the Big Ten preseason media poll — Mingo said it was an expectation of his to win as many games as possible.

“It's gonna be a young guy with a lot of opportunity to prove himself in a great league,” assistant coach Clay Conner said in October. “It'll be exciting to watch, and we're all fired up to help him along the way.”

Mingo didn’t waste any time to start showcasing his winning ability, gathering a defensive rebound before charging upcourt and getting an and-1 layup to fall late in the second half of the season-opener against Fairfield. That play kicked off a run for Penn State to earn a 76-68 win over the Stags.

Penn State is 1-10 in Big Ten play this season, but Mingo has willed the Nittany Lions to keep up with top competition at times, like him tallying 11 points and eight assists during a 76-72 loss to then-No. 9 Michigan State on Dec. 13. His performance prompted Spartans head coach Tom Izzo to say he’s “a Mingo fan” postgame.

Mingo said he sees himself making the NBA once his collegiate career is over. He’s averaging 14.1 points, 3.6 rebounds, 4.7 assists and 2.1 steals per game through 19 appearances this season, showing a tough playstyle that wants to win.

“I'm a winner before anything,” Mingo said. “I can get downhill as a guard, I can shoot the three pretty well. I get my teammates involved very well, and I have a knack for locking up on defense.”

title: Olympic preview | Matilde Fantin, Italy’s road to gold in 2026 Olympics
author: Jimmy Blair | The Daily Collegian
description:
As Italy prepares to host the 2026 Winter Olympics, the Italian women’s hockey squad is preparing to put on a show in its home country. One of Penn State’s own talents, Matilde Fantin, is ready to make a name for herself on the world stage.

Going into the competition, Fantin looks to be one of Italy’s top threats on offense. They will have their work cut out for them, as Italy was drawn into Group B, alongside Japan, Sweden, Germany and France. Because Italy received an automatic bid to the group stages as the host country, all Group A teams will advance to the quarterfinals, while the top three squads from Group B will fill out the next round.

According to ESPN’s projections, Italy has the second-lowest odds to take gold in women’s hockey. However, an overwhelming home-ice advantage could give the squad the boost they need to make it out of the group stage, and potentially make a run in the tournament.

Step One: Preliminary Rounds

Italy opens its campaign against France on Thursday at 8:40 a.m. EST. It faces Sweden next, two days later, on Saturday at the same time. Italy faces Japan on Monday at 6:10 a.m. EST, followed by Germany the next day at 10:40 a.m.

As long as Italy doesn’t drop to the bottom two of the group, the hosts will be through the quarterfinals.

Step Two: Quarterfinals

Italy needs to secure a top-three finish in Group B to reach the quarterfinals, meaning Fantin and the team have to make every game count to achieve a feat they haven’t done for the first time since the 2006 Turin Olympics.

Assuming they make it through, international juggernauts like Team USA, Canada, Finland and Switzerland will all make it through. The Italians will have to face off against one of these sides or one of the nations from Group B that also advanced.

Since Italy hasn’t made it to the quarterfinals in 20 years, they will certainly have a chip on their shoulder. If they can take advantage of their home-ice advantage, the Italians may be able to achieve what they never achieved before.

Step Three: Semifinals

This would be a dream scenario for the Italians, as they have never made it this far in the tournament. Italy will most likely face off against one of the top nations in the world on its home ice.

If the Italians can handle the pressure, control all three areas of the ice and maybe add in a bit of Olympic magic, the unthinkable could happen.

Step Four: Finals

The Italians will have to defeat one of the world's top squads to reach their first-ever final and will likely face Team USA or Team Canada for the gold medal.

Italy has never taken a medal in ice hockey in its history, and there is no better time than to break the standard and hoist silverware in its home country on the biggest stage, not just for Fantin, but for the entire Italian squad, as well.

MORE OLYMPICS CONTENT

title: Position preview | Penn State women’s lacrosse midfielders feature many freshmen, transfers
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Less than two months after being named the new women’s lacrosse coach at Penn State, Kayla Treanor hit the transfer portal and brought one of her former athletes to Happy Valley.

Between Julia Basciano’s arrival, the return of Maggie Rezza and several new freshmen, the Nittany Lions’ midfielders have a strong core to take the field this season.

Returners

Despite having many returners, Penn State’s midfield lineup is relatively inexperienced, with just one athlete having starting experience last year.

Sophomore Rezza is back for more after her strong freshman year. The Ambler, Pennsylvania, native played in all 16 games last year, starting four, and notched three goals and an assist.

The only other returner who scored last year is senior Maddie Greco.

Greco has only played in 22 games through her first three years and has yet to make a start. However, she recorded her first career goal and assist last year, both coming against USC.

Seeing action in 12 games last year, Allie Meyer returns for year two. Meyer recorded an assist, three ground balls and four draw controls in her freshman year.

Redshirt sophomores Evelyn Scallion and Ryan St. Pierre played in two games and one game, respectively, but finished without a stat line.

Alexa Kairis, Dakota Cristo and Abby Baker were all on the roster last year, but didn’t see any playing time.

Freshmen

The Nittany Lions brought in three freshmen to add to the midfield room this year, all hailing from outside the Keystone State.

Hannah Hoyt joins Penn State from Hopkinton, New Hampshire, where she was named a USA Lacrosse All-American.

From Winston Salem, North Carolina, Kate Dennen earned significant recognition in her conference as a three-time all-conference honoree. In 2024, she earned all-state recognition after back-to-back state championship appearances.

Anna Mellinger rounds out the freshmen midfield class, coming from Milton, Georgia. Mellinger was a three-time GHSA 7A state champion and was named a USA Lacrosse All-American.

Transfers

Basciano transferred to Penn State in July after four years at Syracuse. Despite only recording three career starts, the Glenmoore, Pennsylvania, native has a lot to play for after sustaining a season-ending injury last year.

The former Syracuse midfielder was named one of four captains this year and was the only one who was new to Penn State’s squad.

Anna Salerno comes to Happy Valley for her graduate season after four years at Mount St. Mary’s.

Just across the border in Maryland, Salerno started in 49 out of 55 games during her time with the Mountaineers, scoring 110 goals with 11 assists.

title: Penn State notebook | Mike Rhoades says Kayden Mingo didn’t travel, gives injury update
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Coming off Penn State’s first Big Ten win of the season, Mike Rhoades was back in the Bryce Jordan Center on Tuesday for his weekly press conference.

Rhoades acknowledged a ruling from Sunday’s win over Minnesota that stirred controversy, and provided the latest on the team's injuries.

Here’s more of what Rhoades said.

Did Kayden Mingo travel?

Guard Kayden Mingo scored the game-winning basket in Penn State’s 77-75 victory over the Golden Gophers. A debate via social media has sparked over whether Mingo traveled during the play.

Rhoades said he didn’t think it was travel, citing how the game is called nowadays.

“As much basketball that we all watch over the course of the last year or two, no, it's not a walk,” Rhoades said. “I think the game keeps changing and evolving, and I think it evolves the way the game's played. I think it's the way it's officiated.”

Mingo drove into the paint, pivoted several times, lifted his pivot foot and took a step through to lay in the basket.

Rhoades said his coaching staff discussed a couple of weeks ago that plays like Mingo’s are being ruled not a travel and haven’t seen it get called.

“You weren't allowed to jump, stop and pivot at one time, and now you are,” Rhoades said. “People call it an extra step. It's a pivot step. So no, I don't think it is (a travel) because I'm watching all these games and it's not being called.”

Injury updates

Penn State is dealing with injuries to forward Saša Ciani, forward Tibor Mirtič, 7-footer Ivan Jurić, and wing Eli Rice. Rhoades didn’t give a direct answer when asked if any of them would be available Thursday night against Michigan.

"It's all day to day,” Rhoades said. “Just making sure these guys are doing what they need to do to see if they can get back to us and win.”

Jurić woke up with a fever prior to the Nittany Lions’ win over Minnesota on Sunday, causing him to miss the game. Ciani has missed the last two matchups due to an ankle injury.

Mirtič exited the Michigan game on Jan. 6 due to a knee injury. He recently returned to practice after the knee injury, but during that return, he tweaked his shoulder. He’s been seen wearing a sling on his left arm while sitting on the bench during the last two games.

Rice exited the Minnesota game at the 12:47 mark of the second half and didn’t return. He was getting evaluated after he hit his head on a Minnesota player.

Fatigue with short bench

Penn State gave up a 10-point lead in the final couple of minutes of Sunday’s game against Minnesota before Mingo’s game-winning basket. Some of that could be attributed to fatigue as the Nittany Lions were dealing with a short bench.

“One way to avoid fatigue is to go to your bench,” Rhoades said. “When you don't have a bench, then you gotta call some time outs. You got to sub some guys before media timeouts so they could get some dead-time rest, as we like to call it. So you got to be a little strategic that way.”

Rhoades instilled an “empty the tank” mentality in players prior to facing the Golden Gophers. It worked out as Penn State got the victory, but moving forward, the team’s rotation could be as small as seven players, depending on the availability of the current injuries.

Furthermore, Rhoades stuck with the same five players down the stretch in the Minnesota game. Mingo, guard Freddie Dilione V, guard Melih Tunca and forward Josh Reed all played above 30 minutes in Sunday’s game, and guard Dominick Stewart was right behind at 29 minutes.

“That's the balance that we're going to be in right now, is trying to get guys to the finish line,” Rhoades said. “We're not a team that we can take plays off. No way. I thought we did a really good job of that on Sunday. I thought we emptied our tank. We were fatigued, which most teams are, in the last three-four minutes of the game. We just got to find a little bit more to finish cleaner than we did.”

title: State College Borough Council discuss resolution regarding ICE reform
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
The State College Borough Council discussed a resolution on Monday calling for the federal government to make “timely and meaningful” reforms to operations conducted by Immigrations & Customs Enforcement (ICE).

The resolution, codified as resolution #1436, was proposed by council member Matt Herndon who cited the need for ICE to safeguard constitutional rights, the fatal shootings of Renee Good and Alex Pretti during ICE operations in Minneapolis and efforts by the federal government to provide their own narrative to justify both incidents despite publicly available footage.

Herndon said while the council is in support of the lawful enforcement of immigration and other federal laws to ensure public safety, it does not condone the actions of ICE and the federal government which “undermine public trust and raise serious constitutional concerns.”

“These matters are of direct relevance to the Borough of State College, as federal immigration enforcement actions have occurred within the broader community, creating reasonable and immediate concern for the safety, rights, and constitutional protections of residents, workers, and visitors,” Herndon said.

Council President Evan Myers said it was important to make clear the council’s stances on ICE’s — and other federal agencies’ — conduct, especially since other state officials such as Governor Josh Shapiro have already made their own statements on the matter.

“As regimes flail and fail, they strike out at anyone and everyone that would criticize them, and they are now coming for us,” Myers said.

Kevin Kassab, another council member, said the council should consider implementing protections for State College’s immigrant population should the resolution cause repercussions from the federal government.

He said the council should raise more awareness on its policies regarding immigration operations and posited the possibility of having Penn State provide legal resources to residents.

Council Member Nalini Krishnankutty said she has been monitoring the actions by local governments in Cincinnati and Chicago in responding to ICE’s conduct and called on the council to discuss more actionable measures in conjunction with other parts of the Centre Region.

Gopal Balachandran, another council member, said he was skeptical that measures such as body cameras being required for federal agents would reduce the chances of an incident occurring between them and citizens

He said he was worried the borough may be standing alone in its position through not having the support of the rest of the Democratic Party, considering seven Democrats voted with Republicans to pass a bill increasing ICE funding through the House of Representatives on Jan. 22.

Council Member John Hayes said he saw the resolution as a way to ask for accountability through checking ICE’s power.

“I appreciate that people that look like me will not bear the brunt of this but I also need to be able to look my children in the eye, or look at my grandchildren in the eye 25 years from now, and say that I said ‘enough’ and ‘this was shameful’ and ‘it's time to stop,’” Hayes said. “We’re asking for accountability.”

After further discussion among the council and the receiving of public comments, the resolution was tabled for discussion at a future meeting.

title: Penn State women’s basketball reflects on performance while looking for 1st conference win
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Amidst an 11-game losing streak, Penn State is looking for any sign of hope to earn a Big Ten tournament berth with a month left.

Despite the recent struggles, the Lady Lions have been united and at their best over the past few days. With a week off between their last game against Minnesota on Jan. 28 and this week’s matchup against Purdue on Wednesday, the Lady Lions have taken full advantage of their practice.

“We’ve had our best three practices, probably, of the year this week with the off-week and bye-week,” coach Carolyn Kieger said. “I think we’re really excited going into this game to have players back and players healthy and build off momentum from getting our full squad back together.”

Penn State hasn’t won a game since Dec. 20, when it defeated now-coachless VCU 78-66 at the 4 Tha Culture Holiday Classic. Since then, the blue and white has lost both Amiya Evans and Gracie Merkle to injury and has awaited their return.

During the bye week, Kieger had her entire squad back together practicing for the first time since early January when Evans was listed on the Jan. 11 availability report.

While Merkle and Evans’ statuses are still up in the air for Wednesday’s game, the frontcourt duo being back at practice has been a huge boost to Penn State’s team morale.

“Getting Amiya back has been huge for us in practice,” Kieger said. “She’s such an emotional leader for us, and we’ve missed her drastically over the last couple weeks. Having her back has been a huge spark, she’s got a great presence.”

With a full squad on the horizon, Kieger’s focus on one game at a time has shifted more toward qualifying for the Big Ten tournament.

Over the final month of the season, the Lady Lions’ opponents average just 3.6 conference wins so far compared to January’s opponents, who averaged 6.3 wins.

“We obviously have some games against people that are around us in the rankings,” Kieger said. “We have an opportunity to jump up here and win and play. Purdue’s our first opportunity, and we’re going to do everything we can to take advantage of that.”

Ahead of Wednesday’s trip to Purdue, Kieger’s team has prepared for the Boilermakers’ balanced team and pressuring them defensively.

“I think the scariest thing about Purdue is that any given night, someone could go off for 20,” Kieger said. “We want to exploit their turnovers and their lack of ball-handling guards in the back court.”

As Purdue is the third-slowest team in the Big Ten, Penn State holds the advantage with its quick pace of play, and will look to use that on Wednesday and in games moving forward in an effort to make the Big Ten tournament.

“Everything motivates us,” Kieger said. “We’re trying to win every game that we play, we’re competitors. We’re focused on Penn State and what we got to do.”

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State's 2027 matchup against Northwestern debut of Ryan Field
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
New information for Penn State's 2027 matchup against Northwestern has been released.

The Nittany Lions will take on the Wildcats at Ryan Field, which will be the first time a game will be played there after construction the past two years.

Northwestern has had its home games the last two seasons at Martin Field, a lakefront spot on campus, as well as Wrigley Field, the home of the Chicago Cubs.

On top of the new location, the date for the contest has changed, moving from Oct. 3 to Oct. 2.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field rises in latest USTFCCCA poll
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After another record-setting weekend in Happy Valley, Penn State saw improvements in the latest poll.

Checkpoint No. 2 ✅Big performances shook up the national landscape.USTFCCCA TFRI is presented by @AthleticdotNet.https://t.co/sRc7uquFq8 pic.twitter.com/QpzwtOvIbe— USTFCCCA (@USTFCCCA) February 3, 2026

The men's team rose four places to No. 4 in the nation while the women's team moved up 13 places to No. 18

The Nittany Lions hosted the Penn State National Open last weekend, experiencing several new school records.

Nick Sloff opened the competition with a record-breaking mile, running 3:54.90 to win the race.

Later that evening, Handal Roban broke the men's 800-meter record with a time of 1:44.91 — the second-fastest time in NCAA history. Hayley Kitching ran a 2:00.01 in the women's 800m, breaking the school record and setting the No. 7 time in NCAA history

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling's PJ Duke falls in latest InterMat rankings
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
After the first BJC Dual of the season, Penn State had minimal movement in the most recent InterMat rankings.

The Nittany Lions came out victorious in the dual against Nebraska, 26-12.

The only movement in the rankings was at 157 pounds. PJ Duke dropped one spot to No. 4, allowing Antrell Taylor, who beat Duke, to move up to No. 3.

In the rest of the rankings, Luke Lilledahl maintained his top spot at 125 pounds. Marcus Blaze remained at No. 4 at 133 pounds. At 141 pounds, Braeden Davis stayed at No. 12 after losing to No. 4 Brock Hardy.

Shayne Van Ness, Mitchell Mesenbrink, Levi Haines, Rocco Welsh and Josh Barr all maintained their top rankings at their respective weight classes.

To round out the rankings, Cole Mirasola remained at No. 12 following his 2-1 loss to No. 4 AJ Ferrari.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: What had Penn State wrestling so fed up with Nebraska? | The Mat Return
author: The Daily Collegian wrestling staff
description:
“The Mat Return” co-hosts AJ Piazza and Evan Smith came together to recap Penn State’s frustrating victory over a stubborn Cornhuskers squad.

How did the Nittany Lions overcome a dual full of stalling and heated exchanges? Why were the Nittany Lions so emotional on the mat?

The duo dove in on Braeden Davis’ post match outburst and the possible consequences stemming from the indecent.

Following that, the pair previewed the upcoming dual in Ann Arbor, Michigan, where The Daily Collegian will be on location.

MORE COVERAGE

title: ‘This is real’ | Penn State alum Dan Barefoot set to represent Team USA in skeleton
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State will be represented by several athletes in this month’s Olympic Winter Games, but few of them have a story quite as interesting as Dan Barefoot, who will be competing in skeleton, a winter sledding sport, for Team USA.

Barefoot grew up in nearby Johnstown, Pennsylvania, and attended Richland High School.

He graduated from the university in 2013 with a degree in landscape architecture. The rigor of his academics was a key force in his desire to pursue athletics after graduation.

“I probably spent like six hours a day just working in the studio in the architecture school,” Barefoot said. “There was never a moment in my day where I wasn’t doing something, and I think I got used to that. I liked staying busy, and I think that was the reason I attempted to look up the sport.”

It’s hard enough to become an Olympic athlete, let alone in a sport that most Americans haven’t even heard of. The 35-year-old credits his discovery of the unique event to a simple internet search.

“I literally just started Googling things,” Barefoot said. “That’s how I came across the sport. Alphabetically, bobsled and skeleton were near the top, and it was one of the first things I clicked on.”

While he came across the sport in an instant, the journey to its highest level hasn’t been equally as quick for Barefoot. He’s been competing for nearly a decade, this year marking his ninth year involved with the sport, and it’s been a grind to get to where he is.

Like many sports, there are several levels of competition that an athlete has to work up in order to reach the peak.

“The system is set up kind of like Major League Baseball,” Barefoot said. “The World Cup is the MLB, and there’s all these layers under it. You try your best in the lower levels, and once in a while, you get a podium spot. Then the federation moves you up to the next level, and you suck again, but eventually you get another podium spot and they move you up again.”

Barefoot spent those years working his way up the ranks until he made his first World Cup team about three and a half years ago. As the highest level of skeleton, outside of the Olympics, it was the toughest test yet for the 5-foot-10 athlete.

“It’s a dogfight up there,” Barefoot said. “I was getting my a— kicked in a couple races, but I also had a couple races that were good. At the end of the day, it’s a total points thing, so you can have a couple bad races, but if you have a couple good races, you get points for those.”

With skeleton being such a niche sport, at least on the national stage, Barefoot works as a landscape architect in addition to competing. Balancing work, training and competing became difficult as he began taking it more seriously.

“In the beginning, I was a landscape architect, and this was a thing that I was trying,” Barefoot said. “That thing that I was trying became more serious, and over time, I was putting more and more effort into the sport and working less and less.”

Ultimately, Barefoot and his superiors decided to transfer him to a part-time employee, so he could continue to pursue skeleton, and that change has worked well for both parties, so far. These games will be Barefoot’s first, and surprisingly, he initially wasn’t as excited to qualify as many would expect.

“I had no emotions,” Barefoot said. “You get so focused along the way on the small goals, like if you were driving and looking right in front of your headlights instead of down the road, and that’s the way you make progress. But then, all of a sudden, you get to your destination and you’re like ‘holy s—.’”

He ended up feeling the expected emotion when he told the people who helped him get there.

“It really wasn’t until I was texting my mom and responding to Instagram messages from friends that I had before I started the sport, guys whose couch I was sitting on, saying ‘I’m trying out for this sport,’ and they would say ‘keep at it, let’s see what happens.’ When I was messaging those guys back, all of a sudden tears started coming to my eyes, and I was like, ‘holy s—, this is real.’ Because it’s not just a journey for me. So many people have been involved.”

Skeleton is unique because of the high speeds and relatively little control the athletes have. Those factors give beginners huge adrenaline rushes, but Barefoot has grown to find peace in the uncontrollable.

“Once you fully commit to something that you know you can't back out from, metaphorically or literally, your body becomes so calm,” Barefoot said. “It locks in. All the noise that would be floating around in your head goes away.”

Despite Barefoot finding it peaceful, skeleton is undoubtedly dangerous. He had a recent run-in with a track worker that will sideline him for his first opportunity to get on the ice in Italy, but it shouldn’t have an effect in competition.

“This guy was watching the camera feed,” Barefoot said. “Expecting to see when I would start sliding, but it stopped working, and he never saw that happen. As soon as I came out of a corner, and looked up to look at the next one, I saw two legs and a shovel.”

The impact caused a tear in his deltoid, which isn’t ideal as he enters the games, but is far better than a joint or bone injury. Those injuries could have prevented an opportunity that Barefoot and those around him had been working towards for years.

“My support team, I feel like, was more important than me,” Barefoot said. “In this journey, I feel like I contributed like a third of it, and the other two-thirds is everybody supporting, sharing stories and donating. Without those pieces, I’m not here. I’m looking forward to representing them, feeling excited, and feeling grateful to potentially do a once-in-a-lifetime thing.”

It’s been a journey to get to the games for Barefoot, and he’ll finally get a chance to race on the sport’s biggest stage on Feb.12 and 13. Even though the pressure is on, he’s staying grounded as the days approach.

“Thinking about getting a medal at the Olympics doesn’t get you a medal at the Olympics,” Barefoot said. “What gets you a medal is thinking about the form, the breathing, the small stuff. My goal is to keep it simple, to really relax, enjoy the moment, trust everything that I’ve put in so far, and really lean on that.”

MORE OLYMPICS CONTENT

title: 5 ways to create the perfect Galentine's Day party
author: Ava Krysko | The Daily Collegian
description:
Not to be cliché, but most people know love comes in many forms, and doesn't always necessarily mean the relationship between a couple. Many out there may scramble to get reservations at a favorite restaurant and buy a perfect Valentine's Day gift — some may even stress about getting a date — but Feb. 14 doesn't have to be that way.

You can always celebrate the day with friends, who, let's be honest, may be the group of people you love the most. After all, why limit a fabulous holiday filled with candy, affection and hearts to romantic relationships?

Galentine's Day is meant to show love to the gal pals and bros in your life. There are so many ways to have a fun Galentine's Day party, and here are five to ensure a great time with your besties.

1) Decorate

Any proper party thrower knows that decorations are what set the mood for a get together. Boring decorations equal a boring party. Although Valentine's Day decor might not be as easy to find as other major holidays such as Christmas and Halloween, there's still plenty to choose from at stores such as Target and Michaels.

If you're on a budget for Galentine's, there's no need to worry, decorating doesn't have to be expensive. With plenty of homemade options that look just as cute, the sky's the limit.

For example, heart garlands made of red and pink construction paper or felt are perfect for stunning guests. Another option is painting wine glasses with cute Valentine's designs. Not only does this make for an adorable decoration, but also it provides drinkware.

If you doubt your crafting abilities, or simply don't want to take on crafting by yourself, you can always rope in your friends to craft decorations at the party, adding an activity. This can be especially fitting if you're celebrating Galentine's with your roommates.

2) Provide food and drinks

Possibly the best part of any party is the food. Pizza and hoagies are a classic you may want to serve, or you can go for something a bit more niche like your favorite restaurant or something you've never tried before.

Candy salads or charcuterie boards make for perfect appetizers and are aesthetically pleasing as well.

When it comes to drinks for Galentine's Day, any pink or red punch or mocktail will do the trick. You can consider making strawberry daiquiris or alcoholic shirley temples for those over 21, and edible glitter can be added to any of these options to make them shine even more.

3) Bake a sweet treat

If there's any day that's meant for a sweet treat, it's Galentine's Day. There's endless options for dessert, but anything strawberry or cherry-flavored fits the theme the best. This can include strawberry shortcake, cherry tarts or even chocolate-covered strawberries.

Baking is especially perfect for Galentine's because it's a practice that uses time and love. Whether you're doing it before the party, or creating a delicacy with your friends, baking takes a lot of heart.

4) Watch a rom-com

Although it can sometimes take suspension of reality to get into a rom-com (what are the odds you bump into a stranger that just happens to be your perfect match?) when it comes to Galentine's, rom-coms are a perfect way to spend the day.

Curling up on the couch with your best friends to gush over a sweet romance can't be beat. Moreover, rom-coms have a certain light-hearted tone that's the best for a day like Galentine's.

If rom-coms really aren't your thing, any type of movie can theoretically work. Even horror/slasher movies could possibly be romantic. After all, nothing quite says "I love you" like the terror of a serial killer.

5) Play a game

To ensure that your partygoers don't get bored, adding a game to the festivities never hurts. This can include things such as Valentine's-themed bingo or trivia.

Another idea is to have each member of your party create different slideshows to present about various topics. The subjects don't have to be boring — curating the perfect skincare routine or ex-partner horror stories can make for an interesting presentation.

Although this may fall a bit into the baking category, creating a "Hear Me Out Cake" may provide some entertainment as well. To do this, you'll need a cake, along with pictures of some unconventional people (or characters, there's no judgment here) you find attractive. Each person takes turns revealing their choices and sticking them onto the cake.

Hopefully, these tips will help you create a fun, festive Galentine's Day party with love all around.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Big Ten recap | Women’s basketball tournament draws closer amidst many upsets
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Big Ten postseason race has tightened with just over a month until the tournament, with four teams clinching their spots in Indianapolis.

In addition to the tournament clinchers, there has been significant action across the conference, including losing streaks by top-25 teams and the first conference win for a bottom-feeder.

Washington, Oregon upset Maryland

At the beginning of January, Maryland was ranked No. 7 before going on a 3-4 run. Entering last week, the Terrapins were ranked No. 16; this week’s AP rankings have them ranked No. 22.

Things haven’t been going well for Maryland, losing another pair of games last week.

After being up by 12 points entering the second half, the Terrapins gave up a 23-point third quarter to Washington. The Huskies took the game to overtime and Maryland ultimately gave up 24 points in a double-overtime window despite Yarden Garzon’s 24 points.

On Saturday, Maryland allowed 24 points in the fourth quarter to Oregon to lose its fourth-straight game and fall to 5-6 in conference play.

Indiana earns 1st conference win

While Garzon’s team hit the losing column again last week, her former team found its first win since Dec. 21.

The Hoosiers came out victorious against Northwestern on Sunday, winning 89-75 for their first conference win of the year.

Former Penn State senior Shay Ciezki continued to make her case as a future WNBA player, recording 33 points for her sixth 30-point game of the year.

Northwestern had two conference wins against Rutgers and Wisconsin heading into Sunday’s game, but fell to the 15th seed in the tournament, teetering on the brink of elimination.

USC, Illinois earn much-needed upsets

After only winning one game in the first three weeks of January, USC ended the month with a big win over then-No. 8 Iowa.

The Hawkeyes had an eight-game winning streak entering Thursday’s contest, but 20-plus point games by Jazzy Davidson and Kara Dunn gave the Trojans the 12-point victory.

Illinois earned an upset of its own, taking down the No. 25 Huskies at home.

The Fighting Illini also had a pair of 20-plus point scorers in Cearah Parchment and Berry Wallace, with Parchment recording a 23-point, 10-rebound double-double.

Battle of Michigan in OT

One of the closest games of the week came in a battle of Michigan as the Wolverines traveled to East Lansing to face Michigan State on Sunday.

It was a close contest between the two teams, as the Wolverines entered the half leading by one point.Both teams were in the top-25 entering the night, but it was No. 9 Michigan who came away victorious.

The Wolverines were led by Mila Holloway and Olivia Olson, who combined for 49 points on the day.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: 8 must-reads for Black History Month
author: Ava Krysko | The Daily Collegian
description:
Although it’s often overlooked, reading is one of the best ways to gain information, especially when learning about a different culture. When it comes to Black History Month, picking up a book can help you become a more informed and aware individual.

Whether you decide to pick up a historical fiction novel or an autobiography, reading can help you to explore things you never knew before. To get a better understanding about which books might be helpful, Penn State professors shared eight book recommendations for Black History Month.

1) "The African Origin of Civilization: Myth or Reality" by Cheikh Anta Diop

First published in 1974, this book presents historical and archaeological information to assert ancient Egyptian civilization was founded by Africans. Although white Egyptologists tried to debunk his theory, Diop argued fiercely that it was correct.

This book was recommended by Michael West, professor of African American studies, history and African studies, because he said it is "foundational for understanding global African history."

2) "Black Reconstruction" by W.E.B. Du Bois

Written by renowned author, W.E.B. Du Bois, "Black Reconstruction" tells the story of African Americans during the Reconstruction Era. It explores the ways in which Black Americans reshaped democracy and reconstructed America post-Civil War.

Also recommended by West, he said it's an important read because of "its exposition of the Black agency in the single most important event in U.S. experience."

3) "The Black Book" edited and compiled by Toni Morrison

"The Black Book," published in 1974, reads like an anthology. It contains stories and historical documents of African Americans from the beginning of slavery to the mid-20th century in America.

According to Professor Carmin Wong, a research assistant who recommended the book, "The Black Book” serves as a visual and documentary archive of Black history in the United States, as it uses photographs, ephemera and historical records to center Black life and cultural memory.

Additionally, Wong said Morrison makes Black history accessible for wider audiences.

"Morrison was acutely aware of readership, who these stories are written for, who has access to them and who has been excluded," Wong said. “‘The Black Book’ reflects this awareness with compilations of historical records in a way that invites engagement from readers who may not otherwise encounter Black history in institutional archives or academic texts."

4) "How Europe Underdeveloped Africa" by Walter Rodney

This book takes a look at how Europe exploited Africa's resources for themselves and created overwhelming issues when it comes to the continent’s progress in politics, society and the economy.

Wong also recommended this book and described it as, "a critical examination of colonialism and its long-term economic and social effects on the African continent and African diasporic peoples."

“Rodney argues that the exploitation of Africa led to the underdevelopment and restructuring of pre-colonial African societies, directly challenging narratives that frame colonial rule as beneficial,” Wong said.

Additionally, Wong described how the book takes a look at how colonialism reshaped racial identities of African people and how it left a lasting legacy of global inequality through structured systems of race, power and capitalism.

"I selected this text because I want to be mindful that we need to turn to Black writers across the globe in discourse on Black history, and Rodney's work provides an essential transnational framework that situates African histories and diasporic experiences as central rather than peripheral to these conversations," Wong said.

Wong said while this book is a good starting place to learn more about these ideas and understand the function of class in oppressive systems, it should still be followed up by other texts for further education.

5) "The Third Reconstruction: America's Struggle for Racial Justice in the 21st Century" by Peniel E. Joseph

"The Third Reconstruction," published in 2022, explores the idea that the racial reckoning of 2020 was the climax of the third Reconstruction period in America.

Darryl Thomas, professor of African American studies, recommended this book and said it compares the first two Reconstruction periods — along with the backlash that followed them — and how Black freedom was fostered through the end of current racial regimes.

"Joseph brings attention to the current backlash to the election of Barack Obama as a backlash against diversity, equity and Black freedom," Thomas said.

6) "Making All Black Lives Matter: Reimagining Freedom in the 21st Century" by Barbara Ransby

Another book recommended by Thomas, "Making All Black Lives Matter" focuses on the role of Black feminists in Black liberation movements.

"She (Ransby) pays special attention to the radical Black feminist and others outside of the American establishment who not only challenge mass incarceration but the marginalization of those outside of the mainstream," Thomas said. "She declares that freedom and democracy are a lifestyle as well as human rights for all."

7) "Stamped from the Beginning" by Ibram X. Kendi

Published in 2016, "Stamped from the Beginning" centers on the history of racist ideas and how they infiltrated American society.

Professor and Co-Director of the Center for Black Digital Research Christopher Dancy recommended this book and said it "details a useful history as one considers anti-Blackness in the context of U.S. history and present."

8) "Freedom Dreams" by Robin D.G. Kelley

"Freedom Dreams" chronicles a history of radical Black activism in the United States.

Dancy also recommended this book, and suggests everyone read the most recent edition which includes Kelley's reflections in modern times.

"It's a great book for contextualizing Black experiences within histories of the Black radical tradition," Dancy said.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Weekly Recap | No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey completes season sweep over Robert Morris
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
To complete a four-game home stand, No. 4 Penn State took its talents outdoors to Beaver Stadium for the first-ever outdoor hockey game in program history.

The Nittany Lions won 3-0 in Friday’s outdoor game and 5-2 on Saturday when the team returned to Pegula Ice Arena.

With its sweep this weekend over Robert Morris, Penn State took the regular-season series against the Colonials 4-0, with goaltender Katie DeSa recording shutouts in three of the four contests. The blue and white outscored the Colonials 16-2 over the season.

Penn State has now completed regular season sweeps over three conference opponents: Robert Morris, Delaware and Syracuse. It’ll have a chance to add two more teams to that running list as it concludes the season with games against Lindenwood and RIT.

Following this past weekend’s action, Penn State is now 26-4 overall, 19-1 in conference play and has won each of its last seven games. It also maintained its perfect 13-0 home record.

Outwater on top

Scoring two goals and assisting on two others against Roberts Morris this weekend was Grace Outwater.

The sophomore winger’s four points were the most among the team. It’s the second time she’s scored four points in two games this season, having done so against Syracuse in November.

Outwater found the back of the net on the power play in the second period to cut the Colonials’ lead from two goals to one. It was her 20th goal of the season, which put her above Tessa Janecke, who’s out for the Olympics, for the most in the AHA.

The Picton, Ontario, native has scored in each of her last seven games, going back to a 4-1 win on Jan. 16 over Syracuse.

Walsh’s weekend

Just over halfway through the second period in Friday’s matchup, McKenna Walsh opened the scoring, giving her the first Division I goal in Beaver Stadium. It ended her drought of 14 games without a goal.

Walsh followed up her history-making performance on Friday with another goal on Saturday to put the Nittany Lions up 3-2, giving her the game-winning goal in both games, the first two of her career.

It’s the first time she has scored in back-to-back contests in her two seasons with the blue and white.

Butze in the books

Danica Maynard scored on the power play in the second period to put Penn State up 4-2 on Saturday. With her assist on the goal, Kendall Butze passed Lyndie Lobdell for most career points by a defenseman in Penn State hockey history with the 85th point of her career.

Butze added to her numbers with an assist on a Katelyn Roberts goal to give her 86 career points.

This season, the Cleveland, Ohio, native totaled four goals and 21 assists for 25 points in 30 games played.

Six scorers

The blue and white spread the scoring love over the weekend with six different skaters finding the back of the net.

Walsh and Outwater scored in both contests, as Roberts, Maynard, Maddy Christian and Abby Stonehouse also scored a goal. Roberts inched closer and closer to the century mark after her goal served as the 95th point of her career.

Admirable attendance

Despite the below-freezing temperatures, a record-breaking number of fans braved the cold to show their support for the Nittany Lions.

With an announced attendance of 1,838 people, Penn State set a new record for the most-attended home game in program history.

The Nittany Lions will continue to wind down their regular season in Missouri when they face the Lindenwood Lions. Game 1 is scheduled at 5 p.m. Friday.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Column | Touch grass, try a tailgate
author: Julia Kushner | The Daily Collegian
description:
A beloved preparatory ritual signifying unity and controlled transgression, tailgating is so much more than a bunch of silly geese drinking their little faces off.

There’s nothing more American than college football. And there’s definitely nothing more American than a Ford F-150, burgers and dogs and an ice-cold beer on top of college football.

Tailgating is an essential part of game day. We wake up early, dress in our finest blue and white, and break all social barriers.

The usual group dynamics are totally shaken up — parents, students and alumni alike party together and celebrate their shared heritage (if you will) of Penn State ball. We come together, not as different sects of the social strata, but as a singular group with a shared interest.

It’s a lax way to socialize with both peers and adults, as you’ll inevitably end up with someone’s mother and father, their siblings and maybe even their grandparents. It’s an easy way to flex those social muscles in a setting that eliminates all awkwardness by breaching the normal rules of traditional etiquette.

As a Southerner, meeting an adult, I will still say “yes ma’am” or “no sir,” but the hesitancy of chatting with people typically above your social paygrade all but evaporates.

And so many people have this “the more the merrier” attitude. Strike up a conversation with the tailgate next to yours, and you’ll be partying with people you met five seconds ago before you know it.

Compare this with the usual attitude of more formal invitations and the Gen Z inability to even smile at your neighbors in the hallways.

And we transgress other norms as well. My freshman year, before we sold alcoholic beverages at Beaver Stadium, all of Penn State was a dry campus.

That is, except for game days. It was this unspoken rule that you better not be caught dead with liquor in 16802 — unless it was a fall Saturday, of course.

I used to love seeing 18-year-olds traipsing along Millennium Science Complex with a couple of twelve packs in their hands and the police just a hundred yards or so off pretending not to notice.

And music is played so loudly, you’d think your eardrums would burst and the police’d come knocking down your door for a noise complaint, but it’s par for the course in the fields above the stadium.

America prizes the individual, rightly so, but gamedays let us put our group above ourselves, if just for a couple of fun-filled hours. Tailgating and rooting for a team allow us to prioritize something besides our own little worlds for a change.

How nice it is to forget ourselves for a moment to watch Nick Singleton absolutely dominate with 107,000 of your closest friends.

People are able to forget about themselves and what they look like and who they’re with for the duration of the day. They’re able to loosen the death grip social media typically has on young people’s everyday lives and live in the moment while they finally touch some grass.

And there’s so much symbology. Flags fly everywhere from the stars and bars to the Nittany Lion, from fraternity letters to Nicki Minaj. Next time you find yourself at a tailgate, stop for just a moment and appreciate the camaraderie that college has afforded us.

MORE COLUMNS

title: Olympic preview | Nicole Hall, Jessica Adolfsson, Team Sweden’s path to the gold medal game
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s an Olympic year. Like every other country headed to the Milan Cortina Olympic Games, Team Sweden, with current Nittany Lion, Nicole Hall and former Penn Stater Jessica Adolfsson have a chance to take home the gold.

Taking home an Olympic gold medal is one of the oldest sporting honors, but getting there is an accomplishment of its own. Sweden is a powerhouse in the hockey world, and the women's team, commonly known in Sweden as the “Damkronorna” or “The Lady Crowns,” always held its own. Team Sweden has two medals under its belt; here are the steps it needs to take to secure gold number three.

Step One: Preliminary Rounds

Team Sweden will face Germany on Feb. 5, Italy on Feb. 7, France on Feb. 8 and Japan on Feb. 10. Depending on the results of those games, Team Sweden will advance to playoff matches in hopes of reaching the gold medal match.

Team Sweden is looking at redemption this year after a less-than-ideal finish at the 2022 Beijing Olympics, finishing eighth, which is its lowest to date. Historically, it has had a pretty decent run at the Olympics, being a powerhouse among the other teams, so a comeback could very much be in their cards.

Looking at the teams it will face, Team Germany and France are returning to the Olympic Games after some time away. Team Germany could struggle against Sweden, as this is its first Olympic appearance since 2014. Team France is making its Olympic debut this year, so taking on an established team like Sweden could be a challenge. Team Italy, featuring Nittany Lion Matilde Fantin, is returning to the games after 20 years. The most accomplished opponent Team Sweden faces in the group stages is Team Japan, which finished ahead of the Swedes at the 2022 Beijing Olympics in fifth place, so that matchup will be one to watch.

Step 2: Quarter Finals

As of now, there is no guarantee of what the four quarterfinal games will look like, but the pool of teams to choose from is strong. There are powerhouses: Team USA, Team Canada, Team Switzerland and Team Finland, against whom the remaining teams, such as Team Sweden, will have to compete.

These matchups will be quality, with every team bringing in new talent and new ideas. Team Sweden, which features young collegiate talent, may consider a new approach in these tournament stage rounds.

Team Sweden went down in the quarter finals at the 2022 Beijing Olympics, taking a brutal loss from Team Canada, 11-0. Faceoffs were a major struggle for the Swedes, who lost the majority. Confidence can carry them through the group stages and may be the reason they reach the semi-finals.

Step 3: Semi-Finals

Team Sweden has had major success in the semi-finals; the most memorable is the major upset against Team USA at the 2006 Turin Olympics, in which the team beat the Americans in a shoot out.

Team Sweden won one of their two medals at the Turin Olympics, securing silver and leaving the Americans with bronze. Reaching medal contention will be a journey, especially for a team focused on rebuilding as much as Team Sweden.

Step 4: Finals

Reaching medal contention will likely mean getting past Team Switzerland or Team Finland and, most likely, facing Team USA or Canada. The Swedish have the history, the talent and the fire. The Nittany Lions already have multiple Olympians and Olympic medalists, and Team Sweden has the potential to increase that number.

MORE OLYMPICS CONTENT

title: Column | All it takes is a few chicken nuggets
author: Daniela White | The Daily Collegian
description:
Like any young adult in college, I've been trying to convince myself for years that I won’t get homesick. For me, living in Maryland and going to Penn State, only three hours away, I never really had to worry about it too much. All it takes is a phone call from my parents and they'll come get me or I’ll make the drive home.

Now, my home for the next four months is in Barcelona, Spain, 4,000 miles away instead of just under 200 miles. I’ve switched from English to Spanish, use the Barcelona Metro instead of the “WHOOP,” and traded sweat pants for jeans from Zara.

When I first got here, I thought to myself, “I’ll be so busy, I won’t even have time to get homesick.” And I was right, at the beginning.

My second weekend here, I hopped on a plane to the Scottish Highlands. I spent two days off the coast of Spain, only an hour from Barcelona. My week was booked and busy with clubs, cafes, and repeat. I didn’t have time to get homesick. Then, I had my weekly FaceTime with my family and my mom was cruel enough to ask if I missed her.

Once she asked that single question I would get lost in my thoughts to and from class.

I would get quiet at night, knowing their sun was still shining while I was stuck with the moon. I missed them terribly.

Knowing myself, however, I knew I would drive myself crazy if I kept myself in that homesick funk, so I turned to my constants. Fast food and TV dramas.

While I grieve the absence of Chipotle and Chick-fil-a, and I can no longer hop into my car and drive through Happy Valley, I found other avenues. I turned away from the one euro tacos for a meal at KFC and McDonald's.

I finally figured out how to change the Spanish audio to English on my TV in my apartment and scrolled for hours on Hulu, watching episode after episode of cringey American shows.

When I caught a cold, I sacrificed a class absence to journey to the 24-hour markets and scour for a pack of Oreo’s and Diet Coke (or Coca-Cola Zero as they say here) and watched movies snuggled up in my bed, imagining I was back at home or in my apartment in State College.

I did anything that reminded me of being in Maryland or Penn State, keeping myself tethered to my old self while I became a new person at the same time. I worked around the time differences and reached out to my roommates back home and other friends abroad, keeping my relationships alive and constant.

I reminded myself that my life would still be there when I returned, and I reminded myself that being abroad was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

Almost a month now, I have special routines. I allow myself to eat fast food once or twice a week. I’ll have a Pink Drink from Starbucks instead of a café con leche.

While there’s so much to be seen in Barcelona, and so many new things to throw and immerse myself into, it’s important to have a balance. Give yourself some time to FaceTime your parents, or watch a Netflix movie with your roommates abroad, just to get a little taste of what’s waiting for you back at home.

MORE ABROAD COLUMNS

title: Big Ten roundup | Weekend action sees major upset, transfer portal entrance
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
While Penn State was taking down Nebraska in the Bryce Jordan Center, other conference competition occurred with some major headlines.

Ohio State maintained their undefeated season, setting up a likely unbeaten vs. unbeaten in the Bryce Jordan Center on Feb. 13. A major home upset took place in Minnesota while another conference foe earned its first win.

Ohio State stays undefeated

Ohio State defeated No. 17 Wisconsin and No. 10 Michigan in a two-dual weekend. The Buckeyes won 30-10 and 26-16, respectively, moving to 16-0 on the season.

The Buckeyes were trailing the Badgers 10-9 at the intermission, causing some major questions, but that was without their top 125-pound wrestler.

Nic Bouzakis has been alternating starts if Ohio State wrestles twice in a weekend, causing him to not wrestle against the Badgers. Wisconsin’s Nicolar Rivera won the match at 125 pounds after Vinceng Kilkeary filled in for Bouzakis.

The other headliner was the final bout between Michigan and Ohio State. No. 7 Taye Ghadiali of Michigan and No. 3 Nick Feldman went to sudden victory, where Ghadiali took down Feldman to get the upset victory. It didn’t matter for the dual, but with the postseason around the corner, Ghadiali could improve his seeding in the Big Ten and NCAA Tournament.

Minnesota upsets Iowa

No. 9 Minnesota went into Carver-Hawkeye Arena and took down No. 4 Iowa in a close battle. The Golden Gophers defeated the Hawkeyes, 21-16, on the road behind some headlining victories.

Max McEnelly didn’t have to face Angelo Ferrari, but was still tested at 184 pounds. Gabe Arnold stepped in and performed well, not allowing a takedown through seven minutes of action. With eight seconds remaining in sudden victory, McEnelly took down Arnold to get the victory, 4-1.

With Ferrari’s status still unknown, Arnold appears to be a proven wrestler who can compete with the top, but it was McEnelly who was the better wrestler, expanding the lead to 15-13.

At 157 pounds, Minnesota’s Charlie Millard, ranked No. 21, defeated No. 12 Jordan Williams by major decision. Williams was the favorite entering the match, but Millard put that to rest quickly, defeating Williams 13-3.

Michigan State earns first conference win

Two of the bottom teams in the conference, Michigan State and Northwestern, battled it out in East Lansing, Michigan. The Spartans earned their first win of the season, defeating the Wildcats, 22-20.

It was a late push from Northwestern, as the dual began at 197 pounds. With Michigan State holding a 22-9 lead after the 157-pound weight class, the Wildcats picked things up.

They needed at least a tech fall and two-major decisions, to get to the 22-point mark. Eddie Enright did his job at 174 pounds for Northwestern, winning by major decision, but the 165 pound and 184-pound class ended in decisions, giving Michigan State its first Big Ten dual win of the season.

Massoma Endene

Massoma Endene has been in the headlines for weeks. After being dismissed by Iowa in early January, it’s reported by Justin Basch that Endene will enter the transfer portal and file for a medical redshirt.

With not wrestling since November, Endene’s redshirt will likely go through giving him the chance to compete at the Division I level once again. He won a trio of Division III national championships at Wartburg College before transferring to Iowa. He was removed from the Hawkeyes’ roster and will instantly become a major target for teams with or without a major need at 197 pounds.

Endene was ranked well into the top 10 before being removed from the program, and had some hype to be the biggest test for the current No. 1 at the weight class, Josh Barr.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Penn State men's volleyball stays at No. 14 in AVCA Poll
author: Keira Albert | The Daily Collegian
description:
After this week's AVCA Poll, Penn State remains at No. 14.

Still at 1⃣4⃣ in the @AVCAVolleyball Poll#WeAre pic.twitter.com/k6WF4VF4Ha— Penn State Men's Volleyball (@PennStateMVBALL) February 3, 2026
