title: Way-too-early prediction of Penn State’s 2026 offensive depth chart
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
It’s never too early to think about next year.

Ahead of winter workouts, here’s a way-too-early prediction of what Penn State’s offensive depth chart will look like in 2026.

Quarterback

1. Rocco Becht, redshirt senior

2. Alex Manske, redshirt freshman

3. Connor Barry, redshirt junior

4. Peyton Falzone, freshman

5. Kase Evans, freshman

The starting quarterback is an obvious one, as Rocco Becht transfers to Penn State after three years leading the offense at Iowa State. There’s a natural fit for him in State College, following Matt Campbell, offensive coordinator Taylor Mouser and quarterbacks coach Jake Waters.

Behind Becht, there will be a competition for the backup spot between Alex Manske and Connor Barry. Manske also joins the Nittany Lions following a freshman year with the Cyclones while Barry heads to Happy Valley with one year of eligibility left after playing for Division III Christopher Newport in Virginia with a brief stint at Appalachian State beforehand.

Despite only playing in three games with limited numbers in 2025, Manske should have the edge in this battle as a former four-star recruit, who Iowa State believed was the quarterback of the future behind Becht. Barry should provide a veteran presence in the No. 3 role, coming off of a career at Christopher Newport where he’s thrown for 5,561 passing yards and 55 touchdowns and most recently winning his conference’s Offensive Player of the Year.

Rounding out the room are a pair of freshmen in four-star Peyton Falzone and three-star Kase Evans. Walk-on Jack Lambert is the only quarterback on roster who returns from a season ago.

Running back

1. Carson Hansen, senior

2. James Peoples, junior

3. Quinton Martin Jr., redshirt sophomore

4. Cam Wallace, redshirt sophomore

Iowa State transfer tailback Carson Hansen should be the starter come the season-opener against Marshall. He’s coming off of a 2025 campaign where he was a second-team All-Big 12 selection, rushing for 952 yards and six touchdowns.

With that being said, this job won’t be handed to Hansen, as Quinton Martin Jr. and Ohio State transfer James Peoples will more than likely be in the mix.

Last year, Peoples totaled 344 rushing yards and three touchdowns as the third Buckeyes’ tailback on the depth chart behind Bo Jackson and CJ Donaldson. Martin didn’t touch the ball during the regular season for Penn State, but exploded in the Pinstripe Bowl, recording 20 carries for 101 yards.

There should be a healthy dosage of all three running backs to start the year, but any of them can emerge as the lead back. However, there’s a good chance that this is a running back by committee approach, with the trio all seeing some form of a role.

Cam Wallace, who has shown flashes and opted to return for 2026 despite initially entering the transfer portal, will be a key depth piece.

Wide receiver

X-receiver:

1. Chase Sowell, redshirt senior

2. Peter Gonzalez, redshirt sophomore

Y-receiver:

1. Koby Howard, sophomore

2. Keith Jones Jr., redshirt sophomore

Z-receiver:

1. Brett Eskildsen, junior

2. Lyrick Samuel, redshirt freshman

The starting three wideouts on-paper seem to be clear with a pair of Iowa State transfers in Chase Sowell and Brett Eskildsen as well as Koby Howard returning to Penn State for his sophomore year.

As far as where they line up on the field, that’ll be up in the air. Sowell will likely be on the outside, while Eskildsen or Howard can either play on the outside or in the slot.

A season ago, Sowell totaled 32 receptions for 500 yards and two touchdowns while Eskildsen notched 30 catches for 526 yards and five touchdowns. Howard garnered seven receptions for 133 yards in Year 1 as a Nittany Lion, but received rave reviews throughout the course of the campaign.

Peter Gonzalez, Lyrick Samuel and Grambling State transfer Keith Jones Jr. should be the next group up.

Tight end

1. Andrew Rappleyea, redshirt junior

2. Benjamin Brahmer, senior

3. Gabe Burkle, redshirt senior

4. Finn Furmanek, redshirt junior

Andrew Rappleyea and Iowa State transfer Benjamin Brahmer will be the surefire starting tight ends, making them a way-too-early contender for best tandem at the position in the Big Ten.

Rappleyea took over as the top Penn State tight end by the end of the 2025, recording 20 catches for 180 yards and three touchdowns in the final three games of the year. Brahmer, a 2025 second-team All-Big 12 selection, has 977 receiving yards and nine touchdowns through three seasons with the Cyclones.

Gabe Burkle, another ex-Iowa State tight end, should round out the crew of top players at the position. He accumulated 54 receptions for 607 yards and two scores in four years with the Cyclones.

Finn Furmanek will be a key depth piece, as the State College native saw a key role on special teams as well a year ago. Per Sean Fitz of On3, he was put on scholarship.

Offensive line

Left tackle:

Anthony Donkoh, redshirt junior

Owen Aliciene, redshirt freshman

Left guard:

Trevor Buhr, redshirt junior

Malachi Goodman, redshirt freshman

Center:

Brock Riker, redshirt sophomore

Dom Rulli, redshirt senior

Right guard:

Cooper Cousins, junior

Goodman

Right tackle:

Garrett Sexton, redshirt sophomore

Aliciene

Anthony Donkoh is the lone starter to return from 2025, as the rest of the crew is off to the NFL draft. He started at right guard, but with him being the best player, and experience as the starter at right tackle, he could shift over to left tackle to protect Becht’s blindside.

At the other tackle spot, it’ll be a battle between Garrett Sexton and Owen Aliciene. Sexton was the backup right tackle to Nolan Rucci last year, while Aliciene was the third-string left tackle behind Drew Shelton and now-Florida transfer Eagan Boyer. With Sexton having one more year under his belt, he should have the upper hand in this position battle.

For guards, Cooper Cousins and Trevor Buhr should lock down the starting spots. Cousins has been a rotational piece the past two seasons, burning his redshirt in 2024 as a freshman, and starting in the Pinstripe Bowl. Buhr appeared in eight games for Iowa State last year, starting in six of them.

At center, it’ll be a battle between Texas State transfer Brock Riker and walk-on-turned scholarship player Dom Rulli, who started in the Pinstripe Bowl.

Rulli has done some good things for Penn State, notably on special teams as the punt protector, but Riker started in all 12 games in 2025 and was a highly sought after player in the portal by Power Four programs. He also was also a second-team freshman All-American via The Athletic.

Malachi Goodman is a versatile piece off of the bench, who can play either guard or tackle. He came to Penn State as a tackle but practiced at guard under former position coach Phil Trautwein.

The 6-foot-6, 315-pound redshirt freshman was a highly touted recruit, ranking as a high four-star, but didn’t see the field his freshman year.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Practice observations | Penn State women’s lacrosse scrimmages ahead of season-opener
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is just over a week from one of its most anticipated seasons in several years under coach Kayla Treanor’s first year.

The Nittany Lions held an open viewing session for media and fans, featuring two quarters of scrimmage and one quarter of situational work.

After 45 minutes of action, here’s what to expect from this year’s Penn State team.

Strong attack

The White team wasted no time getting down the field after winning the opening faceoff, led by sophomore Allie Meyer. A little over one minute into the game, Meyer scored the scrimmage’s first goal against starting goalie Sydney Manning.

The White team’s success continued midway through the first period as fellow sophomore Ellie Wisch put her team up 2-0.

Friday’s scrimmage was a high-scoring affair through 15 minutes, with goals by Emma Kelly, Delaney Radin and Rocquette Allen.

The second period was slightly slower after four minutes, with neither side able to score. However, things got going after Allen secured her second goal of the day.

The Blue team ultimately took a commanding lead to win the scrimmage with another goal from Wisch and the first goals of the game by Maddie Greco, Erika Ho and Payton Wainman.

Clean play

It was nearly five minutes of play without any turnovers for either team. Treanor’s offense was playing crisp, clean lacrosse.

While multiple passes went astray by the end of the game, the two sides combined for only a few turnovers from pressure and carelessness.

The scrimmage featured several fouls from both teams, with many players being shown the green card and taken off the field for the minute-long violation.

Team depth

Nearly every player saw the field in Friday’s scrimmage, showcasing the depth of Treanor’s squad this year.

That strength was on display through the opening period with the White team — played by a majority of underclassmen — leading the charge.

Two sophomores scored the opening two goals, and freshman Allen scored two of her own.

Goalkeeper questions

While Sydney Manning has been Penn State’s premier goalkeeper throughout her first two seasons, starting in 26 out of 32 games, she wasn’t the star on Friday.

Senior Emily Bette was the goalkeeper to watch in the team’s scrimmage, recording two saves against two goals in the first quarter.

The Albany, New York, native had a hard task while defending the net against Penn State’s starters. However, her second save came against Ho, the Nittany Lions’ leading scorer last season.

MORE LACROSSE CONTENT

title: Penn State wrestling’s PJ Duke loses first match under Nebraska’s slow-paced style
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Nebraska wrestled a visually frustrating style against the Nittany Lions. A majority of matches saw the Cornhuskers keeping their knees to the ground and backing off engagement, looking to pick a spot to potentially take down the high-powered Penn State.

The reaction from the Nittany Lions was a show of apparent frustration across multiple matches, including Mitchell Mesenbrink urging LJ Araujo to take action in his match and Levi Haines nearly shoving Christopher Minto off of the stage.

“You’re not always going to have your best night, and as a team, maybe we were a little flat,” Cael Sanderson said. “I think the guys had to get tough to battle some really good wrestlers.”

While the upper classmen let their emotions fly, one freshman kept his composure in a low-scoring match, despite suffering the first loss of his collegiate career in controversial fashion.

PJ Duke surged up to the top three of the 157 pound weight class throughout the first part of his first season, entering his match at the Bryce Jordan Center undefeated. In his way was the defending national champion at his weight, No. 5 Antrell Taylor.

From the outset of the match, Taylor stayed low, not allowing Duke any leverage to get to his legs. Despite multiple attempts from the former U20 World Champion, Taylor was rarely in real danger due to his ability to back away from his opponent.

“We see it every week, it’s nothing new, but it’s hard to wrestle,”Sanderson said. “Refs don’t really call stalling traditionally anymore.”

The only form of engagement offered by Taylor to avoid the stall calls was rough hand fighting that was the signature of Nebraska’s dual strategy. Taylor kept his hands in the face of Duke when they weren’t being used to push him backwards or maintaining distance wrist control.

“They’re just jabbing us in the face and backing up, right?” Sanderson said. “We have to be able to close the gap and do our thing.”

Duke did have a takedown opportunity in the first period, getting his arms around Taylor on the edge of the mat and getting off his feet momentarily, but the ruling by the referees was to not award a takedown in the moment.

Assistant coach Nick Lee threw the challenge brick on the mat, leading to a moment of confusion as the refs didn’t begin the challenge until after lengthy conversations with both coaching staffs.

“That was my call to throw the brick and we probably shouldn’t have,” Sanderson said. “It was close enough that we threw, and we obviously wish we had it later on.”

After multiple minutes looking at the tape, the call of no takedown stood, citing reaction time.

The NCAA rulebook in 2025-26 allows for wrestlers to have their hands or knees on the mat for a “split-second” without being ruled a takedown as reaction time. However, the explicit time isn’t known and has been viewed as a judgement call to the referees. Sanderson didn’t take the judgement into effect before he threw the brick.

As the bout continued, Taylor stalled the rest of the way through the bout, including sudden victory. The pair went to a tiebreaker in which Taylor successfully rode Duke out for 30 seconds, awarding him the deciding second point.

Despite the Nittany Lions 26-12 victory, Nebraska’s strategy in this Bryce Jordan Center dual was to slow Penn State’s rampant offensive pace using stall techniques and hand fighting. Duke fell victim to the trap, taking his first collegiate loss to Taylor.

“(Duke) will be fine,” Sanderson said. “He’ll learn from it, keep getting better and that’s the name of the game.”

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling’s Luke Lilledahl continues to provide consistency at 125 pounds
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
Despite all the success Cael Sanderson has had at Penn State, one thing that recently has been a struggle to find is a consistent 125-pound wrestler.

That all changed when Sanderson secured Wyoming Seminary product, Luke Lilledahl, to provide comfortability in the weight class.

“Just starting off a dual with some high-scoring matches, and scoring (as) many team points as I can is really fun,” Lilledahl said.

In the 2020-21 season, Penn State had Robert Howard wrestle, but he lost early in the NCAA Tournament. The following year Drew Hildebrandt seemed to be the guy to break the trend, but after earning the No. 2 seed in the Big Ten Tournament, he fell early in the NCAA’s, as well. Gary Steen missed the NCAA Tournament in 2023, before Braeden Davis took the spot in his true freshman season.

Davis won the Big Ten title his freshman year, but was quickly ousted at the NCAA Tournament, going 2-2 and falling out of an All-American spot.

Insert Lilledahl, who’s taken the 125-pound weight class by storm. He was the top-ranked wrestler in the 2024 recruiting class, and has lived up to those expectations. In his true freshman season, he garnered a 25-3 overall record and held the No. 1 ranking at one point in the season.

He went 4-0 in Evanston, Illinois, en route to a Big Ten title, before going 6-1, ending with a pinfall victory over the previously top seed, Matt Ramos of Purdue, to earn third place in 2025.

Lilledahl is now the No. 1 wrestler at the weight class in his second year, and has provided that consistency at the lightest weight, and the typical leadoff wrestler for the lineup.

He faced the easiest competitor of the entire dual on paper, taking on unranked Alan Koehler to open the Bryce Jordan Center on Friday against Nebraska.

Lilledahl lived up to his “lightning Luke” nickname, defeating Koehler by tech fall after a quick takedown to start the dual off.

He was the catalyst to a quick, and hot start for the Nittany Lions. His follow up, Marcus Blaze, came out on top in a top-10 matchup and Braeden Davis came out the gates flying to begin his match.

“It’s not a one-two punch, it’s pretty much like a 10-punch knockout,” Lilledhal said.

He lets his fellow No. 1-ranked wrestlers finish the job, with top-ranked Rocco Welsh sealing the deal against Nebraska. Welsh is joined by Shayne Van Ness, Mitchell Mesenbrink, Levi Haines and Josh Barr as No. 1 wrestlers in addition to Lilledahl.

“That sounds pretty good,” Sanderson said of his six No. 1 wrestlers. “I never really thought about that. We love our lineup, we love our guys, we’re just gonna keep getting better every match and be at our best.”

Despite the four straight top-ranked wrestlers from 165 pounds to 197 pounds, it’s the “lightning” wrestler that kicks things off to really get things going.

Lilledahl has started off every dual with a victory, advancing to 14-0 on the season after his victory, and holds a 67% bonus rate, often getting Penn State started with a four or more point lead.

“I feel like a lot of times, duals may start off slow, and then they can pick up the pace, but I feel like a lot of our duals, if you’re not here early, then you’re gonna miss something, and I think that’s pretty cool,” Lilledahl said.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Penalties, physicality prevail in No. 5 Penn State’s loss to No. 2 Michigan State
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Two months ago, Penn State walked out of East Lansing, Michigan, with a 5-0 loss and almost half a game in penalty minutes. The Nittany Lions were swept by Michigan State in a series that saw over 25 total penalties and four misconducts.

The dislike between the two Big Ten foes is unmistakable, and that was no different when the No. 5 blue and white welcomed the No. 2 Spartans to Pegula Ice Arena for a rematch Friday night.

“No matter how you put it, it’s two top-five teams playing each other, so it’s going to be physical,” forward Reese Laubach said. “It’s going to be two teams that want to kill the other one.”

A night filled with physicality ended in Michigan State’s favor, besting the Nittany Lions 6-3.

The animosity picked up right where it left off, as the Spartans laid some heavy hits from the first whistle.

The first penalty happened shortly after Michigan State’s first goal, when star defenseman Jackson Smith was called for interference.

The blue and whites’ 4th-ranked penalty kill held on, however, highlighted by Fleming’s solid performance in net.

The first time tensions boiled over came with about six minutes left in the first period, after Penn State’s Nic Chin-DeGraves and Michigan State’s Shane Vansaghi got into it in front of Fleming’s net.

A line brawl followed, and it took the refs several minutes to drag Chin-DeGraves away from the action and into the penalty box.

Chin-DeGraves was awarded two minor penalties for cross checking and unsportsmanlike conduct on top of a 10 minute misconduct, while Vansaghi was awarded a minor penalty for roughing.

The Spartans got another shot at the powerplay, with Chin-DeGraves animatedly yelling at Vansaghi across the box for the next several minutes.

“Emotions get high and emotions get low, and you got to find that even keel,” defenseman Jarod Crespo said. “But that kid really wanted to win, and he came back and played a great game.”

This time, Michigan State got one on the man-advantage after sophomore Owen West’s shot from the point made it through traffic.

The blue and white got its first chance on the power play thanks to senior Daniel Russel, but the penalty was negated less than 30 seconds later, when Smith was called for his second interference of the night.

4-on-4 hockey provided no goals, but Michigan State capitalized on its short man-advantage when Cayden Lindstrom found Romani in the slot for his second score of the night.

To a resounding chorus of boo’s for the officials, Penn State headed into the locker room chasing three goals after the first 20 minutes.

After Aiden Fink was caught up high and laid out at center ice by Lindstrom, freshman phenom Gavin McKenna came to the forward’s defense, and both sides started trading punches.

Both McKenna and Lindstrom were given 5-minute majors and game misconducts, ending their nights, while the Spartans’ Colin Ralph was given an additional 5-minute major for face masking.

“You’re returning two-time MVP gets popped right in the head, no, I don’t mind the response at all,” Coach Gadowsky said. “It’s hard to see that happen to your teammate, and you just respond, and (McKenna) just responded.”

Despite several high danger chances, the blue and white couldn’t figure out how to get past first-team All-American netminder Trey Augustine on the extended power play.

The blue and white had a new life after Laubach’s goal, and after successfully killing off a 5-on-3 opportunity from the Spartans, Hockey Valley could feel the energy shift.

Another Michigan State penalty gave the Nittany Lions a golden opportunity with the momentum on their side, and as time expired on the power play, Matt DiMarsico tipped in a shot from JJ Wiebusch, bringing it within one goal of a comeback.

That goal never came, however, and despite a strong final frame, two empty net goals for the Spartans sealed the Nittany Lions’ 6-3 loss.

MORE WINTER SPORTS WEEKEND COVERAGE

title: Guy Gadowsky praises Gavin McKenna’s response to Aiden Fink taking big hit
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Big Ten hockey thrives on physicality. It’s why Penn State coach Guy Gadowsky preaches a grit-and-grind mentality — one that ranks giving maximum effort above anything else.

Another pillar of Gadowsky’s culture: Stand up for your teammates when you think it’s necessary, no matter the ensuing costs.

That philosophy was tested early in the second period when Aiden Fink took a bruising hit as he exited Penn State’s defensive zone. Fink skated with his head down as he eyed a loose puck before Michigan State’s Cayden Lindstrom dug his shoulder into Fink’s head, causing the junior forward to torpedo into the ice, where he’d lie for an additional minute.

As the Pegula Ice Arena crowd roared in disgust, Fink’s teammates — Gavin McKenna, Dane Dowiak and Nolan Collins — beelined toward Lindstrom. There was zero hesitation in their decision, one fully backed by their head coach.

“When your returning MVP (Fink) is popped right in the head, I don't mind the response at all,” Gadowsky said. “You see that happen to your teammate, you just respond. Gavin just responded.”

Collins knocked Lindstrom to the ground. Colin Ralph and Dowiak exchanged blows along the boards. McKenna threw several jabs at a Spartan skater as a mob formed alongside Penn State’s bench.

After a lengthy review, Lindstrom and Ralph received five-minute major penalties and game misconducts for their involvement. Trailing 3-0, Penn State had earned a much-needed five-minute power play.

The downside: McKenna was booked for facemasking, which resulted in a five-minute major and a game misconduct. The Nittany Lions, who already faced a three-goal deficit, were now without one of their top offensive creators.

But the team didn’t care. Their star player didn’t hesitate to defend his teammate after a blindside hit. And for that, McKenna’s teammates expressed great respect.

“Whoever gets hit, we're gonna stand up for him,” Reese Laubach said. “Doesn't matter if it’s (Fink) — it could be anyone. Obviously, taking a penalty and losing Gavin sucks, but he was standing up for (his) teammate.”

The Nittany Lions went scoreless on their five-minute power play. But it awoke something in them — a renewed energy following Lindstrom’s hit that sparked a spirited comeback.

First, Jackson Smith wristed one off the far post and in to make it a 3-1 game. And despite Porter Martone’s tally near the end of the second period, Penn State felt it was right there.

Laubach answered Mortone’s tally with a tap-in goal off a cross-ice feed from Carter Schade to make it 4-2. Minutes later, JJ Wiebusch backhanded a pass to Matt DiMarsico, who tapped in his 15th goal of the season to make it a one-score game.

The Spartans later added two empty-net goals to halt Penn State’s comeback. But the Nittany Lions never quit — a perseverance that drew Gadowsky’s praise.

“We had a lot of chances, we didn't solve them until late, (we) hit a few posts, but I love how we came back,” Gadowsky said. “I think we played a more consistent game, territorially, than the scoring would indicate … I don't think we played much differently, except the punks went in.”

MORE WINTER SPORTS WEEKEND COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling defeats Nebraska in ranked matchup at the Bryce Jordan Center
author: AJ Piazza | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 1 Penn State entered the Bryce Jordan Center for its second time this season, but for its first official BJC dual of the calendar year.

The match contained a lot of confusion, but the result was in Penn State’s favor, as the Nittany Lions got the 26-12 victory over No. 6 Nebraska.

125 Pounds: No. 1 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs Alan Koehler (NEB)

Luke Lilledahl was aggressive off the jump, getting the early takedown in the opening 30 seconds. After an early escape and an attempt to gain higher position, Alan Koehler couldn’t stay off the ground as Lilledahl got another takedown. Lilledahl led 9-2 going into the second period.

Koehler with the early escape, Lilledahl with another slam to the mat. Lilledahl continued to go at Koehler’s leg and tallied four-near fall points. The sophomore held a 14-3 lead going into the third period. Lilledahl got the tech fall 20-4.

Penn State led 5-0.

133 Pounds: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs No. 10 Jacob Van Dee (NEB)

Marcus Blaze and Jacob Van Dee were even early in the match. Van Dee didn’t give Blaze any space, but didn’t do any attacking. Blaze got a hold of Van Dee and got the only takedown of the period.

There wasn’t much action in the middle period, which continued into the final frame. Blaze got the victory, 5-1.

Penn State led 8-0.

141 Pounds: No. 12 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs No. 4 Brock Hardy (NEB)

Braeden Davis didn’t waste any time, as he took Brock Hardy down immediately. Davis got another takedown right after Hardy got up, controlling the first period with a 6-2 advantage.

Davis got the escape, not allowing Hardy to attack, allowing his defense to protect himself. Hardy then got his first takedown of the match, leading Davis 7-5.

Hardy escaped early in the third, cutting the deficit to one. At the end of the match, Hardy tapped Davis’s chest, where Davis then tried to trip him.

The two had some words after the match, resulting in a penalty point deducted from Penn State.

Penn State led 7-6.

149 Pounds: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs No. 18 Chance Lamer (NEB)

Chance Lamer got the first takedown of the match. Van Ness did escape, but Lamer seemed to be the quicker wrestler. Lamer led 3-1.

After a quick escape in the second period by Lamer, Van Ness tied the match with a takedown.

Van Ness escaped and got another takedown to take the 8-4 lead. Once Lamer was down, it took him a while to get back up. Van Ness recorded another takedown and then a 12-5 victory.

Penn State led 10-6.

157 Pounds: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs No. 5 Antrell Taylor (NEB)

PJ Duke and Antrell Taylor was a stalemate to start. Taylor continued to drop to a knee, which prevented Duke from doing anything. Duke tried to attack, but couldn’t get anything going.

Duke got what looked to be a takedown that wasn’t awarded a takedown. Penn State challenged and it was confirmed to be no takedown, resulting in no score after the first.

Taylor escaped quickly taking an early lead. Taylor continued to be on both knees for most of the period. Duke escaped in the third to tie the match, as Taylor continued to avoid Duke and not engage in any offense.

Sudden victory was the same as the first three periods. Time was ticking and Duke was getting frustrated. Taylor escaped by what the Penn State fans thought was a controversial call by the refs. Duke couldn’t escape and Taylor got the victory despite appearing to be stalling throughout the match.

Penn State led 10-9.

165 Pounds: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs No. 7 LJ Araujo (NEB)

Mitchell Mesenbrink opened the match with a takedown. That trend continued two more times as Mesenbrink got a pair of takedowns and took a 9-3 lead.

Mesenbrink delivered another takedown and controlled LJ Araujo the entire match, and was awarded two-stalling points, extending his lead to 14-4. Mesenbrink flattened Araujo, got the reversal and another takedown to get a 19-5 lead.

Mesenbrink got the tech fall with the riding time.

Penn State led 15-9.

174 Pounds: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs No. 4 Christopher Minto (NEB)

Levi Haines shoved Christopher Minto off the mat and over the barricade, awarding a point to Minto. Haines escaped at the beginning of the second period, which was followed by a Minto takedown. Haines trailed 4-2.

Haines got a takedown to gain a 5-4 lead. Haines got another takedown and garnered the victory 8-6.

Penn State led 18-9

184 Pounds: No. 1 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs No. 7 Silas Allred (NEB)

Rocco Welsh got the early takedown and controlled the early part of the match. Welsh garnered another takedown to lead, 6-2, going into the second period.

Welsh kicked Silas Allred’s left leg to get his third takedown of the match, taking a 9-4 lead going into the third period.

Welsh continued his dominance and got the 15-5, major-decision victory.

Penn State led 21-9.

197 Pounds: No. Josh Barr (PSU) vs No 9 Camden McDaniel (NEB)

Josh Barr got the takedown early as he continued the trend of most of the Penn State matches. Barr made it difficult for Camden McDaniel to get up, and when he did, Barr would slam him back down onto the mat. Barr led 12-3 after the first period featuring four takedowns.

Barr added multiple takedowns including yanking McDaniel back into the center of the mat to get a 19-6 lead. McDaniel got his first takedown of the match to make it 19-9.

Bar got the victory by major decision 21-9.

Penn State led 26-9.

Heavyweight: No. 12 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs No. 4 AJ Ferrari (NEB)

AJ Ferrari tried to get a takedown to start, but couldn’t get complete control of Cole Mirasola. Mirasola avoided a few takedowns by spinning out of them. Ferrari escaped early to gain a 1-0 lead.

Mirasola almost got the first takedown of the match, but Ferrari never allowed him to get full control.

Ferrari rode Mirasola for most of the third period. Ferrari kept looking for blood, but the ref didn’t oblige. Ferrari got the riding-time point and got the victory 2-1.

Penn State got the victory 26-12.

title: Penn State men’s hockey reporters take over ahead of Winter Sports Weekend | The 1-0 Podcast
author: The Daily Collegian Football Staff
description:
On a special edition of “The 1-0 Podcast,” co-hosts Lyle Alenstein, Evan Smith and Andrew Mercer came together ahead of a massive weekend for Penn State athletics.

How will Penn State men’s and women’s hockey perform at Beaver Stadium? What will the environment be like? Will this be the biggest weekend for both hockey programs?

Following that, the group dove into the rest of the sports that will be in action this weekend such as football, wrestling and men’s lacrosse.

MORE COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field shatters school records at Penn State National Open
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is in the midst of a historic season, and that success continued this weekend.

The Nittany Lions hosted the Penn State National Open on Friday and Saturday, hosting dozens of teams at the Horace Ashenfelter III Indoor Track.

Friday

Senior Maddie Pitts kicked off the action in the pentathlon as she furthered her previous No. 3 time in school history with a score of 4,239 points.

In addition to her overall score, Pitts recorded personal bests in the 60-meter hurdles and shot put, winning the two alongside the 800-meter.

The women’s mile continued a long streak of personal-bests for the Nittany Lions as Lea Hatchering, Sarah Pickering and Ada Rand all improved their times, finishing third, sixth and seventh in the race.

In the men’s mile, junior Nick Sloff broke his second school record in as many weeks, running 3:54.90 for the win.

Ryan Watson, Brian DiCola, Justin Healey and Logan Strawser all finished in the top-10 with personal-bests of their own.

The school record streak continued in the women’s 800m as senior Hayley Kitching extended her all-time performance. Kitching broke her own school record, running 2:00.1. Freshman Boh Ritchie finished just behind Kitching with a 2:01.60 for the No. 2 time in Penn State history — her second No. 2 mark this season.

Senior Handal Roban earned the blue and white’s third school record of the day in the men’s 800m, as he ran a 1:44.91 to win the race.

Graduate students Allon Clay and Yukichi Ishii finished in third and fourth in the race with times of 1:45.17 and 1:46.37 to set the No. 2 and No. 5 marks in school history.

The blue and white earned more podium performances in the women’s weight throw as senior Alex Pancoast led the way with a second-place throw of 19.49 meters. Sophomore Gabby Cope earned a second-place finish with a throw of 19.23 meters.

Senior jumper Tristan McGarrah earned Penn State’s fourth win of the day in the men’s pole vault, jumping 5.10 meters for a season best.

Continuing the success of the Nittany Lions’ jumpers was Joe White, who finished second in the men’s long jump with a jump of 6.92 meters.

The men’s weight throw saw graduate student Collin Burkhart improve his previous No. 5 time in school history, throwing 21.22 meters for first place. Senior Sam Engebretson also earned a personal best, finishing fourth with 19.77 meters.

The Nittany Lions earned another victory in the women’s 400m as sophomore Alexandria North finished with a personal-best 54.04.

Sophomore Jake Palermo finished the day with Penn State’s last victory, running a meet record 45.98, coming back in the final lap.

Saturday

The Nittany Lions opened Day 2 of the Penn State National Open in the men's 600 meters, where senior Austin Gallant ran a personal-best 1:17.02 to win the race.

Sophomore Jackson Smith finished just behind Gallant in 1:19.90, finishing in third place.

The women's 500-meter saw another pair of personal bests for Penn State, as freshman Macey Shriner finished second with a 1:14.08, followed by Abasiono Akpan in third with 1:15.62.

Junior Kaleb Nastari led the way in the men's 1000-meter, finishing third in a stacked race with a three-second PR of 2:20.84.

After a standout cross country season, senior Charlotte Costich earned a nearly 40-second personal best in the women's 3000-meter, running 9:07.10 for second place — the fourth-best time in school history.

Lea Hatcher and Claire Daniels also finished in the top five, earning personal bests of 9:09.35 and 9:15.35.

Senior Brendan Flynn earned a big personal-best in the men's 3000m, running 8:11.61 for fourth place.

The women's 4x400m ran a season-best 3:42.52 to conclude the women's track events, finishing fourth overall. The men's cut four seconds off their season-best to finish second in 3:11.01.

The Nittany Lions had success in the field events on Saturday, kicking off with Robert Allen’s winning high jump with 2.06 meters.

In the women's high jump, senior Gwen Cudmore jumped a season-best 1.73m to finish third.

After throwing the No. 4 time in school history earlier this season, Ryan Henry came back to improve his distance with a throw of 19.81m in the men's shot put to win. Dylan Lambrecht finished second with a throw of 18.33m.

Lizzie Schreiber continued Penn State’s field success with a win in the women's triple jump, jumping 12.70m.

The Nittany Lions wrapped up the Penn State National Open with even more personal best as Skye Petrie-Cameron and Sasha Garnett finished first and second with personal bests of 16.20m and 16.12m.

Up next

The Nittany Lions will host the Sykes & Sabock Challenge on Feb. 7.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: No. 5 Penn State comes out flat on Friday, loses to No. 2 Michigan State despite comeback bid
author: Chase Fisher | The Daily Collegian
description:
A filled-in crowd at Pegula Ice Arena unleashed two of its loudest reactions of the night during pregame introductions. One was for the booing of Michigan State goaltender Trey Augustine. The other was the deafening cheers for Penn State netminder Josh Fleming.

While the introductions for both goaltenders were vastly different, the reactions were as loud as they were for the same reason: both Augustine and Fleming are key to each program’s top-five ranking in the country.

However, neither one got its footing on Friday in a relatively high-scoring affair. In the end, it was No. 5 Penn State on the losing end, dropping Game 1 to No. 2 Michigan State, 6-3, and ending its seven-game winning streak.

First period

Friday’s first period started as advertised, as both teams played physically behind a raucous Pegula Ice Arena crowd. While vicious hits were exchanged on both sides, Michigan State was the one to take advantage of them early.

Just four minutes into the contest, defenseman Maxim Strbak retrieved a puck and fed an outlet pass to right wing Anthony Romani shortly after right wing Aiden Fink was knocked down onto the ice.

That feed led Romani into a breakaway with defenseman Jarod Crespo on the backcheck, but the Spartans’ third liner was able to beat Fleming on his forehand, giving Michigan State a 1-0 lead.

The Spartans piled on in a chaotic final five minutes of the first frame, beginning with defenseman Owen West flicking a wrist shot from the point on the power play past Fleming’s left blocker to extend Michigan State’s lead to 2-0.

Then, Romani tallied his second score of the night on the man-advantage, one-timing a shot off a backhand feed from center Cayden Lindstrom to make it 3-0 Spartans.

Second period

Similarly to the first period, the action began four minutes into the second frame. However, it wasn’t scoring that sparked the deafening crowd pops — it was several massive hits and scrums.

Lindstrom started the party, delivering a crushing hit on Fink near the blue line. Left wing Gavin McKenna retaliated, leveling his former teammate on the Medicine Hat Tigers seconds later.

Both Lindstrom and McKenna, as well as defenseman Colin Ralph, were sentenced to five-minute majors. However, despite earning a five-minute man-advantage, Penn State couldn’t score or generate dangerous chances.

Those values held true on the Nittany Lions’ second power play of the period, until defenseman Jackson Smith gloved down a wobbling puck and fired a wrist shot past Augustine and into the back of the net, cutting Penn State’s deficit to 3-1 with a hair under nine minutes remaining in the period.

But that momentum didn’t last long, as left wing Lev Katzin conceded a costly turnover behind the goal, which led to right wing Porter Martone jamming home a goal through Fleming’s five hole and extending Michigan State’s lead to 4-1.

Third period

For the third consecutive period, the action started four minutes into the frame. But for the first time, it was via a Penn State goal, cutting its deficit to 4-2.

The Nittany Lions’ tally came from center Reese Laubach, who tapped in a shot on the backdoor of Augustine, which came from a pass from the point by defenseman Carter Schade.

Penn State continued its comeback on the power play in the midst of an exchange of penalties. Near the midway point of the period, right wing JJ Wiebusch took a rebound off the boards and fed left wing Matt DiMarsico at the goalmouth, where the junior hammered the puck past Augustine on one knee, cutting the Nittany Lions’ deficit to 4-3.

However, that’s all Penn State could muster up in its comeback bid, as Romani iced the game to finish off his hat trick and left wing Daniel Russell hit an empty-net goal with 22 seconds remaining to lead Michigan State to a 6-3 win.

Injury Report

Defenseman Casey Aman, who was listed as day-to-day according to coach Guy Gadowsky on Tuesday, was inactive on Friday.

Up Next

Penn State and Michigan State will duel in the first-ever outdoor game at Beaver Stadium at 1 p.m. Saturday.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s volleyball swept by No. 3 Hawai'i in series opener
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
To kick off another weekend series, Penn State returned to Rec Hall after getting swept by McKendree to host No. 3 Hawai'i in its White Out game.

The Rainbow Warriors weren’t affected by the snowstorm in State College, though, traveling just under 5000 miles to take down the Nittany Lions and pick up a 3-0 sweep in the first game of the series.

No. 3 Hawai'i got on the board first and got hot off the rip, quickly jumping up to a 4-1 lead in the early running.

A lot of points in the early stages usually come from service errors, but it was just kill after kill for both sides, with Kainoa Wade kicking it off.

Penn State found itself down 7-3 after a Sean Harvey service error, and things were looking bleak, but the Nittany Lions were stepping on the heels of the Rainbow Warriors despite falling in a hole early on.

Harvey, far and away leading the blue and white in kills, currently with 71, notched another in an effort to cut his squad’s deficit to just one point.

The Nittany Lions took their first lead thanks to a Matthew Luoma ace put them up 15-14 in a tightly contested first frame.

Just when it looked like Penn State was going to pull ahead, Hawai'i went on a 4-0 scoring run on its way to capturing the first set 25-22.

Back-to-back Adrien Roure kills kicked off another Rainbow Warrior scoring run as they quickly got out to a 7-3 lead in the second set with Luomo giving Penn State its only point not from errors.

Really turning it up, Hawaii went on a suffocating 5-0 scoring run, backed by kills from Roure and Wade, which were followed by back-to-back service aces out of Tread Rosenthal.

The Rainbow Warriors were laying the hurt on the blue and white as they sailed to an 18-9 lead thanks to that scoring run.

Penn State was failing to chip away at the lead and was stuck watching the second set slip away.

Yet another Harvey kill kept the Nittany Lions alive, though many of their points were coming off Hawai'i errors.

Just as it looked like the Rainbow Warriors were going to pull away, Penn State went on a 6-0 scoring run backed with a service ace from Owen Rose to tie it at 22-22. Rattled, Charlie Wade and Hawai'i used a timeout.

Though the Nittany Lions kept it interesting down the stretch, it wasn’t enough to shake the Rainbow Warriors, who won the second set 25-23.

Another Harvey kill just couldn’t match back-to-back scores from Justin Todd, which gave him five kills on the night and moved Hawai'i just one set away from a first-game sweep.

With 10 kills on the night, it felt like Harvey was doing everything by himself on the floor. Ryan Merk, who just earned EIVA defensive player of the week honors, was quiet all night, not able to lend much help.

Just like it had the rest of the night, Hawai'i immediately went on a 4-0 scoring run in the third set, with Rosenthal picking up an ace along the way.

The Nittany Lions closed the gap, though, with Gabriel Gaige garnering an ace of his own to cut the Rainbow Warriors’ lead to 6-4.

Hawai'i extended its lead to four points after a Harvey attack error, but Penn State was closing in prior to that misstep, picking up back-to-back kills.

Mark Pavlik was forced into a timeout after Hawai'i moved just nine points away from the sweep after a Finn Kearney service ace pushed his squad out to a 16-10 lead.

Penn State was dead in the water after falling behind 20-13, unable to stop Hawaii from piecing together consistent scoring drives.

In full control in the third frame, the Rainbow Warriors moved even closer with a Louis Sakanoko kill, but yet another Harvey kill kept Penn State in it for now.

Ultimately, though, the Nittany Lions just couldn’t climb out of the hole as Hawai'i won the third set 25-15 to pick up the sweep.

Up Next

Penn State is back in action tomorrow for game two of its early-season series against Hawai'i.

Saturday’s match is set for 5 p.m.

MORE VOLLEYBALL CONTENT

title: Hayley Kitching, Handal Roban break Penn State 800m records
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Hayley Kitching and Handal Roban keep getting better.

The duo broke the school records in their respective races, improving on their previous times at the Penn State National Open

Kitching previously held the school record, but took nearly two seconds off her time to set the new mark of 2:00.1.

On the other hand, Roban previously held the No. 5 time in school history, but took over two seconds off with a time of 1:44.91 to break Isaiah Harris' previous record.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: Record-breaking attendance fuels No. 4 Penn State women's hockey to a win at Beaver Stadium
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
Snow-filled bleachers, paired with freezing weather, did not deter rowdy Penn State fans from supporting No. 4 Penn State at Beaver Stadium.

A record-setting 1,838 fans, dressed head to toe in winter gear, witnessed not only the first-ever Penn State hockey game outdoors, but a 3-0 Nittany Lions win over Robert Morris.

It wasn’t until the clock struck 15 minutes left in the game that the public address announcer informed the stadium about the historic milestone. The immediate roar from the crowd lifted the Nittany Lions throughout the final minutes of the game.

“I was excited to hear the attendance record, the bench was fired up,” McKenna Walsh said. “It was cold and it’s a 1 p.m. game, so it’s tough to get people to come out. The fact that we set the (attendance) record at this game is pretty special.”

Walsh had the honor of scoring the first-ever goal in Beaver Stadium after the puck bounced off her skate and into the net. This was only the second goal of the season for the Oswego, Illinois, native.

The historic attendance played a major role in the atmosphere throughout the game. From the opening faceoff to the final buzzer, the air was filled with chants and constant support for the players on the ice.

Katie DeSa recorded her ninth shutout of the season and was met with cheers from the fans as she headed down the tunnel. However, for the Pawcatuck, Connecticut, native, she saw this moment as a full circle, closing out her senior season.

“Especially being a senior, it's great to have it in my final year,” DeSa said. “(I) definitely appreciate it a little more having come to Beaver (Stadium) for football games the last four years and then finally being able to play there. It’s really awesome.”

An energetic atmosphere was ultimately topped off with the Nittany Lions heading through the gates and down the tunnel, surrounded by handmade banners made by the “RoarZone.”

For coach Jeff Kampersal, the Nittany Lions’ continued work together further exemplified the “standards” they’ve set for themselves. Penn State adapted to the unusual environment and never gave up on its goals, which only added to the trust Kampersal instills in his team.

“They have higher goals than what they’ve accomplished so far, but trust is our biggest core value,” Kampersal said. “I trust them all with my life, I think they have that sort of relationship with everyone else. That’s what makes us so connected on the ice.”

The connection between player and coach could be seen since the start of the season, as Penn State had its best start in program history, winning 16-straight games.

From being a part of the first hockey game inside Beaver Stadium to setting records throughout the season, there is a belief in the locker room that this historic game set the program on track to reach new heights.

“Here at Penn State, we get so much support it’s insane,” Walsh said. “I think that people are starting to realize women’s sports really matter. So, I think that was a big step for us, and then (fans) coming here supporting us, it’s super special.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: McKenna Walsh scores first goal in Penn State outdoor hockey history
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
There was a lot of unfamiliar territory explored when No. 4 Penn State took the ice to face conference opponent Robert Morris University.

A roughly 40-yard walk to the bench from the tunnel, Beaver Stadium public address announcer Joe Putnam announced the starters, opposed to Pegula Ice Arena’s Rodney Martin, and the students of the Roar Zone were not breathing down the neck of the opposing goaltender.

However, all that went away when the familiar sound of the goal horn echoed through Beaver Stadium, signaling a goal from McKenna Walsh, the first outdoor goal in Penn State hockey history, en route to a 3-0 win over the Colonials.

“She’s a legend now,” coach Jeff Kampersal said, and referred to her as a “lunch-pailer,” focusing on her work ethic. “Every day she goes to work with a lunch pail and grinds. She’s not gonna get a ton of points, but she’ll defend the other team’s better players. She’ll win faceoffs, she’ll grind, get in the goalie’s mix and stir things up a bit.”

After a scoreless first period, the Nittany Lions finally struck 12 minutes into the middle frame of action.

After Walsh stick-lifted and knocked Robert Morris winger Rowyn Ringor off the puck, Katelyn Roberts deflected Catriona Crarer’s attempt to dump the puck into the Colonials’ offensive zone and knocked the puck into the neutral zone.

Walsh picked up the puck at the red line and skated up the near-side boards in a 2-on-1 with Shelby Shane, who was promoted from the extra skater position to the third-line left wing position in coach Kampersal’s adjusted lineup in the absence of Tessa Janecke, Matilde Fantin and Nicole Hall for Olympic purposes.

“Shelby’s a really smart player,” Kampersal said. He also mentioned that despite the freshman’s low minutes this season, she’s a happy kid. “She thrived when her number was called and we would expect nothing less from her. I thought she was dynamite as well, made the plays that she needed to make.”

After she crossed the blue line and entered the Penn State offensive zone, the Oswego, Illinois, native skated to the near-side faceoff circle and delivered a centering pass to Shane. While Walsh cut toward the net, Shane sent a backhand pass that kissed Walsh’s skate and effortlessly slid through the five-hole of Robert Morris goaltender Maggie Hatch.

Despite it being a historic goal, that wasn’t even a thought in Walsh’s mind. She said she didn't, at the moment, realize the significance of her goal. Instead, it was more important for a different reason.

“I was more excited to get us on the board because I knew once we got one, we were gonna get another,” Walsh said.

The goal served as the first of the game and the second of the year for the sophomore center, the sixth of her career. Shane now has three points in her collegiate career, all on assists.

Walsh also praised the Kutztown, Pennsylvania, native Shane.

“I thought she did awesome today and obviously [I] wouldn’t have scored without her, but she did really good, and I can’t wait to see how she’s gonna excel from here,” Walsh said.

Walsh and the Nittany Lions will conclude their series against Robert Morris on Saturday at 6 p.m. at Pegula Ice Arena.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field's Nick Sloff breaks 1 mile record
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another week, another record by Nick Sloff.

Sloff broke the men's mile record at the Penn State National Open, running a 3:54.90 to win the race.

Last week, Sloff broke the men's 3000-meter record at the Penn Elite, running 7:48.55. A week before that, he ran the 10th-best 1000-meter time in school history in 2:19.06.

Sloff's record breaks Evan Dorenkamp's record set in 2022, when he ran 3:55.02.

title: 2-goal second period lifts No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey to win over Robert Morris at Beaver Stadium
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State women’s hockey team competed at Beaver Stadium against in-conference opponent Robert Morris for the first time in program history, at 1 p.m. Friday.

The Nittany Lions increased their winning streak to six with a 3-0 victory over the Colonials behind a two-goal second period. Goaltender Katie DeSa closed out the game with 13 saves on 13 shots and recorded her 22nd career shutout, building on her program record as she now leads the nation with nine on the season.

“They set their own standards, as coaches, we can guide, we can work on them with habits and things like that,” coach Jeff Kampersal said. “But they're doing their own thing on a day like today.”

The contest set the record for the highest single-game attendance in program history, with 1,838 spectators watching in person.

Less than a minute and a half into the first period, the ice staff got to work on repairing a hole behind goaltender Maggie Hatch’s crease along the boards. The repairs stalled action for roughly five minutes before the players were able to resume play.

Penn State played its first game without captain Tessa Janecke (USA), Nicole Hall (Sweden) and Matilde Fantin (Italy) as each of them will be competing in the 2026 Milano-Cortina Winter Olympic Games. Mya Vaslet filled Janecke’s spot as the first-line center, playing alongside Katelyn Roberts and Abby Stonehouse.

“(Vaslet) managed the game really well, and she's really fast, and so that'll allow her speed to help out,” Kampersal said.

Taylor Lum and McKenna Walsh moved up to play with Shelby Shane on the third line in the absence of Hall and Fantin.

The blue and white didn’t lack offensive firepower, however, as Penn State consistently peppered goaltender Hatch. At the final buzzer, the Nittany Lions outshot the Colonials 42-13.

Tensions flared in the early game as the blue and white controlled possession, as the starting forwards Grace Outwater, Maddy Christian and Mikah Keller generated offensive opportunities on the doorstep. Penn State’s physicality prompted a response by the Colonials’ defense as pushing and shoving ensued.

With 4:29 remaining in the first period, Keller intercepted a breakout pass in the slot, striding down on the Nittany Lions’ first true open opportunity. Her wrist shot was saved by Hatch’s hot glove.

Two minutes later, Penn State got its best chance of the period as Walsh, Lum and Shane surged on a 3-on-0. Walsh deked to Hatch’s glove side and had a step on the goaltender, but her backhand shot was saved by Hatch’s extended pad to keep the game scoreless heading into the first intermission.

Robert Morris took its first penalty just under three minutes into the second period. Laura Eustace cross-checked a Nittany Lion in her own defensive end. However, the power play lacked substance and the teams were back to even-strength without incident.

Walsh scored the first Division I goal at Beaver Stadium with 7:52 remaining in the second period. Shane gave a backhand pass to Walsh, who seized the moment for her second goal of the season.

“I was more excited to get us on the board, because I knew once we got one, we were going to get another,” Walsh said. “I was just happy that it went in the back of the net.”

And then the floodgates opened. Fifty seconds after the opening goal, Christian followed up with a one-timer courtesy of Outwater’s centering feed to the middle of the slot that found a hole under Hatch’s blocker.

The third period slowed the pace of play considerably, with neither team generating key opportunities through most of the frame. Both teams relied on defense to mitigate odd-man rushes and breakaways, leading to a stalemate.

However, with 4:22 remaining in the game, Outwater stripped a Colonial defender of the puck in the slot and flicked a shot over Hatch’s glove to take a 3-0 lead.

The Nittany Lions coasted to the final buzzer to improve to 25-4 on the season.

Up Next

Penn State returns to Pegula Ice Arena tomorrow at 6 p.m. to close out its two-game series against Robert Morris.

MORE WINTER SPORTS WEEKEND COVERAGE

title: Penn State women's hockey's Beaver Stadium game breaks single-game attendance record
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State's fans delivered at Beaver Stadium.

The official attendance at the outdoor game for Penn State against Robert Morris on Friday was 1,838, as announced at the game, setting a new program record for single-game attendance.

An announced attendance of 1,838 here at Beaver Stadium is a new single-game record for women's hockey.— Daniel Studer (@DanielStuderPSU) January 30, 2026

The Roar Zone, located in the student section at the back of the field's south end zone, brought banners similar to the ones that Nittanyville usually brings.

The rest of the fans, located along the eastern bleachers, showed up in freezing temperatures to witness the first-ever Division I hockey game at Beaver Stadium.
