title: Building a dream hockey lineup out of Penn State football players
author: Avery Hill | Football Editor
description:
A lot of hockey will be played in Beaver Stadium, so let’s get weird with it.

With their athleticism, physicality and the chance to be esteemed skaters, I decided to build the dream Penn State hockey lineup out of past and present Nittany Lion football players.

If Guy Gadowsky is reading this, I’d advise trying talking to the NCAA to approve eligibility waivers to bring a title to Hockey Valley. Anyway, here goes nothing.

Left wing: Tyler Warren

Let’s get the obvious one out the way. You can’t convince me Tyler Warren doesn’t fit into any sport, including things like water polo, bocce ball and even professional TAG.

The only question was what position does Warren fit best. Playing on the left wing will allow him to attack the net, find open skaters and play a bit of defense as well.

In emergency situations, Warren easily slots in at goalie or defenseman as well, but goalie would take away a chance for him to make an impact offensively. At 6-foot-6, 258 pounds, he’d be a huge wing, but his presence would make him easily a polarizing force on ice.

Center: Michael Robinson

Michael Robinson could do just about everything at Penn State, so I’m confident he can win every faceoff too.

Robinson would represent yet another jack-of-all-trades for Gadowsky’s squad, becoming a force on the defensive end while being able to dish it to Warren and others offensively.

Additionally, the 2005 Big Ten MVP’s skillset includes the stamina to stay on the ice for longer shifts. I may not have ever played hockey, but I think I’ve already built a championship-winning team.

Right wing: Saquon Barkley

This list is incorrect if SaQuads doesn’t crack the offensive lineup. With freak athleticism paired with strength and skills that likely far surpasses anyone in the NHL currently, he’d be an absolute superstar on the ice.

Saquon Barkley would give opponents nightmares anytime he laced the skates up, and his breakaways would be a sight to see.

Let Barkley make it to the NHL. Trust me, I’ll be tuned into each All-Star Weekend to watch him put on a show.

Defenseman: LaVar Arrington

While I’m not sure how much leaping LaVar Arrington will be able to do on the ice, I think he can be a driving force on the defensive end.

With the unit already assembled on the offensive end, all Gadowsky needs Arrington to do is deliver body-crushing board checks and become an obstacle near the net.

You can really slot any of ST1X C1TY in this position, and even go with Michael Mauti. But I’m sticking with Arrington.

Defenseman: John Urschel

I know what you’re thinking here. The 300-pound John Urschel has no business on ice. I argue he does.

Urschel, who earned his PhD at MIT in mathematics and scored a 43-of-50 on the NFL Wonderlic test, is extremely intelligent. He could be the cerebral captain on this team, though Gadowsky may need to do a bit of load management if he’s on the ice for too long.

Even outside of his intellect, Urschel has the strength and the quickness to translate to skills on skates. Pick Urschel, and you get a leader that can help push the team through tough moments in the pursuit of glory.

Goalie: Chop Robinson

Chop Robinson got off the ball better than just about anyone during his time at Penn State, such reflexes and agility is perfect for playing goalie.

Robinson may not enjoy being unable to lunge out and level opposing skaters, but the position would allow him to make plenty of plays for his team.

Additionally, his incredible bend would allow for some highlight reel saves at the net, making him a netminder to watch every night he’s out there.

Top players off bench: Justin King, wing; Daryus Dixson, Kaytron Allen, center, defenseman; Sean Clifford, goalie

Gadowsky’s got a big and physical lineup going so far, but I’m sure they’ll be sent to the penalty box a ton or even suspended, so he’s going to need some key players on his bench.

Justin King, who ran a 4.31 40-yard dash, has the speed to either race down to save a short-handed breakaway, or get off on one of his own during the power play.

Daryus Dixson has the length and scrapiness to really make a difference defensively, using his stick to become a menace on the defensive end.

Kaytron Allen’s motor never stops. Expect him to be aggressive on faceoffs and a presence not to be messed with on a 2-on-1.

Then at goalie it’ll be Sean Clifford. A bigger goalie can’t be sustainable for the whole season. Clifford’s IQ and athleticism allows for a change of pace when Robinson’s out for the night, so he’s an easy one to slot in.

MORE WINTER SPORTS WEEKEND COVERAGE

title: Preview | Penn State men’s lacrosse set for season opener against Colgate
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
After a run to the NCAA semifinals last year, No. 7 Penn State will open the 2026 season on Sunday when it hosts Colgate.

The Nittany Lions will have to wait at least another week to return to Panzer Stadium, as Sunday’s contest will be played in Holuba Hall due to potential inclement weather and frigid temperatures.

Last season saw the blue and white go 12-5 en route to the aforementioned appearance in the Final Four, where it lost to Cornell, the eventual national champions.

Penn State will get another shot at the No. 4 Big Red later in the year, but it’ll first match up against another two-time foe from 2025 in its third consecutive season opener against the Raiders.

Colgate went 10-8 last season while playing about as tough a schedule as a Patriot League team can. After the Raiders’ season-opening loss against Penn State, they travelled to Charlottesville, where they lost to No. 5 Virginia by 10 goals.

The Raiders won the Patriot League championship last year, getting two ranked wins in the process. The title secured their spot in the NCAA Tournament, setting up a first-round rematch with Penn State, which ended Colgate’s season.

Colgate had three players with 67 or more points in 2025, but all three either transferred or graduated after the season. Its most productive returner will be senior midfielder Hunter Drouin, who had 48 points for the Raiders last year.

Drouin was named a preseason All-American honorable mention by Inside Lacrosse ahead of the 2026 season, a recognition he also received prior to his last campaign.

For Penn State, the biggest challenge will be figuring out how to succeed in the post-Matt Traynor era. Traynor scored 153 points as a Nittany Lion, 61 of which came in his senior season.

He’ll be replaced on the first midfield line by star sophomore Hunter Aquino, who scored 37 points in a freshman campaign that saw him be named Big Ten Freshman of the Year and a second-team All-American by Inside Lacrosse.

The Easton, Pennsylvania, native has already been named a preseason second-team All-American by Inside Lacrosse, joining fellow second-teamer Alex Ross and honorable mention Jon King.

Penn State leads the all-time series with Colgate 16-10. The Raiders’ last win against the Nittany Lions came in 2024 when they secured a 13-12 victory in that year’s season opener.

MORE LACROSSE CONTENT

title: Penn State wrestling hosts Nebraska in first Bryce Jordan Center dual of calendar year
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
One of the most highly anticipated matchups of the 2025-26 season for Penn State will take place on Friday when the Nittany Lions host Nebraska inside the Bryce Jordan Center.

The Nittany Lions have dominated the series history, with Cael Sanderson holding the edge since he took over in Happy Valley over Cornhuskers’ head coach Mark Manning.

Here’s how each matchup breaks down.

125 pounds: No. 1 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs. Alan Koehler (NU)

Luke Lilledahl will take on the lone unranked wrestler in the entire dual in Alan Koehler. Lilledahl is the top wrestler at 125 pounds, and will have the easiest matchup of the entire dual.

The 125-pound bout is likely to start off the dual and could be the quickest of the matches with Lilledahl’s style of wrestling. He could go on the attack early and often, scoring a lot of points en route to a possible bonus-point victory.

133 pounds: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs. No. 10 Jacob Van Dee (NU)

Marcus Blaze will have another major test with Jacob Van Dee on Friday. Van Dee is 12-3 and dropped from his No. 8 ranking after losing to Ben Davino of Ohio State.

Blaze will take on Davino in two weeks when Ohio State faces the Nittany Lions in the second BJC dual. With Blaze’s low style, it’ll be tough for Van Dee to score points, as Blaze has restricted points all season. In his freshman year, he’s well in contention to win the Big Ten and national title.

141 pounds: No. 11 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs. No. 4 Brock Hardy (NU)

Braeden Davis’ stamina will be put to the test against Brock Hardy. Hardy, just like Van Dee, fell against Ohio State to a highly ranked wrestler when he lost to Jesse Mendez.

Mendez appears to be in a tier of his own so it didn’t come as a surprise when Hardy lost. Now, Hardy will take on Davis, who’s starting to find more and more comfort at his new weight class.

If Davis can hold up stamina wise, things could get interesting down the stretch.

149 pounds: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs. No. 18 Chance Lamer (NU)

This is the first of the gauntlet of wrestlers Penn State brings to the lineup. Shayne Van Ness is the top wrestler at 149 pounds and has showcased an unreal gas tank as of late. Van Ness is coming off the back of a 31-point performance against Maryland after nearly getting pinned.

Chance Lamer, who only has three losses on the season despite his No. 18 ranking, will have to step up his game even more to take down Van Ness, who’s proved he’s taken another step from his redshirt sophomore year.

157 pounds: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs. No. 5 Antrell Taylor (NU)

Another test for the highly regarded freshman.

PJ Duke will take on Antrell Taylor, the 2025 National Champion, in a match to really see where Duke is in his freshman year. After a slower start, Taylor appears poised to get back the national title match.

Taylor will be the big test for Duke, and if Duke comes out on top, it’ll be all eyes on two weeks from now, when the freshman phenom takes on No. 1 Brandon Cannon.

165 pounds: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs. No. 7 LJ Araujo (NU)

Mitchell Mesenbrink continues to raise his level, asserting himself as one of the favorites for the Hodge Trophy. LJ Araujo has shown signs of potential, already ranking No. 7 in the country, while holding an 11-5 record.

Mesenbrink is on another level from any wrestler he’s faced this season. Araujo fell to Mikey Caliendo of Iowa, a wrestler Mesenbrink is 7-0 against. All signs point to another big win for Mesenbrink as there’s yet to be a wrestler to keep it close with the Nittany Lion.

174 pounds: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs. No. 4 Christopher Minto (NU)

Levi Haines is another wrestler who’s raised his style to another level. Haines made the powerful jump last season, focusing on back points, something Mesenbrink is doing this season. He’ll face Christopher Minto, who’s 14-3 on the season compared to Haines’ 14-0 record.

Minto fell to Patrick Kennedy on Jan. 23, a wrestler that Haines has a 3-0 record against. Similar to Mesenbrink, that matchup against the Iowa wrestler could be the overall deciding factor, with Haines poised to get back to the top of the podium.

184 pounds: No. 1 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs. No. 6 Silas Allred (NU)

Rocco Welsh is up to No. 1 after his victory over Angelo Ferrari. Welsh will face Silas Allred, who appears to be in the second grouping of wrestlers nationally at 184 pounds. The top group features both Welsh and Ferrari in addition to Minnesota’s Max McEnelly and Missouri’s Aeoden Sinclair.

Allred could make a statement, but the momentum could be fully on the Nittany Lions’ side by this point, proving to be too much against Welsh, who’s given up minimal points across the entire season.

197 pounds: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. No. 9 Camden McDanel (NU)

Josh Barr is another Penn State wrestler who appears to be in a tier of his own. Camden McDanel has proven himself as an All-American threat, but taking down Barr will be a whole different task.

Barr has just two losses in the last 12 months, also holding one of the biggest moments of the BJC duals last season when he defeated Jacob Cardenas in tiebreakers.

McDanel is 14-4, while Barr sits at 12-0. Since Barr’s return from injury, he’s undefeated and remains dominant, culminating in another potential dominant performance from the Nittany Lion.

285 pounds: No. 12 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs. 4 AJ Ferrari (NU)

Cole Mirasola will take on AJ Ferrari to likely close out the dual — if the dual begins at 125 pounds like it typically does. Ferrari and Mirasola match up well weight wise, with the Cornhusker jumping to heavyweight this season after wrestling at 197 pounds a year ago.

Mirasola has performed well against wrestlers closer to his size, but Ferrari’s unique style could cause issues. The match will likely be very low scoring as Ferrari has a more conservative style of wrestling, but could overpower Mirasola with his strength if the opportunity arises.

Based on the lineups, the dual will likely be out of hand by this point, but could play a major factor in rankings, Big Ten seeding and even NCAA Tournament seeding when the calendar turns to March.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Report: Penn State RB Nick Singleton breaks foot at Senior Bowl, his father says
author: Avery Hill | Football Editor
description:
A former Penn State running back’s draft stock is now in jeopardy.

According to a report by Rich Scarcella of the Reading Eagle, Nick Singleton broke his foot Thursday during Senior Bowl practice.

His father, Tim, told Scarcella that the running back injured the fifth metatarsal bone in his right foot. He’s set to undergo surgery next week and won’t participate in on-field drills at the NFL combine.

Singleton rushed for 3,461 yards in his four-year career in Happy Valley. He broke the program’s career rushing touchdowns, total touchdowns and all-purpose yards records this past season.

Prior to his injury, he was expected to be one of the top running backs off the board in April.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 5 Penn State looks at a rematch against Illinois in competition supporting THON
author: Annie Gleba | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 5 Penn State will take on Illinois in a Big Ten matchup at 1 p.m. on Sunday at Rec Hall. The match will be in support of THON. Last week, the Nittany Lions tied with Illinois in the Sam Mikulak Invitational at second place with a score of 317.650.

This season, Penn State sits at 1-0 in individual matches outside of tournament play, where it has finished 1st and 2nd. In the last competition, it performed well across the board, which greatly improved its score. With that, the Nittany Lions still have room to improve, which they will try to bring into this rematch.

In Florida, they weren’t able to have all of their best gymnasts in the lineup, but are expecting them to be out on the floor Sunday. During the routines in Florida, Brayden Erickson put up the second-best floor routine of his collegiate career at a 13.050. Matt Underhill followed him with a 13.550, which was just a tenth short of his season high.

In addition to these record-breaking routines, three other Nittany Lions posted some of the highest scores of their careers, including Bobby Alessio with a 12.850 on the pommel horse, Ritam Malik with a 13.800, his best score of the season on any skill and Ricky Perez with a personal best of 13.650.

With all of these record-breaking scores, Penn State is coming into this matchup strong. Illinois arrives in this matchup with a record of 0-3-1, placing 4th at the OSU Open, and the runner-up finish in the last tournament, facing Penn State.

The Fighting Illini showed strength on the rings events, scoring a 52.700 at the OSU Open and a high performance from Hasan Aydogdu, with a 14.500 in the Sam Milulak Invitational, keeping them in close range to Penn State. The rings will be a category to watch closely at this meet, with many competitors achieving over 14 points on both sides. It could be a determining factor in the outcome of the overall match.

Other high-performing categories for the Fighting Illini are pommel horse, with two competitors scoring over 14. That includes Preston Ngai with a 14.350 and Brandon Dang sporting a 14.650. The highest score a Nittany Lion has achieved on the pommel horse this season was a 13.850 by Landon Simpson in the Sam Milulak Invitational.

This competition is expected to feature close scores, requiring both squads to ensure their top athletes are healthy and ready to perform their best routines. The outcome of this matchup will help set the tone for future conference matchups. Both teams will compete against Michigan, Ohio State and Nebraska down the line.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Review | From fatherhood to the courtroom, A$AP Rocky returns to studio in new album ‘Don’t Be Dumb’
author: Brennan Kramp I The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s official — A$AP Rocky is back. After nearly a decade spent making some switches to his life in a more mature and adult fashion, dealing with some incredibly unfortunate and somewhat nasty endeavors, A$AP Rocky has put out his much anticipated fifth studio album, “Don’t Be Dumb,” to already incredible acclaim.

On just the first day of its release, “Don’t Be Dumb” amassed over 35,000,000 Spotify streams and is projected to sell just under 120,000 units of vinyl.

This doesn’t come as much of a shock as the long awaited return stems all the way back to when Rocky quietly whisked himself away from music for about eight years after his 2018 album “Testing.”

Since his last release, Rocky has welcomed three kids with Rihanna, entered the fashion and film industry and — to put it simply — was going through it.

Now nearing 40, Rocky is back with “Don’t Be Dumb,” an album that subverts expectations people have for artists as they mature. While many popular artists begin to lose their stride after they’ve hit their prime, on “Don’t Be Dumb,” Rocky shows that he still has plenty left in the bag.

The album opens with the humble and ballsy jam, “ORDER OF PROTECTION” that delivers the truth from the source with Rocky starting the track by saying, “It’s been a lil’ while since I been in the league / A couple lil’ trials, couple of leaks.” Right away, Rocky makes sure the audience knows the context of this project before unloading a producer masterclass on the rest of the album.

Following the opener are two heavy-hitting, true-to-form A$AP Rocky tracks in “HELICOPTER” and “STOLE YA FLOW,” with the latter being Rocky’s diss track to Drake. Here, Rocky takes that same energy seen on “HELICOPTER” and uses it to deliver a right hook to Drake’s already banged-up ego.

Drake, famously trampled in his “beef” with fellow rapper Kendrick Lamar in 2024, also had a well known on-again off-again relationship with Rocky’s now wife Rihanna. “STOLE YA FLOW” hits on a different level lyrically, as Rocky not only flaunts the fact that he stole Drake’s once-love, but disses Drake’s musicianship saying, “First you stole my flow, so I stole yo’ b —.” Kendrick Lamar may have delivered the final blow, but Rocky nailed the coffin shut.

After his ruthless yet poised attack on Drake, Rocky eases you into a R&B soaked jam in “STAY HERE 4 LIFE” featuring the rising hip-hop star Brent Faiyaz. A mellowed out tune about the processes of embracing life after a tumultuous time — whether it be fame, fatherhood, music or love, Faiyaz perfectly compliments Rocky’s message on this track, as an ode to his life outside of the studio — showing love to his wife and kids as he enters back into the music scene.

One of the more unique songs on the album comes from “PUNK ROCKY,” a fabulous merger of early 2020’s New York alternative and late modern R&B. An angsty and heartfelt song where the fusion of alternative sound with Rocky’s traditional rap flow makes for an intriguing listen as you get to see yet another side of Rocky’s production capabilities.

Another semi-experimental song with so much class and ingenuity is the album's 13th track, “ROBBERY” featuring Doechii. On “ROBBERY,” Rocky lays down an intimate, smokey tune supported with some acoustic bass and drum kit pulled right off the stage of a late-night speakeasy bar.

The chemistry between Rocky and Doechii in this musical back-and-forth is perfectly complimented by the jazzy production on the track, giving a low-lit and sensual vibe. It’s a song where you can actually feel the inspiration and level of commitment behind what you’re hearing.

The closing track on the album is “FISH N STEAK (WHAT IS IT),” featuring Tyler, The Creator and Jozzy. Here, Rocky closes the door on the album with an ultra-slowed down tune designed to produce sweet sounding, melodic and chill vibes, throwing in some DJ-vinyl-scratch samples, flute, harp and traditional drum and snare to give his closer an authentically classic feel that reminds you of his early rise and long awaited return.

There are several other songs on the album that are absolute speaker boomers as well. “STOP SNITCHING” featuring BossMan Dlow and Sauce Walka, “AIR FORCE (BLACK DEMARCO) and “THE END” featuring will.i.am and Jessica Pratt, just to name a few.

Overall, “Don’t Be Dumb” is not only great for music culture, but it also represents something bigger in Rocky’s career. In the current trends of popular music, a lot of the industry has been dumbed down by in-and-out acts — propelled by singles featured on TikTok trends and commercials — yet there are still veteran members of popular music that can leave for nearly a decade and come back to produce a smash hit album just for the love of the game.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Coffee shop crawl | A coffee-lover’s guide to local businesses
author: Amelia Houck | The Daily Collegian
description:
If you're like me, you eat, sleep and breathe coffee. I go to bed every night genuinely excited to wake up and drink my next cup.

A hobby of mine is trying local coffee shops and seeing what unique creations each place has to offer. Here are some of the best local places in downtown State College and beyond to get your caffeine fix.

Elixr

With a charming atmosphere, Elixr has such a quintessential coffee shop vibe to it.

I tried their hot cappuccino, and it was delicious. There was an adorable latte art flower on mine, and the attention to detail here certainly did not disappoint.

My friends ordered one of their signature drinks — an iced strawberry oatmilk latte. If coffee is not your favorite, Elixr boasts a wide range of matchas as well.

Overall, the price was affordable and the atmosphere was adorable, so I will be returning.

Irving’s

Known best for their homemade bagels, Irving’s also has an espresso machine, and their coffee is some of my favorite downtown.

There is plenty of seating upstairs, downstairs and outside, which is great for larger groups looking to sit together. My go-to that never disappoints is an iced caramel latte with an extra shot of espresso (paired with a breakfast sandwich, of course).

I particularly love Irving’s dedication to curating special holiday and seasonal drinks.

Additionally, Irving’s is well known for its wide variety of homemade smoothies if you are looking for an alternate drink option. Definitely a place that offers great coffee and food for a reasonable price, and one I will certainly go back to.

Vibe Coffee Co.

This vibrant place is the perfect spot to sit with a friend. The adorable decor, large windows and bright lighting add to the atmosphere of this coffee shop.

I ordered one of their custom Penn State-themed iced lattes and it was delicious. A fun feature of Vibe is that they offer coffee flights so you can try multiple different flavors of their lattes, and split coffee cups where you enjoy two different drinks in the same vessel.

Vibe uses farm-fresh milk and you can genuinely taste such a huge difference in the quality as well as the freshness.

If you are looking for other options, they also make their own fresh-squeezed lemonade. With moderately priced items and quality coffee, Vibe is a must-visit place downtown.

Bagel Crust

With two downtown locations, Bagel Crust is probably not your first thought when you think of a morning coffee.

However, I have found they offer the least expensive coffee in State College by far.

I ordered an iced coffee with a splash of milk, and it was very refreshing with a bold flavor. Additionally, the seating at Bagel Crust is pretty vast, and lots of space is available.

Sowers Harvest Cafe

Offering healthy cuisine and a wide range of custom drinks, Sowers makes an incredible iced caramel latte.

With farm-fresh milk, their coffee is always rich, creamy and flavorful. Sowers boasts very affordable pricing, given that most of their ingredients are locally sourced.

The indoor and outdoor seating offers plenty of options for large groups and the atmosphere provides such a comforting and calming energy.

I highly recommend stopping by for coffee or lunch.

Pump Station

Located just outside of State College in Boalsburg, Pump Station is an aesthetic gas station-themed coffee shop that even has a drive-thru.

The decorations inside include vintage wall decor and historical gas station displays, sure to make you feel like you’re getting “fuel” for your car and not you.

I ordered a cold brew with vanilla cold foam — you can get it in any flavor you want, and it was the perfect balance of boldness and creamy vanilla essence.

Pump Station offers plenty of seating near large garage-esque windows. With moderate pricing, it is definitely worth the five-minute drive outside of downtown.

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: New Year, new me | Why the ‘75 Hard Challenge’ is effective
author: Skylar Williamson I The Daily Collegian
description:
When the clock strikes midnight on Jan. 1, the pressure of choosing a New Year’s resolution starts all over again, just as it did the year before. People can sometimes find themselves stuck on what they can improve during the next 12 months.

The viral 75 Hard Challenge combines physical and mental components that intrigue people on the internet, with rules that create the perfect concoction for a healthy new year.

The challenge was created in 2019 by Andy Frisella, a podcaster and motivational speaker. He described his challenge as a “mental toughness,” less concerned with losing weight and more about building self confidence and determination.

Like many fitness challenges, 75 Hard grew through social media. During COVID-19, millions of people spent their time inside trying to stay in shape, waiting for the world to open back up.

The hashtag ‘75Hard’ now has over a million posts on Instagram and millions more spread over different social platforms, especially TikTok.

The main rules of the challenge seem simple: follow a healthy diet, perform two 45-minute workouts a day — one must be outdoors — and no alcohol.

The other daily rules include drinking one gallon of water, reading 10 pages of a nonfiction book and taking a progress photo, but the catch is slipping up equals starting over from day one.

The first step is choosing the right diet for whoever is doing the challenge.

Penny Kris-Etherton said people are attracted to a flexible diet, which is shown in the 2025 update from the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee (DGAC) with its new slogan: “Eat Healthy Your Way!”

“A healthy diet can be implemented in a lot of different ways,” Kris-Etherton, professor of nutrition, said. “Consistency with that diet is important.”

She said younger generations like to do things “their way” and that’s what 75 Hard gives them the opportunity to do.

The physical activity part of the challenge is just as flexible as the dieting. The only strict part is one of the two daily exercises needs to be outside.

Travis Masterson said the 75 Hard Challenge gives people the freedom to adjust their exercising to their own lifestyles.

“When we look at successful weight-loss programs, it's (75 Hard) about the level of exercise we recommend in a day anyway,” Masterson, an assistant professor, said. “It’s good that they keep it very vague because that’s going to mean different things for different people.”

Exercise can be a walk in the park with your friends, and for people looking for a challenge, it can be a full-body workout in the gym. Bottomline, increasing physical activity is the overall goal.

Masterson said figuring out not only what is best for the body, but what will stick long term, is important to be aware of.

“Rather than building very strict rule sets around things, it’s (75 Hard) teaching you to be disciplined and consistent with whatever you can do,” Masterson said. “That’s a part of why it’s so valuable.”

Removing alcohol is where the concerns of 75 Hard come in. Michael Russell said if a person who drinks frequently cuts out alcohol, there are several changes that are apparent over time.

“If you cut out alcohol for a long period of time, your sleep quality will start to improve pretty dramatically,” Russell, an assistant professor, said. “For young adults, the other thing you will see is a lot more emotional regulation.”

Although this seems like the hardest part for every college student, cutting out alcohol can significantly improve their quality of life if taken seriously, according to Russell. Having “hangxiety” is just one example of the negative effects of drinking.

Russell said the downside of the 75 Hard Challenge is the rebound effect it can have, especially with alcohol.

“It’s possible if someone drinks when they’re out with friends and messes up the challenge, they will just drink more because the challenge is now over and they have to start over,” Russell said.

Overall though, the benefits of the challenge are undeniable — it can be used as an effective starting point for a healthier life.

“Getting people on the track to just thinking about their health is a huge step forward,” Kris-Etherton said.

As the viral challenge progressed over the years, people started creating their own versions and adding personal goals, like getting eight hours of sleep daily. A lighter version of 75 Hard is 75 Soft, where people follow similar rules to the original challenge but give themselves more leeway for failure.

The 75 Hard Challenge allows people to take their own individual goals and put them into something that is about more than just losing weight, making it a good New Year’s resolution.

“It’s kind of a comprehensive program with nutrition and physical activity included but also reading books,” Kris-Etherton said. “That’s what health is. It's not just one thing.”

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Penn State women’s gymnastics travels to Piscataway to take on Rutgers
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State women’s gymnastics heads to New Jersey to take on Rutgers for week 4. This is the third Big Ten opponent for the Nittany Lions so far, and they look strong as they head east.

The blue and white are coming off three straight wins after narrowly beating Maryland in their meet up on Saturday.

The Scarlet Knights are coming off a loss against Washington, which was their second Big Ten matchup of the season. The first was Ohio State, which resulted in a loss, as well. Rutgers competed in and won two tri-meets to start off its season, but has yet to make a splash in the Big Ten season. It hopes to get a win against the Nittany Lions this weekend.

Penn State has been a strong force at the beginning of this season, putting up great scores across the board and keeping the good times going with win after win. The blue and white seem to be particularly strong on vault and bars, really creating a lineup of gymnasts that are both strong in both of these events.

Ava Piedrahita and Elizabeth Leary are all over the score sheet for the Nittany Lions, and like against Maryland last weekend, these two gymnasts have been consistently putting up great scores on vault and beam. Leary had a strong weekend, going 9.825 on vault and 9.875 on bars. Piedrahita went 9.900 on both events, leading the scoring for the blue and white in both events.

The blue and white have a really great rotation going on. Ellie Monahan, Dani Latronica, Kalea McElligott, as well as Leary and Piedrahita, are in constant rotation for Penn State. With McElligott and Monahan both putting up 9.800 plus on both floor and beam, the team has the opportunity to do really well against not only Rutgers but also other Big Ten teams.

Rutgers has a few gymnasts who are really strong all-around, or in more than just one event. Gabrielle Dildy was a top performer in the Ball State Tri meet against Ball State and Western Michigan. Dildy put up a 9.825 on beam and a 9.850 on vault, which won her individual all-around and vault awards.

In the Rutgers Tri meet against Temple and Brockport, Delaney Adrian was a standout as an all-around gymnast. Adrian scored first on beam with a score of 9.825, and also took home a personal best of 9.875 on floor.

Emily Leese was also really valuable for the Scarlet Knights in the Rutgers Tri meet, but has been contributing to high vault scores so far this season. Leese scored a 9.900 on vault against Temple and Brockport, and then scored a 9.850, coming in first on vault against Washington this past Friday.

If Rutgers plays its cards right and creates a really great lineup for this weekend, it can send the Nittany Lions home with their first loss of the season. Both of these teams have the ability to cover all of their bases with talent and have depth in their rosters.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Column | Penn State baseball’s three biggest must-watch games in 2026
author: Samuel Simonic | The Daily Collegian
description:
The start of the 2026 baseball season is almost here. As the Nittany Lions prepare to suit up for action, fans supporting the blue and white are doing the same.

Given the hectic nature of our daily lives, watching all 55 regular-season games is a tall task. Below is a guide to three games you should circle on your calendars.

These are the nonnegotiables.

Feb. 15: Kansas State (MLB Desert Invitational)

Penn State’s first test.

There is nothing like baseball in February. Sure, it’s freezing cold in State College, but across the country, the blue and white will be competing in the warm state of Arizona for its first set of action.

The MLB Desert Invitational grants a favorable slate of three games for Penn State, which will take on Air Force and Grand Canyon before facing Kansas State.

The Wildcats were a respectable team competing out of the Big 12 and finished with a 32-26 record last season. While Kansas State was very solid at home, tallying an 18-3 record, the team was just 7-4 on neutral sites. Penn State finished last year with a 4-2 record on neutral sites, making this matchup an even battle.

Both teams possess similar strengths as each ranked among the best hitting teams in college baseball last season. Kansas State ranked 23rd among the entire poll last year in home runs, hitting 97 in 58 games. The Nittany Lions weren’t too far behind at 47th, hitting 81 homers in 56 games.

Despite the Wildcats losing talent to the MLB, the team has been on the rise. In the last two seasons, Kansas State has reached the NCAA Tournament twice. This will be a good early test for two very even teams.

March 6-8: at Texas Tech (three-game series)

A sneaky nonconference test.

To this point, Penn State would have a decent amount of baseball under its belt. While March Madness serves as the highly coveted college sports event of this month, college baseball presents a unique show of its own.

For the blue and white, this will mark a major nonconference series ahead of Big Ten play.

In the offseason, Penn State went to the portal to snag Greg Minnick, a former highly-touted recruit, who signed with Texas Tech out of high school. That may have fueled an even better duel, yet to be seen on the diamond.

Aside from looking ahead to Penn State’s schedule, Texas Tech will start out with an SEC gauntlet. Having to face Oklahoma, Vanderbilt and Arkansas, it’ll be a great identity test for the Red Raiders early on.

This will give a good indication of what to expect when Penn State opens up Big Ten play. After finishing last season with a subpar 20-33 record, the Red Raiders are receiving hype for a better upcoming season.

After reloading in the portal and on the recruiting trail, Texas Tech has balance across its roster. This seems like another evenly matched opponent for the Nittany Lions, who could be in for a surprising upset in early March.

April 24-26: at Oregon (three-game series)

Heading across the country for a quality Big Ten opponent.

All the talk of the town in 2026 college baseball has centered around the team in the West. And no, it’s not the Oregon Ducks.

The UCLA Bruins are the team to beat. Nevertheless, Penn State will not face them in the regular season. Luckily, or unluckily, the Nittany Lions will get a stab at another Big Ten foe from the West in Oregon.

Besides serving as a premier site in college baseball, PK Park presents an intimidating atmosphere, one that is hard for opposing teams to win. In recent years, the Ducks have emerged as one of the top units in the nation.

Seeking its sixth-straight NCAA Tournament appearance, Oregon is coming off a highly successful year in 2025. The Ducks tallied a 42-16 overall record and went 22-8 in Big Ten play, finishing as the Big Ten regular-season co-champion with UCLA.

Like Texas Tech, the Ducks will be tested early on in their neutral-site contests. Playing in the “Live Like Lou Las Vegas College Baseball Class,” Oregon will face the likes of Vanderbilt and UC Irvine. Following that, they will face Oregon State at home. All three of those opponents were Tournament teams last season.

In Perfect Game’s Preseason Top 25, the Ducks placed at No. 13. Given the national preseason attention and coach Mark Wasikowski’s vast winning continuity, Oregon will pose a major threat to the Nittany Lions in 2026.

MORE BASEBALL CONTENT

title: Column | Projecting Bridget Nemeth's stateline after missing 2025 season
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
The most victories in a single-season by any pitcher in Penn State softball history, top five in both strikeouts and innings pitched in a single campaign, unanimous First-Team All-Big Ten, Big Ten Freshman of the Year and a top-40 ERA in the nation.

Those are just some of the many accomplishments that Bridget Nemeth has achieved in her career as a Nittany Lion. The catch, Nemeth achieved all of them in just one season.

The junior right-hander had arguably the best freshman season and pitching performances in program history. Given her rookie year success, the Glendora, California, native had plenty of eyes on her ahead of her sophomore season. However, Nemeth was sidelined for 2025 due to an undisclosed injury.

Those eyes now turn to the 2026 season to see how Nemeth’s return to the circle will play out.

Here’s a look at some projected stat lines for Nemeth’s upcoming junior campaign.

ERA and nonconference opponents

In 2024, Nemeth’s 1.77 ERA finished second in the Big Ten. In 2026, the junior will have to face some tough lineups right from the get-go. The blue and white are scheduled to face four Power 4 teams in its first five games.

It’s safe to assume that Nemeth won’t get the starting nod in all of these, but she’ll certainly be on stand by. The one in particular to look out for is when Penn State takes on BYU on Feb. 7.

The Cougars’ .308 team batting average finished third in the Big 12 and top-50 nationally. The hitter that poses the biggest threat to Nemeth and company is sophomore Ilove’a Brittingham. The Nipomo, California, native’s .410 batting average and 69 RBI placed third in the conference, additionally her 21 home runs finished second.

The opponents only get tougher as the month goes on, as the Nittany Lions travel to Knoxville for two games against ESPN/USA Softball preseason No. 4 Tennessee.

The Lady Vols lost Taylor Pannell, who was one of the SEC’s most productive hitters last year, to the transfer portal, but gained a batting gem in Boise State transfer Sophia Knight.

Knight set a Mountain West record last campaign with 103 hits, and she was also the only player in Division I softball to record an 100 hit season. The junior also finished with the nation's third-best batting average at .486.

Knight’s going to be one of the toughest bats that Nemeth has to face, and they’ll likely have to battle multiple times. This factor could either make or break Nemeth’s ERA early on in the season, and possibly set the tone for the rest.

Given the state of Penn State’s early schedule, I think heading into conference play, Nemeth will post an ERA close to 3.00.

ERA and Big Ten competition

It won’t get much easier for Nemeth when conference play comes around, starting in mid-March. The Nittany Lions’ opening and closing Big Ten series is where Nemeth will likely find her toughest battles.

Penn State opens conference play with a trip to Eugene to face preseason No.5 Oregon, and will close it by hosting preseason No.9 Nebraska.

Both opponents ranked top-three in the Big Ten and top-10 nationally when it came to batting average and total hits.

Oregon’s best returning hitter is sophomore infielder Rylee McCoy, who reached single-season program highs a year ago with a tied best 19 home runs and top-ranked 32 extra-base hits.

Nebraska returns a strong pair of senior bats in reigning Big Ten Player of the Year Jordyn Frahm and Ava Kuszak. Both finished with top-15 batting averages in the Big Ten. Frahm’s .462 average was also enough for sixth nationally. Additionally, both Frahm and Kuszak finished in the top-11 in the conference in hits.

Kuszak is the only one of these hitters that Nemeth has already faced, meeting in 2024 when Kuszak was at Wisconsin. The then-Badger went 1-for-3 with a double and a strikeout.

As Nemeth has some tough tasks ahead of her, I don’t think she’ll post an ERA as low as she did in her freshman campaign, instead I think she’ll finish near the 2.00-2.15 range.

Strikeouts

In 2024, Nemeth tossed 202 strikeouts, becoming the fourth Nittany Lion to surpass 200 in a season. This also put her third in the conference in total strikeouts.

I think it’ll be hard for Nemeth to reach 200 strikeouts again, but it’s certainly possible. My prediction is that her final total will be somewhere between 185 and 200.

Victories

Nemeth holds the single-season program record with 23 victories. It’s hard to predict how she’ll fare in the win column without knowing how many appearances Nemeth will see this season.

Assuming that, like in 2024, Nemeth appears in more than half of Penn State’s games, then I think she could reach 20 victories once again.

title: Penn State men’s basketball drops eighth-straight game in defeat to Northwestern
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
With a 1-4 record on the road, Penn State visited Northwestern in hopes of earning its first conference win and first win in January.

That record didn’t get any better Thursday night, though, as the Nittany Lions now find themselves in an eight-game losing streak after falling to the Wildcats 94-73 to remain winless in the Big Ten.

Ivan Jurić won the opening tipoff, giving the blue and white a prime opportunity to get off on the right foot, but a Josh Reed turnover led to a Max Green three-pointer that put the Wildcats on the board first.

Mike Rhoades entered Thursday’s match with a 1-2 record over Northwestern, and the fourth meeting was getting off to a good start.

The two foes were trading three pointers in the early running of the first half when an Eli Rice long-range basket tied the affair at 6-6.

Rice entered the contest against the Wildcats as Penn State’s most efficient three-point shooter, knocking down 45.4% of his attempts from three-point range.

Northwestern was quickly seizing control in the early stages of the game but Rice knocked down his ninth point to once again tie it back up as he went 3-4 from three-point distance, hoping to stay hot.

Though the Wildcats had been in control so far, Penn State took its first lead of the night when Freddie Dilione V called his own number on a drive to the basket for his second basket of the night.

Met with contact, Dilione was gifted a trip to the charity stripe and took advantage to put the Nittany Lions up 20-19.

Consecutive Wildcat misses from right under the basket gave the Nittany Lions a golden opportunity to dig into their 35-30 deficit, but a failed Kayden Mingo driving layup put an end to those hopes.

Northwestern immediately capitalized and grabbed onto a seven-point lead after a Tre Singleton close-range make. Singleton, averaging 7.6 points per game, was up to nine points against the blue and white with three minutes to play in the first half.

Shooting 59% from the field and out-rebounding Penn State 13-10, the Wildcats held a slim 41-39 lead at the two-minute media timeout.

Despite Northwestern holding the lead for nearly nine-and-a-half minutes longer than the blue and white, it was still anyone’s game with the first half winding down.

Juriċ knocked down an and-one for Penn State’s 10th free throw in as many attempts, as well as his ninth point of the game, after getting fouled on his way to the basket to make it a 41-40 game in the late stages of the half.

Back-to-back Nick Martinelli baskets were the only remaining bit of action in the first half, and the Wildcats left their home court for the halftime break holding a 45-40 advantage, though the Nittany Lions felt they were within reach of their first conference win.

Penn State got on the board first in the second half with Reed making just one of two free throws.

Shortly after, Mingo poked the rock out, picking up a steal, but getting fouled on the shot, which ended up being a beneficial foul for the Wildcats as Mingo could only convert one of two from the charity stripe. Mingo’s miss was just Penn State’s second of the night from the free throw line.

A Dilione turnover led to a two-handed slam from Angelo Ciaravino off the fast break, as the Wildcats seized a 55-44 lead, followed by a discombobulated Penn State taking a timeout.

A mid-range Martinelli jumper gave him his 24th point of the night and a personal milestone – his 17th 20-plus point performance this season, the most in the nation.

Northwestern’s 13-point lead faded into a 60-53 edge after back-to-back scores from Reed, followed by an unassisted Mingo score, capitalizing on a Wildcat turnover.

A big slam from Juriċ was the final score of Penn State’s run after Northwestern snapped it with a Singleton basket that was followed by a Ciaravino three-pointer.

With just over nine minutes left to play, back-to-back Mingo makes from the charity stripe made it a 67-61 Wildcat lead, but Martinelli quickly called his own name once more on the and-one as he moved up to 27 points on the night.

Consecutive blue and white turnovers led to Northwestern’s largest lead of the night, as the Wildcats grabbed a 76-61 advantage with just about six minutes to play, not fully closing the door, but feeling pretty comfortable against a Nittany Lion team that was in the midst of a three-minute scoring drought.

Martinelli moved up to 32 points after three-consecutive free-throw makes on different possessions, putting him just two points away from his career-high 34 points that he set against Rutgers earlier this year.

Northwestern just kept hammering away to make sure its lead would be insurmountable, as it commanded an 84-66 lead with just over three minutes to play.

On the way to nailing the coffin shut, Martinelli matched his career-high thanks to the help of a season-high of four three-point makes.

The action may have stopped there for Martinelli, but not the rest of the Wildcats, as Ciaravino went over 20 points and a couple more three-pointers went in on the way to a 94-73 Northwestern victory.

Injury Report

Entering Thursday’s game, Tibor Mirtič was listed as “questionable,” rehabbing a knee injury, but he did not play against Northwestern.

Saśa Ciani was also missing from action against the Wildcats, listed as “out,” with an “undisclosed injury.”

Up Next

Penn State returns to action when it hosts Minnesota this Sunday at the Bryce Jordan Center in the first game of February.

The Nittany Lions look to snap their 8-game losing streak against the 10-11 Golden Gophers. Tipoff is scheduled for 2 p.m.

title: Takeaways from Penn State’s 2026 schedule
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
After eager anticipation from the Happy Valley faithful, Penn State’s 2026 schedule has been released, marking the first slate of games where Matt Campbell will be leading the Nittany Lions from the sidelines.

Penn State 2026 schedule:9/5: Marshall9/12: Temple (Lincoln Financial Field)9/19: Buffalo9/26: Wisconsin10/3: @ Northwestern10/10: USC10/17: @ Michigan10/24: Bye10/31: Purdue11/7: @ Washington11/14: Minnesota11/21: Rutgers11/27: @ Maryland— Lyle Alenstein (@LAlenstein) January 27, 2026

Here is what you need to know about the schedule.

Favorable nonconference slate

Penn State starts the season once again with a trio of nonconference opponents. All three of the games will be played in Pennsylvania, with two of them being at Beaver Stadium.

Those opponents will be Marshall, Temple and Buffalo. When the Nittany Lions face the Thundering Herd and the Bulls, it’ll be in State College. In Week 2, they’ll travel to Lincoln Financial Field, also the home of the Philadelphia Eagles, to play the Owls.

In 2025, all three squads boasted a 5-7 record, making Penn State likely a way-too-early favorite by a comfortable margin in every matchup.

The Nittany Lions will see familiar faces when they face Temple, as quarterback Jaxon Smolik, tight end Joey Schlaffer, safety Kolin Dinkins and defensive tackle Kaleb Artis all transferred to the Owls following the 2025 season.

The idea of facing lower-level FBS and FCS programs for Power Four conferences will likely be a trend for the foreseeable future, as schools will want to minimize losses in pursuit of a College Football Playoff appearance.

Toughest stretch

Weeks 6 and 7 will be the toughest stretch of games for the Nittany Lions, hosting USC and traveling to Michigan in consecutive weeks.

During the 2025-26 campaign, both sides boasted a 9-4 record, finishing right next to each other in the final AP Poll of the year, as the Trojans were No. 20 and the Wolverines were No. 21. Both teams lost in the postseason, as USC fell to TCU in the Alamo Bowl while Michigan dropped the Citrus Bowl to Texas.

Both teams bring back their star quarterbacks, with USC returning Jayden Maiva and Michigan bringing back Bryce Underwood. There also are some changes, as the Trojans lost defensive coordinator D’Anton Lynn to Penn State for the same role while the Wolverines replaced head coach Sherrone Moore with Kyle Whittingham from Utah.

The game’s on Oct. 10, so there’s a good chance the USC game is the White Out with it being at the midway point of the season and the Trojans being the best opponent up to that point. On the other hand, a road game at Michigan Stadium is a daunting environment, as the atmosphere “the Big House” creates is up there for one of the best in college football.

Overall

On paper, Penn State has a pretty easy schedule, but as the 2025 season indicated, that doesn’t mean it’ll be a breeze.

The expectation this past season was the only regular season losses for the Nittany Lions could’ve been Oregon and Ohio State. Instead, it resulted in a six-loss, spiraling season.

With that being said, the only matchups that present a notable challenge on paper in 2026 are USC and Michigan.

An argument can be made for Washington as well, as Penn State will make the cross-country trip to face the Huskies for the first time on the road since they joined the Big Ten.

Still, the makeup of the roster shows this, as of January, is a team that should be able to win football games. With no Indiana, Ohio State or Oregon on the schedule, and Purdue, Rutgers and Maryland on it, the slate gives Campbell an opportunity to cash in on an easier schedule in Year 1 at the helm.

With that being said, the talent on the roster has to gel together for the schedule to work out in Penn State’s favor. The makeup of the roster is those coming transferring in from 8-4 Iowa State, players who stuck around from a 7-6 Penn State and an assortment of recruits and other transfers.

If the roster can find its chemistry come August, the 2026 group of games should have Campbell leading the Nittany Lions to a winning record in comfortable fashion next year.

title: Penn State softball faces some tough matchups in nonconference play
author: Ashley Beres | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State opens up its 2026 campaign with a loaded nonconference schedule that lasts over a span of 26 games before it faces its first Big Ten opponent. Last season, the Nittany Lions finished 25-27 and 10-12 in nonconference play.

The blue and white dug itself into an early hole in its 2025 campaign, recording just one win in five nonconference games at the NFCA Leadoff Classic. Blue and white head coach Clarisa Crowell’s squad looks to come out hot this season and pick up key wins before conference play begins on March 13 against Oregon.

NFCA Leadoff Classic

The Nittany Lions travel to Clearwater, Florida, for a slate of games against Missouri, Boston College, Eastern Kentucky, BYU and Auburn.

The season kicks off against Missouri on Feb. 6, and while the Tigers finished last in the SEC in 2025, they could still be a tough opponent to begin the new campaign. Despite Penn State having the highest ERA in the Big Ten in 2025 at 5.76, the Tigers struggle behind the plate.

Missouri finished last in its conference in many major offensive categories, including batting average, runs, hits and RBIs. Additionally, junior Bridget Nemeth returns to the pitching staff after an injury ended her season, after she faced just four batters.

With just one returner from last year’s rotation, sophomore Abigail Britton, it’s important for this new pitching staff to come out hot against a rocky offensive team.

The Nittany Lions then take on Boston College and Eastern Kentucky. The blue and white should be favored in both of these matchups, but the Colonels could be difficult. They finished with a 38-16 record last season and are an ASUN powerhouse.

The key to a victory over Eastern Kentucky is shutting down star junior Kennedy Drafton. The Pearland, Texas, native had an excellent 2025 campaign, posting a .356 average with 52 hits and 45 RBIs.

Following that matchup, Penn State takes on a good BYU squad. The Cougars were on the cusp of reaching the NCAA Tournament, but fell just short after a loss to Iowa State in the Big 12 Tournament.

Despite this, BYU finished 32-17 and was one of the best offensive teams in the conference with the third-best batting average at .308.

The opening slate of games wraps up against Auburn, which finished hot after a rocky start to last season. The Tigers made it all the way to the NCAA regionals before falling to Florida State.

Houston/HCU Invitational

Penn State hits the road again to Houston, Texas, for games against Incarnate Word, Houston, Lafayette, Houston Christian and Pitt. This is a favorable part of the schedule for the Nittany Lions as they should have the upper hand in all the contests.

Houston finished last in the Big 12 in 2025 at 22-25 and was bounced in the first round of its conference tournament against BYU. However, the squad has new leadership after the Cougars fired its coach, Kristin Vesely, after nine seasons.

The blue and white conclude the invitational against interstate rival Pitt. The Panthers finished at 20-32 in 2025, but one of the bright spots of their rough campaign was a 16-8 win over the Nittany Lions in Happy Valley. Penn State needs to limit Pitt’s offense in its matchup for a chance at redemption.

SPACEU Classic

The next group of games takes the Nittany Lions to Orlando, Florida, for games against Charleston Southern, UCF, Ohio and Notre Dame.

Penn State should hold steady against most of these squads, but UCF will be a true test. The Knights finished as one of the top teams after reaching the NCAA Regional Final.

The blue and white’s bats will be challenged by UCF’s dominant pitching staff, who finished with the fourth-best ERA in the Big 12 in 2025 at 3.07. Sophomore Isabelle Vega had a breakout freshman campaign, with an excellent 1.70 ERA and 110 strikeouts.

Tennessee Invitational

February concludes with matchups against NC Central, Tennessee and Appalachian State in Knoxville, Tennessee. Two games against the talented Volunteers highlight this round of games.

Tennessee finished as a top-eight team in the nation after plowing through multiple tough opponents and reaching the Women’s College World Series semifinals, where it lost to SEC foe Texas. The Volunteers are a complete team, and it showed with their 47-17 record and dominance on both sides of the field.

If Penn State pulls off the upset, then it will earn much praise from the softball world and put the program on notice.

Penn State Softball Invitational

The Nittany Lions head back to Happy Valley for their opening home slate against Lehigh, Binghamton, Colgate and Niagara. This should be a successful series of games for Penn State, as they are favored in all matchups.

The blue and white have won against Lehigh in its last two games against the Bald Eagles, so its home opener should likely end in a victory.

Oregon State

Penn State travels cross-country and ends its early nonconference play at Oregon State on March 11. The Beavers finished at 24-23 in the West Coast last season and boast a 4-0 record against the Nittany Lions this millennium.

The last matchup between the two teams was in 2014 when Oregon State defeated Penn State 12-10 in a neutral site.

The Nittany Lions have two more nonconference games, Bucknell and Saint Francis, later in the season, but both matchups are winnable.

It’s essential for Crowell’s squad to pull off some upsets and win the favorable matchups before entering play in a tough conference.

MORE SOFTBALL COVERAGE

title: Column | Key Players to watch in Penn State softball’s 2026 season
author: Brielle Gari I The Daily Collegian
description:
With the 2026 season days away, Penn State’s roster has been finalized and is ready to be put to the test this year. With returning stars, impacting transfers and freshmen ready to step back onto the dirt and have a long run into the spring.

As veteran leadership returns to Beard Field, guidance from the upperclassmen is key.

Here are some players to watch as the 2026 season looms.

Brooke Klosowicz

Brooke Klosowicz is returning to the blue and white after an astounding 2025 season. She led the Nittany Lions in every offensive stat, starting and appearing in all 52 games last year.

With her .422 batting average, she led Penn State with 65 hits, 23 doubles and a tied best 13 home runs. Klosowicz has been named a preseason top-10 utility player by D1Softball. She’s looking to build off her record-breaking sophomore season.

Natalie Lieto

The true freshman from last season returns for the Nittany Lions, Natalie Lieto. The Monroe, Connecticut native is expected to excel in her sophomore year for the blue and white. With her speed, power and defensive skill in the outfield.

Lieto was named to the Big Ten All-Defensive team as one of two student-athletes in the league who were true freshmen. Penn State’s defensive MVP in the postseason after tallying 98 outputs. Left fielder had an impressive .329 batting average with a .936 OPS over the course of her first season with the blue and white.

McKenna Young

Transfer from South Dakota, McKenna Young joins the Nittany Lions pitching staff for her junior year. In her breakout season as a Coyote, she went 14-8 in the circle. Finishing the season with 152 strikeouts, 10 complete games and five shutouts in her 2025 season.

With Young in the circle for Penn State, the defensive side for the Nittany Lions looks promising for the upcoming season.

Gabby Grandishar

Champion, Ohio native Gabby Grandishar was one of the most versatile two-way players in the 2025 signing class.

Being a pitcher and infielder with the height of 5-foot- 9, Grandishar is a high prospect with a lot of potential and versatility. On the plate but also in the diamond.

Coming into Happy Valley as the No.54 prospect in the nation.

Breanna Hanik

Another standout recruit in the 2025 class was Breanna Hanik, who joined the blue and white. Ranked No. 65 in the nation for overall player. The Oak Lawn, Illinois native led Marist High School to the state championship game in three seasons.

Having a combination of defense, power, and speed contributes depth to the lineup. Adding excitement to the squad as well as youth. Penn State will rely heavily on Hanik for her positioning in the outfield, as she’s expected to see early action there.

The 2026 season is days away, and their lineup is an important first step into a successful season. Taken together, these players form a top-tier lineup that will succeed in the regular season and postseason.

MORE SOFTBALL CONTENT

title: No. 5 Penn State men's hockey prepared for outdoor battle with No. 2 Michigan State
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State men’s hockey plans on fully transforming Happy Valley into Hockey Valley this weekend with arguably the most widely anticipated regular season series in program history, as the No. 2 Michigan State Spartans travel to State College Friday and Saturday.

All eyes on the outside

Saturday’s contest will take place inside of Beaver Stadium, the first men’s hockey game to take place in the historic football venue. The gravitas of the event has drawn the eyes of the national media to this top-five matchup with attention that regular-season college hockey doesn’t usually receive.

Reporters who typically focus on the National Hockey League, including Barstool’s Paul Bissonette, are gathering around the game as a prototype for an NHL Winter Classic taking place in Beaver Stadium.

Penn State has played in just one outdoor game up to this point, coming last season at Wrigley Field’s Frozen Confines, where it tied Notre Dame and lost the shootout. Michigan State has played in multiple outdoor games during its history, including the Frozen Confines. The Spartans are 2-2-2 all time in outdoor games.

Temperatures for the game are expected to feature a wind chill well below zero degrees Fahrenheit. Both benches will be heated to keep players warm while off the ice. Fans attending the game can enjoy “warming zones” around the east side of Penn State’s campus, as well as hot beverages sold inside Beaver Stadium to combat the frigid temperatures.

While Saturday’s game is expecting over 60,000 fans in attendance, Friday’s game should push for the all-time attendance record at Pegula Ice Arena. With fans coming to town early, the smaller venue has a get-in price of over $50 for standing room only tickets as of Thursday morning.

The hype centers around the star power on display as well as the scenery, with Gavin McKenna, Jackson Smith and Aiden Fink going up against Porter Martone, Cayden Lindstrom and Trey Augustine. These top prospects will be the focus of the national media throughout this top-five series.

Battle scars

The Nittany Lions traveled to East Lansing in early November and suffered two losses at the hands of the green-and-white. The first game was a closely contested overtime loss, but game two was an embarrassing disaster for Penn State.

The blue and white lost 5-0 in an embarrassing loss that was highlighted by multiple line brawls and egregious penalties. The game marked Josh Fleming’s worst game of the season and saw the offense unable to compete against a Michigan State defense that was overpowering.

Since that game, Penn State made a focus to find an identity and to control its emotions on the ice. Both of those plans have come to fruition in the second half, as Penn State is in the midst of a seven-game winning streak. Stars like McKenna and Fink have started showing the offensive prowess they were hyped upon when they arrived to begin the campaign. The trajectory is similar to last year’s Nittany Lions, with more success for the groundwork than the nearly winless stretch Happy Valley witnessed in 2024.

Michigan State has been at the top of the nation throughout the year, led by Martone and Augustine. Martone, the Flyers' most recent first-round pick, sits at 28 points on the year, while Augustine holds a 1.73 goal-against-average and a .938 save percentage.

Series History

Historically, the Spartans are the Nittany Lions’ closest rival. The series sits at 22-22-8 entering this weekend. The visitors hold the recent advantage, leading the series 8-2-4 since 2022, including a 4-0-1 mark in the last five matchups at Pegula Ice Arena.

Ben Schoen’s eight points pace every current Nittany Lion in points against Michigan State, while Aiden Fink leads with five goals. Fink missed November’s series due to injury.

The series renews at 6 p.m. Friday at Pegula Ice Arena and 1 p.m. Saturday at Beaver Stadium.

MORE WINTER SPORTS WEEKEND COVERAGE

title: Column | Who’ll step up in net for No. 7 Penn State men’s lacrosse with goalie Jack Fracyon graduated?
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State goaltender Jack Fracyon started between the pipes for three years, and when a mainstay netminder graduates, it can be difficult to fill the gap left behind. The Nittany Lions are in one such situation.

Coach Jeff Tambroni has four options for who’ll step into the starting role: senior Will Mitchell, junior Ben Johnson, redshirt freshman Hayes Schreiner and true freshman Preston Hawkins.

1. Ben Johnson

Johnson, a junior out of Peoria, Illinois, was the only backup goaltender to appear in action last year, with Fracyon playing nearly the entire season. He entered the crease on two separate occasions, playing the closing minutes in a pair of games.

His first outing was against Yale in New Haven, Connecticut, where he didn’t face a shot in his little time in between the pipes. In his second game against Robert Morris, where he made three saves on five shots in the fourth quarter, Penn State won 22-8.

Johnson played in three games as a freshman, making two saves on four shots in that season. After seeing no shots against Navy, Johnson saw two shots against Cornell and Maryland each, where he made one save in both games. His appearance against the Terrapins, leading to a 19-9 victory, was also his first and only postseason experience, as it was the Big Ten semifinals.

Having experience at the collegiate level is valuable when having to choose the next starter. Johnson, being the only one with that experience, appears to be a shoo-in to fill Fracyon’s role to start the season.

2. Hayes Schreiner

Schreiner is my second choice for who I believe would inherit Fracyon’s crease. While he’s yet to make his debut at the collegiate level, the Wyndmoor, Pennsylvania, native’s bright future can be summed up by his high school resume and his family’s prestige.

The redshirt freshman was a four-star recruit via Inside Lacrosse, having played all four years of his high school lacrosse career on the Chestnut Hill Academy varsity team and being named the captain in his senior season. There, he set the all-time school record for most saves in a career.

Schreiner’s noteworthy performance earned him various honors in 2023, including being named to the All-State, All-Philly and All-Inter-Academic teams.

Looking deeper into his history with the sport, it’s apparent that Schreiner comes from a “lacrosse family.” His father, Todd, a graduate of Lehigh and also a goalie, was drafted in the seventh round by the Rochester Rattlers in the 2002 Major Lacrosse League (MLL) draft. Hayes’ mother, Katie, played lacrosse at Washington College.

Should Tambroni place his trust in the young netminder, and Schreiner perform aptly, he’ll presumably have a long-term goalie on his hands. Someone who’s able to produce for three or four years in a row, like Fracyon.

And in lacrosse, stability between the pipes can’t be ignored.

3. Preston Hawkins

Hawkins, while being the youngest of the four, is far from out of the running. It’s rather uncommon for true freshmen to receive playing time due to a lack of collegiate experience or simply because of how the older netminders fit into the current system.

However, Hawkins’ background suggests that he’ll be ready to compete with Johnson and Schreiner for the starting role.

Hawkins, a Powell, Ohio, native, was rated a four-star recruit by Inside Lacrosse as well as the 96th best goaltender in the Class of 2025. He committed to Penn State back in 2023 and remained loyal.

Like Schreiner, Hawkins also holds his high school’s record for most career saves, and he did so in his junior year at Worthington Kilbourne High School.

His long list of high school awards includes a trio of consecutive conference championships, back-to-back First-Team All-State honors, being named a USA Lacrosse All-American, and the Ohio Goalie of the Year award.

It may be worth testing Hawkins in goal against an unranked opponent, or playing him in the fourth quarter of a blowout, to see where his baseline collegiate capabilities are before his maturity rises over the course of his career.

4. Will Mitchell

It’s Mitchell’s senior season, and the Matthews, North Carolina, native hasn’t touched the field throughout his collegiate career, serving as a depth piece behind Fracyon.

Despite not seeing action so far at Penn State, Mitchell’s veteran wisdom brings a new skill set: mentoring.

Being the oldest of the goalies, someone who’s “been there, done that” in terms of the daily life of a student athlete, he’s able to provide the younger goalies like Schreiner and Hawkins, as well as other incoming recruits, with knowledge.

However, it’s hard to argue against seniority being at play when it comes down to the “garbage minutes” at the end of a blowout victory or defeat. Tambroni may elect to throw Mitchell a bone and give him the time in goal that he’s dreamt of for the past three years over someone like Schreiner or Hawkins, who’ll have more opportunities as they grow older.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Freezing temperatures expected for Penn State women’s hockey game at Beaver Stadium
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
