title: Penn State’s Guy Gadowsky unsure of reason behind Hastings’ handshake no-show
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following No. 5 Penn State’s 3-1 victory over No. 8 Wisconsin last Saturday, coach Guy Gadowsky wore a confused expression, his hands extended in bewilderment as he stood on the Nittany Lions’ bench.

He intended to greet Wisconsin coach Mike Hastings at center ice for a postgame handshake, as is tradition at the end of a college hockey series. But Hastings never showed.

The Badgers’ coach instead walked toward his team’s locker room as the Nittany Lions mobbed goaltender Kevin Reidler on the other end, boos raining down from a disgruntled Kohl Center crowd after they witnessed their team get swept in a crucial Big Ten series.

At the end of last nights game Wisconsin head coach Mike Hastings refused to shake hands with PSU head coach Guy Gadowsky The Badgers and Nittany Lions will meet again March 5th & 6th 🍿 👀 pic.twitter.com/P7R5Y5wVfE— Game Notes (@GameNotesBud) January 26, 2026

Gadowsky remained unsure of the exact reason behind Hastings’s actions but guessed it was linked to his postgame celebration with Green Bay Packers linebacker and Penn State alum, Micah Parsons.

“I think it was just the timing of it,” Gadowsky said. “There was Micah Parsons behind our bench, and I think I was celebrating with him, and maybe took a little too long, I guess.”

It’s possible Hastings, who wore an angered expression as he appeared to yell “What the f—” as he walked away from center ice, was dismayed by the last-minute brawl that ensued in the third period of Saturday’s contest.

The fighting started when Wisconsin forward Tyson Dyck jabbed at Reidler’s glove after the netminder covered the puck with 10.2 seconds remaining in a 3-1 game. Penn State defenseman Nolan Collins cross-checked Dyck from behind, which sparked an extended brawl that saw Dane Dowiak take down a Badgers skater and Gavin McKenna grab another by the facemask.

Chaos at the end of the Penn State Wisconsin game in the final seconds included a ref being pulled down to the ice and multiple ejections! #WeAre #HockeyValley #CollegeHockey pic.twitter.com/HKKsnwGa6C— Basic Blues Nation (@BasicBlues) January 25, 2026

All 11 skaters involved in the scuffle were handed game misconducts.

Dowiak, his hand still attached to a Badgers skater long after the brawl ended, gestured with his other hand toward the scoreboard, which showed Penn State’s 3-1 advantage. The crowd roared with boos, but the junior forward didn’t care.

He said the Nittany Lions were simply giving back what Wisconsin fans had given them all weekend.

“I don't waste my time on (opposing fans),” Dowiak said. “Fans like to chirp at us, say a lot of things, and emotions kind of get the best of you at the end of the sweep. Sweeping in the Big Ten doesn't come around often. We were just giving back what they gave us.”

Penn State and Wisconsin will meet again, this time in Happy Valley, for a two-game series on March 5-6. It will mark the team’s final series before postseason play begins.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State 2026 season schedule released
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State finally has its 2026 schedule.

While the opponents were known, the dates were not, and Big Ten Network provided that information on Tuesday. The Nittany Lions will open conference play at home against Wisconsin in Week 4.

They'll then travel to Evanston, Illinois to face Northwestern, which Penn State faced in 2025 for what ended up being James Franklin's last game as the Nittany Lions' head coach.

Penn State will return home in Week 6 to face USC, a game that might be the best option for the 2026 White Out, before heading to face Michigan and its new head coach Kyle Whittingham. It'll be the teams' first matchup since the Nittany Lions' home loss in 2023.

After the two-game gauntlet, Penn State has a Week 8 bye before hosting Purdue on Oct. 31. The Nittany Lions will then travel cross-country to Seattle to face Washington on Nov. 7.

Penn State will return home for two straight weeks afterwards, facing Minnesota in Week 11 and Rutgers in Week 12. The 2026 regular season will conclude at Maryland on Nov. 28.

As for nonconference play, the Nittany Lions will face Marshall at home in Week 1, Temple at Lincoln Financial Field on Sept. 12 and Buffalo in Week 3.

Full schedule

Sept. 5 vs Marshall

Sept. 12 at Temple (Lincoln Financial Field)

Sept. 19 vs Buffalo

Sept. 26 vs Wisconsin

Oct. 3 at Northwestern

Oct. 10 vs USC

Oct. 17 at Michigan

Oct. 24 BYE

Oct. 31 vs Purdue

Nov. 7 at Washington

Nov. 14 vs Minnesota

Nov. 21 vs Rutgers

Nov. 28 at Maryland

author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor

Another week at No. 1.

Penn State remained at the top spot in the latest NWCA poll following a 2-0 weekend.

Ohio State stays unbeaten after sliding past Nebraska; Top-ranked Nittany Lions pick up two more shutouts1. @pennstateWREST2. @wrestlingbucks3. @CycloneWR4. @Hawks_Wrestling5. @CowboyWrestling6. @HuskerWrestling7. @HokiesWrestling8. @PackWrestle9. @GopherWrestling10.… pic.twitter.com/DULjShUFiM— NWCA (@nwcawrestling) January 27, 2026

Ohio State received the other top vote, coming in at No. 2 in the rankings. Other Big Ten teams in the rankings included Iowa at No. 4, Nebraska at No. 6, Minnesota at No. 9, Michigan at No. 10, Illinois at No. 12, Rutgers at No. 16, Wisconsin at No. 17 and Indiana at No. 24.

author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After a few weeks of competition to start the season, Penn State is ranked in the first weekly poll.

The men's squad enters the season ranked No. 8, while the women's team is ranked No. 31.

First rankings update of the indoor season📊#WeAre #PSUTF pic.twitter.com/SPj29pHjol— Penn State Track & Field/Cross Country (@PennStateTFXC) January 27, 2026

The Nittany Lions men's team rose 48 places after last year. Over the past few weeks, Ajani Dwyer and the mid-distance squad have run some of the best times in the nation.

title: No. 4 women's hockey earns pair of weekly conference awards after Delaware sweep
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following their sweep over Delaware and securing the AHA Regular Season Championship, two Nittany Lions earned weekly honors from the conference.

Four performances worthy of Women’s Players of the Week honors ⭐ #NCAAHockey pic.twitter.com/RFOD1MqFB1— Atlantic Hockey America (@Atlantic_Hockey) January 27, 2026

After leading all skaters in points over the weekend, Kendall Butze was tabbed the AHA’s Defenseman of the Week for the second time this season. The senior defenseman scored twice and assisted on three goals for a total of five points.

Butze’s goal in Saturday’s 7-0 win over Delaware was the 84th point of her career, tying former Nittany Lion Lyndie Lobdell for most career points by a defenseman in program history.

She now has 23 points in 28 games played this season.

Finishing the weekend with three points was center Mikah Keller, who was awarded the AHA’s Rookie of the Week for the first time in her career.

Keller, along with each of her linemates, scored a goal and assisted on another in Friday’s 5-0 win over the Blue Hens.

The Mosinee, Wisconsin, product brought her season total to 25 points, the most among all freshman skaters.

Butze, Keller and the rest of the Nittany Lions will prepare for their next game against the Robert Morris Colonials at Beaver Stadium on Friday at 1 p.m.

title: Penn State notebook | Kieger discusses losing streak, moving forward
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Amidst its third-worst losing stretch in school history, Penn State is on the outside looking in with the Big Ten tournament just over a month away.

Coach Carolyn Kieger expressed the team’s desire to play harder against more favorable opponents over the final stretch, starting with the Lady Lions’ matchup against Minnesota on Wednesday.

Remaining opponents

For the second straight year, Penn State is outside the Big Ten tournament and needs big wins if it wants to continue its season into March.

“We got some good games coming up against teams near who we need to be in order to get into the postseason,” Kieger said. “Obviously, focusing on one game at a time, but we know our schedule is more favorable down the stretch.”

Included in those remaining games are Indiana, Rutgers and Northwestern, who all sit at two or fewer conference wins. Before the Lady Lions face those struggling teams, they’ll face the Golden Gophers, who are 14-6 with five Big Ten victories.

“Minnesota is very versatile,” Kieger said. “They’re the best defensive team in the Big Ten. They do a great job of holding their opponents for points per game.”

The Golden Gophers’ low points against opponents stem from the slower pace of play they run. As a result, Minnesota gives up a conference-low 10.6 turnovers per game, as opposed to Penn State’s conference-high 18.9 turnovers per game.

Lineup changes

Saturday’s game against Oregon featured a very different starting lineup for the Lady Lions, missing both Kiyomi McMiller and Gracie Merkle.

While Merkle went down with what is believed to be a head injury during last week’s game against Washington, McMiller came off the bench for the first time this season.

“It’s just the same thing we’ve been doing all year,” Kieger said. “Changing up lineups, changing up starters and trying to find the right fit at the right time.”

In addition to Merkle’s appearance on the availability report, senior Amiya Evans has been out since Jan. 11, but has a chance to return on Wednesday.

“Hopefully (Gracie and Amiya) are healthy to play, but obviously concerned about their health first,” Kieger said.

Career reflection

With Kieger’s seventh season with Penn State winding down, she’s on track for her sixth losing season, with four of the worst losing streaks in school history.

This year, the Lady Lions are riding a 0-10 conference record alongside the men’s team’s 0-9 record. Both Kieger and Mike Rhoades have faced immense backlash on the internet over the past few weeks over the legacy they’re leaving behind.

“I mean, we approach every game the same,” Kieger said. “We approach everything the same, which is giving our all and putting our team in a position to win. We’re going to continue to do that.”

With eight games left this year, Kieger has a chance to break even or go above .500. Despite the hard path to reach that goal, her squad is continuing to fight for its season with Kieger in the hot seat.

“We continue to instill winning habits and make sure that we’re talking about what it takes to succeed in all walks of life,” Kieger said. “We want Penn State to win, but we want our women to feel it, and we want them to feel proud of themselves and each other.”

title: Report: Buffalo Bills promote former Penn State graduate assistant Joe Brady to head coach
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
A former Penn State graduate assistant is receiving a promotion in the NFL.

Joe Brady has a new role for the Buffalo Bills, going from offensive coordinator to head coach, according to multiple reports. The news was first reported by Ian Rapoport of NFL Network.

Brady was a graduate assistant for the Nittany Lions from 2015-16. He earned his Master's degree in educational leadership from Penn State.

Following his time with the Nittany Lions, he spent time with the New Orleans Saints, LSU and Carolina Panthers before joining the Bills in 2022.

Brady will replace Sean McDermott, who was fired after the Bills lost to the Denver Broncos this postseason. The deal is reportedly five years.

title: Penn State men's hockey's McKenna, Dowiak earn Big Ten honor
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 5 Penn State had two players earn Big Ten recognition following its series sweep of No. 8 Wisconsin.

Gavin McKenna and Dane Dowiak, who last Friday became the first teammates in program history to each tally a hat trick in the same game, were named the Big Ten's First and Second Stars of the Week, respectively.

Freshman Gavin McKenna and junior Dane Dowiak earn #B1GHockey First and Second Stars of the Week, respectively, following their Friday night hat-tricks and five-point weekend's each!! 🏒⭐️Read ➡️ https://t.co/D363nbTCTD#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/FG6iVdr0wt— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 27, 2026

McKenna earned the conference's top spot following his five-point weekend at the Kohl Center. The 18-year-old freshman scored three times in Game 1 and added another goal, his conference-leading fourth of the weekend, in Game 2.

McKenna extended his point streak to five games. He has registered eight points over his last three contests.

Dowiak opened the weekend with three goals in Game 1 and added two assists in Penn State's 3-1 win last Saturday. This marks the captain's first Big Ten Star of the Week in his four-year career.

title: Around the Big Ten | Pair of close duals headline weekend slate
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Similar to Penn State, there were two dominant victories over the weekend as the rest of the Big Ten saw a series of lopsided-dual matches.

However, two duals stood above the rest in competitiveness, headlined by a clash between upcoming opponents for the Nittany Lions.

BJC Dual preview

The most noteworthy contests of the previous weekend came from Penn State’s upcoming dual opponents in the Bryce Jordan Center in Nebraska and Ohio State. The two faced marquee opponents on Friday before clashing with each other in a highlight-reel matchup on Sunday afternoon.

The Buckeyes started the action on Friday with a 29-9 blowout of Minnesota in Minneapolis. Ohio State won the first five matches en route to taking seven out of 10 matches on the card.

Noteworthy matches in the dual included No. 4 Max McEnelly beating No. 5 Dylan Fishback, 4-1, in sudden victory. McEnelly has performed under expectations up to this match after being a favorite in the weight class entering 2025-26, while Fishback has surged up rankings up until his match Friday.

Unranked Buckeyes’ 125-pounder Vincent Kilkeary upset no. 9 Jore Volk in sudden victory to set the tone. During the ensuing five-match win streak, 141-pound No. 1 Jesse Mendez delivered a 21-5 tech fall over No. 9 Vance Vombaur.

Notable news for the Buckeyes is that 157-pound No.1 Brandon Cannon is out with a knee injury, which is expected to keep him out for multiple weeks. He is uncertain to return for their dual with Penn State on Feb. 13.

Nebraska, on the other hand, spent their Friday night losing to Iowa at home. Hawkeyes’ coach Tom Brands earned his 300th career win in the 22-14 victory.

The victory came behind a couple of upsets by the Hawkeyes. At 133, No. 10 Drake Ayala upset No. 8 Jacob Van Dee, 12-6, and at 184, Gabe Arnold upset No. 7 Silas Allred, 4-1.

On Sunday, Nebraska and Ohio State met in Columbus in a dual decided by a single point.

The dual started with four straight Buckeye victories, getting Ohio State out to a 14-0 lead. One of those wins saw Mendez get revenge over No. 3 Brock Hardy in a national final rematch. Mendez won 14-3 via major decision.

Once the bout reached 157 pounds, Nebraska turned the tides. No. 5 Antrell Taylor’s major decision over Maddox Shaw set off a run of five straight wins to give Nebraska a 16-14 lead with one match to go. Nebraska saw upsets at 174 pounds, with No. 6 Christopher Minto defeating No. 4 Carson Kharchla. At 184-pounds Allred beat Fishback in tiebreakers during the streak.

The dual came down to a heavyweight rematch between No. 3 Nick Feldman and No. 4 AJ Ferrari. The match went into sudden victory, where Feldman took down Ferrari to secure Ohio State’s 17-16 win.

Rest of conference

The rest of the Big Ten saw a smattering of blowouts around the Midwest, with the exception of another one-point swing in Champaign, Illinois. The No. 12 Fighting Illini beat No. 17 Rutgers on a criteria tiebreaker after the matches concluded tied 16-16.

The teams traded back-to-back wins for the first four weight classes, before Illinois pulled away slightly, up 13-6. At 174 pounds, Ryan Ford upset No. 25 Colin Kelly with a major decision to bring the Scarlet Knights back into it.

Rutgers trailed 16-13 entering the heavyweight bout when No. 19 Hunter Catka took a sudden-victory decision to knot the dual at 16.

Illinois was awarded the decisive point on third criteria, which is awarded to the total individual scoring across the 10 matches, where it had a 46-42 edge.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Braeden Davis falls in latest InterMat rankings for Penn State wrestling
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 1 Penn State had a largely inconsequential week for Tuesday’s InterMat rankings update.

Braeden Davis fell one spot to No. 12 at 141 pounds despite winning both of his matches against Indiana and Maryland. Davis was jumped by North Carolina freshman Luke Simcox, who jumped from No. 17 to No. 10.

The other nine Nittany lions held steady in their positions, including six No. 1 wrestlers across the lineup.

Luke Lilledahl, Shayne Van Ness, Mitchell Mesenbrink, Levi Haines, Rocco Welsh and Josh Barr are ranked No. 1 in their respective weight classes.

Elsewhere in the lineup, Marcus Blaze sits at No. 4 at 133 pounds, PJ Duke is ranked No. 3 at 157 pounds and Cole Mirasola remains No. 12 at 285 pounds.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: People’s Defense Front, SCDS hold vigil, protest to honor Alex Pretti
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
The People’s Defense Front and Student Committee for Defense and Solidarity (SCDS) held a vigil and protest Monday night at Old Main to honor Alex Pretti, who was shot and killed Saturday during Immigration & Customs Enforcement (ICE) operations by a Border Patrol agent in Minneapolis.

The death of Pretti, an intensive care unit nurse working for the Veterans Administration, occurred a little over two weeks after the fatal shooting of Renee Good by an ICE agent. Good’s death sparked protests in both State College and across the country.

Elise Groff, who also participated in the Renee Good protest, said she felt disturbed with Pretti’s death and what it says about the current climate in the United States.

”ICE killed a man in Minneapolis and the government's lying about that,” Groff, a fourth-year studying chemistry, said. “I'm surprised there aren't more people out here.”

Groff said she hoped the vigil and protest would give Pretti’s family comfort by showing they are not alone in grieving for their loss, and that the protest would help spread further awareness to others who may not be well-informed about his death.

The vigil began at 7 p.m. and saw hundreds of protestors lead through chants of “Say his name: Alex Pretti,” “Say her name: Renee Good” and “Fuera La Migra (ICE out).”

During the protest, a red car attempted to drive through the crowd at the Allen Street light with a protester jumping onto the vehicle and punching the windshield before the car drove away.

Carter Davis said he was appalled by attempts from the federal government to cover up the details surrounding Pretti’s death.

State College police said no reports have been made about any incidents from the protest.

“I feel like everyone here saw what happened in Minneapolis, which is kind of pretty clear,” Davis, a second-year studying secondary education, said. “It's just not right.”

Davis said he believes change must happen soon in order to prevent further bloodshed.

“I'd like to hope that someone's listening but if they're not listening, we can at least try to be heard by being loud and outspoken,” Davis said. “I hope we should start to get people's attention so that they start thinking critically about what's going on and just stir up some sort of action. Maybe you can get more people to just come to the protests and just speak out against what's going on, just cause it's terrible.”

Protestors were guided to march from Old Main and into downtown State College, holding signs that said “Drive out ICE,” “I prefer my ICE crushed” and “Make racists afraid again.”

The march ended at Old Main at 8:15 p.m. with organizers from the SCDS and People's Defense Front urging those in attendance to sign up for neighborhood patrols and continue coming together to hold future events.

An SCDS spokesperson, who requested anonymity for fear of their personal safety, said they hoped the protest’s message would reverberate across multiple channels and ways.

“I'm hoping that people in Minneapolis see that people in a relatively small rural part of Pennsylvania stand with them,” the spokesperson said. “I'm hoping that Penn State sees what students want, what the community wants, and doesn't allow ICE to come on campus, doesn't revoke student visas, and I'm hoping that ICE sees this and knows that people are gonna take action if they plan to come here and we're prepared.”

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: We are so back | A 2016 playlist
author: Ashlyn Kafer | The Daily Collegian
description:
The year is finally 2026 …or is it?

It’s been 10 years since 2016, yet the masses are still engulfed with nostalgia for the last days of Vine, the peak “King Kylie” era and posing in front of Los Angeles’ “pink wall.”

Celebrities and social media users alike have flooded their feeds with throwback pictures from 2016, only perpetuating the mutual longing to go back to Gen Z’s “good ol’ days.”

The music of 2016 holds many memories from the era of Pokémon Go and riding for your Snapchat streaks, so hop in your time machine and immerse yourself back into the days before TikTok dances and ChatGPT.

“Panda” by Desiigner

Desiigner said it best: “panda, panda, panda, grrrah.”

With six-second Vine videos featuring this song as the backtrack and the music video garnering 20 million views in the first two weeks of its release, “Panda” by Desiigner became one of the most notable pieces of 2016.

Characterized by its signature trap beats and the full-toned nature of Desiigner’s vocals, “Panda” rose to the No. 1 spot on the Billboard charts shortly after its release, furthering the expansive pop culture surrounding the summer months of 2016.

“Closer” by The Chainsmokers ft. Halsey

Even if you’ve never looked at the lyrics, there’s a good chance you’re able to sing this song word-for-word after its near-constant radio time and internet exposure.

“Closer” made waves throughout 2016, its catchy and memorable chorus born in the back of the Chainsmokers’ tour bus taking the song to the top of the Billboard Hot 100 for a record-breaking 26 weeks.

“Black Beatles” by Rae Sremmurd ft. Gucci Mane

Known for freezing people in place after hearing the first few notes, “Black Beatles” took 2016 by storm after sparking the “Mannequin Challenge,” one of the most widespread internet challenges to date.

This song remains to be a “real crowd-pleaser” with its distinctive beat that courses beneath each verse and the reverberating vocals of Rae Sremmurd, making it nearly impossible to sit still through the entire four minutes and 51 seconds of the track.

“Somebody Else” by The 1975

Veiling impenetrable sadness and heartbreak with synthesizers and sonnet-like rhythms, “Somebody Else” has become a timeless relic of 2016, relevant even 10 years after its release.

If your memory of 2016 is a bit more scathing than the general perception allows, sing along with Matty Healy as he curses love and embraces getting his money up.

“This Is What You Came For” by Calvin Harris ft. Rihanna

Baby, songs like this are what you came for.

“This Is What You Came For” features Rihanna’s sultry vocals and the signature 2016 “pop-drop,” including synth plucks in an upbeat breakdown between verses.

While everybody else is looking at 2026, plug in your wired headphones and look back at 2016.

“Formation” by Beyonce

2016 was the year of Beyonce.

“Lemonade” dropped in April, featuring songs like “Formation,” reigniting the importance of telling album storytelling and highlighting music’s role in healing.

“Formation” is a standout track, illuminating the Black female experience and including a novel, bouncing sound to captivate listeners from the beginning of the song until the number concludes.

“Never Be Like You” by Flume ft. Kai

Twinkling in your ears like the remembrance of the sparkle in a past lover’s eyes, “Never Be Like You” emulates the pop-inspired EDM sound of 2016 with its trap-centric beats in juxtaposition with Kai’s breathy vocals.

Making a resurgence after an edit of Jacob Elordi featuring the track went viral in 2023, “Never Be Like You” has been bringing back those 2016 vibes for several years and counting.

“Lean On” by Major Lazer ft. DJ Snake and MØ

This song is the “Rio de Janeiro” Instagram filter personified.

“Lean On” incorporates bright pluck synths and the raspy vocals of vocalist MØ, perpetuating the trend of opening the door for dance music to enter the mainstream field of view.

Lean on memories of endless 2016 summer nights and “boho” inspired crocheted Coachella outfits with Major Lazer and DJ Snake’s steady beats to get you through these dark winter nights.

MORE LIFESTYLE COVERAGE

title: Weekly recap | Penn State women’s basketball continues to struggle on Pacific coast
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s been a rough season for Penn State women’s basketball, and the struggle continued when the Lady Lions took on Oregon and No. 25 Washington last week.

The team’s road trip to the Pacific Northwest saw the blue and white remain winless in Big Ten play, losing by a combined 46 points to the former Pac-12 foes.

After the two losses, the Lady Lions are 7-14 on the season, and in the midst of a ten-game losing streak. They’ve won just one of their last 14 games, that victory coming over VCU on Dec. 20.

Shooting inefficiency

While Penn State went a relatively acceptable 40.6% from the field in the two losses, several key players had poor shooting performances that contributed to the failing efforts.

Against Washington, guard Kiyomi McMiller shot 5-for-17 from the field and 28.6% from inside the arc. Fellow guard Tèa Clèante also struggled, posting a 36.4% shooting percentage and going just 20% from three-point range.

Clèante’s poor shooting continued against Oregon, as the French freshman shot 16.7% overall and 0-for-4 from deep.

Shaelyn Steele and Vitoria Santana each went 2-for-7 from the field against Oregon, contributing to a team shooting percentage of 39%. With the Ducks shooting a far more efficient 57%, it would’ve been a tall task for the Lady Lions to come out on top.

If Penn State is going to pick up a Big Ten victory by season’s end, it will need to find better shooting form, particularly from its star players.

Charity stripe challenges

In the matchups with Washington and Oregon, the Lady Lions struggled mightily when they found themselves at the free throw line.

Against Washington, Penn State went 3-for-9 from the line, while the Huskies shot 12-for-15. Washington got more opportunities, but being outshot by nearly 50 percentage points at the free throw line is generally not congruent with victory.

The same theme held true against Oregon, where the Lady Lions shot 50% from the charity stripe in comparison to the Ducks’ 85%.

Making more free throws wouldn’t have made up the 30 point deficit that Penn State lost by, but poor free throw shooting has been a common theme throughout the season. Through 21 games, the Lady Lions are shooting a combined 65.3% at the line, a rate that ranks last in the Big Ten.

Still searching for Big Ten success

Last season, coach Carolyn Kieger and the Lady Lions won just a single conference game, and they’re on pace to come up short of that mark this year.

Last week saw the Big Ten struggles get even worse, with the loss to Oregon marking the third time the Lady Lions lost by 30 or more points this year. A 36-point deficit to UCLA and a 40-point dismantling by Michigan earlier in the season slotted the loss to the Ducks as the third-worst of the season.

Under Kieger, the blue and white posted two seasons with just a single conference win. One came last year, and the other was her debut campaign as Penn State’s head coach.

While the conference slate has been ugly so far, there’s ample opportunity to get an elusive Big Ten victory. There are still two ranked teams left to play, No. 13 Michigan State and No. 15 Maryland, but there are easier games to follow.

The Lady Lions still have to play Northwestern, Rutgers and Indiana, which rank No. 15, No. 16 and No. 17 in the Big Ten, respectively. Coming in the final weeks of the season, those matchups will be the best opportunity for Kieger and Penn State to get on the board in the Big Ten.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s basketball hosts Minnesota for National Girls and Women in Sports Day
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State women’s basketball suffered two double-digit losses in its West Coast trip to Washington and Oregon last week, falling to 7-14 on the season. The Lady Lions are still searching for their first Big Ten win since Jan. 19, 2025.

The blue and white have eight games left this season to find its footing and earn a conference victory, starting with a battle against Minnesota.

Tipoff is set for 6 p.m. Wednesday in Rec Hall, and the meeting with the Golden Gophers is Penn State’s National Girls and Women in Sports Day game.

Minnesota is 14-6, with its win column highlighted by a victory over then-No. 21 USC, while suffering close losses to then-No. 7 Maryland and then-No. 9 Michigan.

In the Gophers’ most recent outing, they convincingly defeated Wisconsin 88-53. Sophomore guard Tori McKinney was the game's leading scorer with 20 points. The Minnetonka, Minnesota, native is the team's second-highest scorer this season, averaging 12.5 points per game.

The Lady Lions’ last game against Oregon was a tale of two halves. After trailing 40-34 at halftime, the blue and white fell 89-59. Freshman Nyla McFadden and sophomore Kiyomi McMiller each scored a team-high 15 points.

Penn State played without 6-foot-6 Gracie Merkle after suffering a head injury in the previous game against Washington. Merkle is the Lady Lions’ leading scorer at 19.3 points per game.

Minnesota’s scoring effort is led by 5-foot-10 junior guard Grace Grocholski, who averages 14 points per game and is a top shooter in the Big Ten with 2.6 made three pointers per game. The North Prairie, Wisconsin, native enters Wednesday's matchup after an 18-point performance in which she shot 6-for-7 from field-goal range and 4-for-5 from beyond the arc.

The Gophers present tough guard play thanks to the likes of Grocholski and McKinney; the Lady Lions will look for a strong outing from their backcourt, which is led by McMiller and redshirt junior Moriah Murray.

McMiller is the blue and white's second leading scorer, averaging 18.8 points per game. Murray averages 9.5 points per game, and matches Grocholski’s scoring from deep by also netting 2.6 three pointers per contest.

Both teams own a nearly similar total points per game average, with Penn State averaging 74.4 points, compared to Minnesota’s 74.2. The bigger outlier between the two opponents comes from the defensive side of the ball.

Statistically, the Gophers have the best defense in the Big Ten, allowing just 54.2 points per game, and this number also ranks in the top-10 nationally.

On the other hand, the Lady Lions have the conference’s worst defense, with opponents averaging 82.3 points per game.

Wednesday’s matchup presents Penn State with both a clear challenge and an opportunity. If the Lady Lions can generate consistent offense from their guards while tightening up defensively, they’ll give themselves a chance to crack Minnesota’s elite defense and potentially break through in conference play.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Nittany Lions around the nation | Bloomsburg Open headlines weekend slate
author: AJ Piazza | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State has a ton of wrestlers competing around the country, including former wrestlers while other current wrestlers on the roster wrestled at an invitational.

It was a quiet weekend for former Nittany Lions wrestlers overall.

Bloomsburg Open

Penn State had five wrestlers at the Bloomsburg Open. Four of the five wrestlers placed at the invitational.

Hayden Cunningham was the first to wrestle for the Nittany Lions. Cunningham wrestled at 141 pounds and had an overall record of 2-2 for the weekend. The redshirt freshman registered a major-decision victory and placed fourth.

At 149, Dalton Perry competed for Penn State, recovering from his knee injury that he suffered at the Army Black Knight Invitational in November. The freshman went 2-1 with a major decision-victory and placed second.

At 174, the Nittany Lions had two wrestlers compete in Sam Beckett and Sean Degl. Degl went 2-2 and had a rougher outing than Beckett. Beckett also went 2-2, but had a tech-fall victory and placed fourth in the weight class.

Rounding it out at 285 pounds, Dawson Bundy wrestled the most out of any of the other Penn State competitors. Bundy went 2-0 in collegiate matches and 1-2 in non-collegiate matches. The redshirt freshman also had a tech-fall victory and placed fourth.

Transfers

Oklahoma State was supposed to have two matches last weekend, but the match against Utah Valley got postponed. That match could’ve contained three former Nittany Lions, with 149-pounder David Evans being on Utah Valley, but the Cowboys only had their match against Missouri. Oklahoma State defeated Missouri 33-3.

Of the Oklahoma State contingent who were in action, No. 7 Alex Facundo at 174 pounds wrestled a former All-American in No. 10 Cam Steed. The match was tight, but Facundo got the better of Steed, defeating him 2-1. Facundo now has four-ranked wins with his last two being Steed and No. 8 Carter Schubert of Oklahoma.

At 184 Pounds, No. 8 Zack Ryder continues to struggle against wrestlers ranked higher than him. The Cowboy dropped his match, 4-1, after No. 3 Aeoden Sinclair got a takedown in the later parts of the third period. That is Ryder’s fifth loss of the season.

Jack Kelly got some action for George Mason against Edinboro. Kelly bumped up from 184 to 197 in this one, and it didn’t go in his favor. Kelly lost by decision, 8-4, to Brody Evans which led to Edinboro getting the victory over the Patriots.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Big Ten recap | Winning, losing streaks continue with 5 weeks left of women’s basketball
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
After another week of action, more movement takes place across the Big Ten as the conference tournament approaches.

Five teams extended their streaks of at least three straight wins or losses as Week 12 saw its fair share of big games and big moments.

Iowa earns 3rd straight top-15 win

After losing two of its first three ranked matchups, Iowa returned with four ranked victories.

The Hawkeyes began their march with a close, seven-point victory over Michigan State on Jan. 18 before defeating Maryland by seven points in overtime on Thursday. Iowa had its biggest conference win of the season on Sunday when it toppled No. 12 Ohio State by 21 points.

Sitting at No. 7 in the Big Ten with 80.9 points per game, the Hawkeyes have seen success from every athlete on their squad.

Over the past week, Iowa had three different athletes lead the team in scoring in each of the three games. Senior Hannah Stuelke led with 22 points against the Spartans, sophomore Ava Heiden dropped 20 against the Terrapins, and freshman Addie Deal scored a team-high 20 points against the Buckeyes on Sunday.

Purdue earns 2nd Big Ten win over conference winless Indiana

The lowest tier of the Big Ten continued to separate from the rest after another week of action.

The biggest reason for this came in Purdue’s second conference win of the season, a victory over an 11-9 Indiana despite a 42.6% chance of winning.

While the Boilermakers haven’t yet established a true leading scorer, they had three athletes in double figures, with another four players just one basket away from double-digit scoring.

For the Hoosiers, however, former Penn State star Shay Ciezki led the way in scoring. The senior guard scored 37 points, accounting for over 53% of her team’s points.

Purdue moved to No.13 in the Big Ten rankings — in control of the last seed for the conference tournament — while Indiana sits just one loss away from the Lady Lions’ last place.

Maryland suffers back-to-back ranked losses

After winning its first ranked matchup of the year, Maryland has lost its last three, including back-to-back top-10 losses last week.

Following a loss to UCLA, where the Terrapins allowed 97 points — the second-highest this season — they suffered an overtime loss to Iowa to fall to 17-4 on the year.

Maryland’s offense was successful on Jan. 18 as junior Oluchi Okananwa scored 25 points, followed by Saylor Poffenbarger and Addi Mack’s combined 27 points.

Their offense was even stronger on Thursday as the Terrapins scored 34 fourth-quarter points to send the game to overtime.

This time, redshirt junior Isimenme Ozzy-Momodu led the way with 18 points. However, Maryland was outscored 12-5 in the overtime period, ultimately losing their third straight ranked matchup.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Built in Happy Valley | Jessica Adolfsson’s journey from Penn State women’s hockey to Olympic stage
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
As coach Jeff Kampersal made his way back from a European hockey camp, he knew Jessica Adolfsson had the potential to be a great Penn State athlete. Little did he know she would make it to the Olympics and represent her country twice.

“Believe in the process and be patient with yourself,” Adolfsson told The Daily Collegian. “Surround yourself with people who support you, and don’t be afraid to step outside your comfort zone. If you’re willing to work consistently and stay passionate, those dreams are possible.”

With those goals and that mindset, Adolfsson earned her spot in the 2022 and 2026 Olympics to represent Sweden in women’s ice hockey.

While Kampersal knew she would be a star in the future, many of Adolfsson’s teammates saw that skillset in her when she joined the Nittany Lions in 2018.

“Jess had a very clear standard for herself and for how she showed up every day,” Chantal Burke, a former teammate of Adolfsson, told the Collegian. “She was consistent, driven and quietly confident. On the ice, she played with purpose. That combination of internal motivation, self-awareness and work ethic is what made it easy to believe she could reach the Olympic level.”

After playing a limited role in the first two games of the season, Adolfsson had a huge effort on Oct. 5, 2018, against Merrimack, when she recorded her first assist after five shots.

A few weeks later, she earned her first goal on a last-minute power play against Robert Morris and tallied her first multi-point game against Cornell.

“Jessica just had a lot of presence as a (defender), good stature, a really good skater, really good puck mover and a cannon for a shot,” Kampersal told the Collegian. “She came to Penn State and hit the ground running with no issues whatsoever.”

Adolfsson’s quick success was made evident on the ice, but her teammates and coaches saw her success in the locker room becoming even more prevalent.

“In the locker room, she brought sincerity and accountability,” Burke said. “She shared pieces of herself in genuine moments and wasn’t afraid to connect on a deeper level, which built trust and brought the team closer together.”

After scoring two goals and five assists through the first few months of action, Adolfsson finished the season on a hot streak with three goals and two assists through February and the first week of March.

Adolfsson’s freshman success was evident following her postseason awards, being named to the CHA All-Rookie team after ranking third among CHA freshmen defenders in scoring.

In just her second season with the Nittany Lions, Adolfsson was named an alternate captain before ultimately sustaining a season-ending injury just five weeks into the season. During this time, Adolfsson’s interactions with her team became more important as her efforts weren’t possible on the ice.

“(Jessica) loved poetry and learning, and she would genuinely share what she was studying or thinking about with me,” Burke said. “Those moments showed a depth to her that people might not have seen from the stands. She was very intentional with her words and her actions, and you could tell she knew what she wanted from herself and from her team.”

What she wanted was on display when she came back from injury, playing in all 21 games of the season after she returned on Nov. 29, 2020.

In the following game, Adolfsson returned to her peak form with a goal from the defensive end. A little over a month later, she had the only two-goal game of her career against Robert Morris, as she tallied four goals and seven assists on the season.

Adolfsson ultimately departed from Penn State after just three years, as she joined Linköping HC in the Swedish Women’s Hockey League.

Despite cutting her collegiate career short, the Linköping, Sweden, native made her mark on Happy Valley, both on the ice and off.

“In my opinion, her greatest legacy is bringing that sort of professional approach to the team culture and commitment,” Kampersal said.

After combining for just 23 points in her two seasons in the SWHL before joining Penn State, Adolfsson scored 25 points off 6 goals and 19 assists in her first year back in 2021.

“Penn State prepared me tremendously,” Adolfsson said. “The experience I gained at PSU taught me how to be consistent, handle pressure and elevate my game in big moments.”

The biggest moment of her career came just a year after leaving Penn State, as she was named to represent the Swedish women’s hockey team at the 2022 Beijing Olympic Games.

“I wasn’t surprised,” Burke said. “It felt like one of those moments where you think, ‘This just makes sense.’ Seeing her make her first Olympic team in 2022 is a testament to her growth, resilience and commitment to her passion for hockey.”

As Adolfsson prepared for the big game, she adapted her collegiate training style from the typical six-month season she had previously experienced to a new two-and-a-half week Olympic tournament.

“The preparation has been very detailed and intentional,” Adolfsson said. “There’s more emphasis on short-term performance, international systems and team chemistry in a condensed time frame. It’s different from a long college season, but the focus and intensity are extremely high.”

Sweden opened the 2022 Olympic Games with two 3-1 losses to Japan and Czechia before earning a 2-1 win against China and a 3-1 win against Denmark.

While Adolfsson and Sweden ultimately lost 11-0 in the quarterfinals to Canada, finishing eighth overall, she strongly cherished the moment representing her country.

“Wearing Sweden’s jersey is something I never take for granted,” Adolfsson said. “It represents playing for everyone back home and honoring our hockey tradition and competing with heart every time I step on the ice.”

After another year of action with Linköping HC, Adolfsson moved to HV71 of the SDHL before moving across the Atlantic to the Ottawa Charge of the Professional Women’s Hockey League. She only played one game in Canada before returning home to Sweden to join SDE HF in the SDHL.

“It makes me incredibly proud of her, especially as someone who understands all the highs and lows, blood, sweat and tears that are unavoidable through the trajectory of a unique hockey career,” Burke said.

Over the past month, Adolfsson was named one of four Penn State athletes to represent her country at the 2026 Olympic Games, marking her second appearance at the Olympics.

“Penn State is developing players who can compete at the highest level, and seeing that reflected on the international stage speaks to the coaching, culture and commitment within the program,” Adolfsson said. “Sharing that experience with Nicole (Hall) makes it even better.”

While Adolfsson enters the Olympics at 27 years old, Kampersal hopes she can make the most of her experience later in her career.

“I’m super excited because she’s getting on with her career,” Kampersal said. “These opportunities are very few and come every four years, so I’m super excited and proud of her to represent Team Sweden in Italy.”

After an eighth-place finish in her first Olympic Games, Adolfsson doesn’t have an exact placement in mind ahead of 2026, but is hoping for success with her team.

“We believe in our group and our preparation,” Adolfsson said. “Our expectation is to compete hard every game, play our style of hockey and continue to grow throughout the tournament. If we stay connected and committed, we believe we can do something special.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Column | Men’s lacrosse players to watch
author: Elliott Inscho | The Daily Collegian
description:
After coming two goals short of a national championship appearance last season, Penn State has a shot at another strong campaign in 2026.

Last year saw the Nittany Lions go 12-5, with wins over No. 10 Notre Dame, No. 13 Michigan and eventual national champion No. 3 Cornell, though the Big Red would end the blue and white’s season in the NCAA semifinals.

This season, the Nittany Lions are ranked No. 7 in the season-opening Inside Lacrosse rankings. While the blue and white are a well-rounded group, a few players could help push that ranking higher with strong seasons.

Hunter Aquino

Aquino made a quick name for himself in 2025, being named the Big Ten Freshman of the Year following a 16-goal debut season. The 6-foot-5 midfielder’s 37 total points ranked second on the team, behind only Matt Traynor.

With Traynor graduating following last season, Aquino is likely to step into an even larger role in 2026. The Easton, Pennsylvania, native got first-line reps last year, but with Traynor gone, he’ll be the clear-cut first option midfielder for Penn State.

After being named a second-team All-American by Inside Lacrosse as a freshman, an offseason of development and increased workload could make for an even larger breakout by Aquino this season.

Alex Ross

Ross was named to the All-Big Ten Second Team and an Inside Lacrosse All-American Honorable Mention in 2025. To start 2026, he’s been named as a Big Ten Player to Watch alongside Aquino and defensive midfielder Jon King.

The 6-foot-1 senior caused 15 turnovers in 2025, a mark that ranked second-most by any Nittany Lion. Similar to Aquino, Ross will see an increased role with the departure of Kevin Parnham, and is likely to take on the most challenging attack matchups in each game.

Penn State’s defense allowed a solid 9.4 goals per game last season, a mark that ranked No. 14 in the nation, and Ross was a major factor in that strong performance. The unit will be shaken up a bit in 2026, but the Davidsonville, Maryland, native is likely to have another strong season.

Liam Matthews

The redshirt sophomore scored 28 goals last season, second-most on the team, trailing only the aforementioned Traynor. The Orangeville, Ontario, native’s 34 total points ranked fourth-most, and second among returning players.

Matthews’ scoring total came on a 40% shooting percentage, which led all Nittany Lions who took more than four shots last season. That efficiency will be valued on an offensive unit that needs to replace a lot of production with Traynor’s departure.

The blue and white scored 12.3 goals per game last season, ranking No. 21 nationally. Matthews and the rest of the attack unit are poised to improve on that mark in 2026.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Column | We Are or I am?
author: Julia Kushner | The Daily Collegian
description:
Community traditions build the collective we. They’re the ties that bind us together.

Otherwise, we’re just a bunch of randos forced together by happenstance.

If you’ve ever met someone who went to your high school, before or after your attendance, you probably asked them a series of questions related to your own personal experiences.

“Did you have XYZ teacher that everybody hated?”

“Did you also go to PQR event that was the biggest of the year when I went there?”

If their answers were no, the conversation probably fizzled out pretty quickly. You don’t have any of the same experiences. You just happened to be born in the same place at a similar time.

If their answers were yes, you probably felt a deeper connection to them. Though not at the same time, nor with the same people, you had the same experiences.

Traditions transcend time.

Observances from the past are often demonized today. It’s said that traditions, experiments that worked, are often monolithically labeled as outdated, oppressive or unfair.

But what if most traditions are positive social integrators that mark time and place?

I’d bet we could all agree that most rituals are not the demons we make them out to be.

For example, Penn State used to have class dances. There was the Soph Hop, the Junior Prom, and the Senior Ball.

Now, maybe these disappeared due to class sizes and space constraints, but how much fun would a class-wide university dance function be? There’d be a King and Queen and all sorts of fun aspects.

These dances, though just a minor example, are full of symbology. They marked the experience of getting older each year and enjoying social settings with our peers. There’s nothing unfair or oppressive about it.

Additionally, Penn State used to have all sorts of annual competitions and exhibitions.

For example, there used to be an annual All-College Circus in Rec Hall where outstanding members of student orgs were presented to their peers and applauded for their meaningful contributions.

We had an annual livestock exhibition held by a club, complete with a co-ed pig race and a meat auction — a representation of our agricultural roots. This tradition began in 1916 with the last mention of it in The Daily Collegian in 1992 — its 75th anniversary.

Take a walk down memory lane with Penn State’s archives, and you’ll see a plethora of examples like these. But what happened to them? Where are all of our traditions now?

We have the White Out and Homecoming. What else?

Where are all of the silly traditions, the formal collegiate experiences, the collective activities marking a moment in time, or the uniqueness of a certain place?

Why have the past and the events from it been so collectively demonized?

Some say modernity is always a positive — a marker of moving forward. But when we move forward, do we have to leave everything behind? Can’t we mix our modern day and age with the glories of the past, the experiments that worked?

Maybe, just maybe, traditions don’t deserve to be constantly castigated and relegated to the dustbins of history.

MORE COLUMNS

title: Penn State men’s basketball remains winless in Big Ten play with latest loss to Ohio State
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is still looking for its first Big Ten win of the season, and that search will continue as another conference loss happened Monday night.

The Nittany Lions’ youthful roster couldn't overcome an 18-point halftime deficit while facing Ohio State, losing 84-78 inside the Schottenstein Center in Columbus, Ohio. Mike Rhoades’ squad dropped to 9-11 on the year and 0-9 in Big Ten play.

Penn State opened the second half on a 27-10 run, cutting Ohio State’s lead down to 60-59 after an and-1 jumper by forward Josh Reed with 10:46 left in the game. The Nittany Lions were consistently threatening the lead early in the second half with wing Eli Rice slimming it down to 58-54 at the 11:57 mark.

But as Penn State came close to taking its first lead of the game, the Buckeyes went on a quick 5-0 run behind two free throws and a 3-pointer by guard John Mobley Jr., guiding his squad to a 69-61 advantage. The two squads battled, but Mobley got Ohio State back to a double-digit cushion with another 3-pointer to make it a 74-63 game with 6:38 left.

Guard Melih Tunca made multiple baskets down the stretch to keep Penn State in it, and Rice brought the Nittany Lions down 80-76 after a 3-pointer with 23 seconds left. However, it wasn’t enough to fully complete a comeback after late free throws by Ohio State.

It was the third-straight game Penn State was losing by 18 points or more at halftime as the Buckeyes led 50-32 at the break. Despite entering the game averaging only 9.1 turnovers per game, the Nittany Lions had 10 turnovers in the first half and only shot 41% from the field.

Ohio State, on the other hand, shot 66.7% from the field and 54.5% from 3-point range during the first half. The Buckeyes mounted a 14-2 run midway through the half, and even while Penn State cut the lead to 10 points, they temporarily stopped any comeback from happening with a 12-4 run near the end of the half.

The Nittany Lions’ offense was led by Rice, who totaled a team-high 20 points. Seven-footer Ivan Jurić, Tunca and Reed were all in double figures as well, with the team shooting 50% from the field, 40% from 3-point range and 86% at the stripe.

Jurić registered a double-double with 14 rebounds as well, winning the rebound battle for Penn State, 31 to 21.

Ohio State had three players in double figures: Mobley, forward Devin Royal and forward Amare Bynum. Mobley paced the Buckeyes with 25 points, and Ohio State shot 56% from the field, 34.8% from 3-point range and 76.2% at the free-throw line.

Monday’s game also saw former Penn State player Puff Johnson in action for Ohio State. Johnson had two points and three rebounds in 14 minutes during his second appearance of the season for the Buckeyes.

Injury report

Rotational forward Tibor Mirtič remained listed as “out” on the Big Ten availability report. He hasn’t played since the Michigan game on Jan. 6, which is when he exited with a knee injury.

Freshman guard Reggie Grodin is redshirting this year, so he’s listed on the availability report as “out for season.”

Up next

The Nittany Lions will travel to Welsh Ryan Arena in Evanston, Illinois, for a game against Northwestern at 8 p.m. Thursday, streamed on Peacock. The Wildcats are 9-11 on the year and 1-8 in Big Ten play.

title: Postion preview | Penn State men’s lacrosse attackmen has star power, lacks depth
author: AJ Piazza | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State will need to have guys step up at the attack position after losing some key pieces in Matt Traynor and Will Peden. The squad also lost key point-getters in Jack Aimone and Ethan Long.

Traynor was selected No. 6 overall by the New York Atlas and impressed in his rookie season. Despite the blue and white losing some key contributors, there are a ton of names who could step up this season.

Kyle Lehman and Hunter Aquino are expected to be key pieces as attackers.

Lehman saw much more time in his sophomore season than he did in his rookie season, and the growth showed. He had a career high in goals with 26 and points with 33. With Lehman being one of the main ball handlers, he’ll be able to spread the ball around more. The junior improved his shot last season and will look to add more assists to the stat sheet.

Aquino will now play attack after being a midfielder last season. The Big Ten Freshman of the Year impressed in his first season. Aquino only started nine games but tallied 37 points, including 21 assists. The sophomore had an injury that forced him to slow down during the NCAA Tournament, but the Easton, Pennsylvania native will be focused on potting in points in his first year as an attackman.

Liam Matthews became an important piece during the second half of the season. Despite only starting seven games, Matthews was second on the team in goals with 28. He had the highlight of two behind-the-back goals against Cornell and is expected to have more highlights this season.

The depth beyond these three attackmen is thin and unknown. The only player to appear in a collegiate game is Wesley Scurci, who played in two games last season and in 12 games for Lindenwood in 2022-23. The redshirt junior didn’t have any points for the Nittany Lions.

Jack Iannantunono was ranked as the No. 60 player in the 2025 class, according to Inside Lacrosse. The freshman could be a rotation piece at attack this season for the blue and white, considering the lack of experience at depth.

Matthew Beachley could be another name to watch. The freshman is in a similar situation to Iannantunono. He could start as a rotational piece and work his way up the depth chart. Beachley is not as highly ranked as Iannantunono, but was still rated as a four-star prospect and has potential.

Enzo Grieco redshirted last season and is likely at the bottom of the depth chart, while Matthew Beachley could redshirt this season.

The attack show will run through Matthews and Aquino, who’ll likely score a majority of the points for the Nittany Lions in 2026.

title: Former Penn State QB Bekkem Kritza transfers to Alabama A&M
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
A former Penn State quarterback has found a new home.

Ex-Nittany Lion Bekkem Kritza announced his transfer commitment to Alabama A&M on Monday morning via his Instagram.

The 2025 season was Kritza's lone campaign in Happy Valley, and he didn't appear in a game during his freshman year.

He was a former 3-star product via the 247Sports Composite rankings from national powerhouse Chaminade-Madonna College Preparatory School in Florida, but also had stops playing his high school ball in Colorado and California.

The Hollywood, Florida, native was buried on the depth chart. When Ethan Grunkemeyer was the starter, and Kritza was the only other healthy scholarship quarterback on the roster with Drew Allar and Jaxon Smolik injured — Kritza still wasn't the backup to Grunkemeyer as wide receiver Liam Clifford held that role.

Kritza was always viewed as a long-term project, needing to bulk up from his 6-foot-5, 199-pound frame, but now he will look to develop with four years of eligibility left at Alabama A&M.

"He is such an unpolished gem, in my opinion, ex-Director of Player Personnel Kenny Sanders said during National Signing Day last year. "I think that I could probably spend an hour just talking about what I think Bekkem Kritza is going to be."

title: Penn State sues major healthcare companies over alleged insulin price manipulation
author: Taylor McGillvray | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State filed a lawsuit against several major healthcare companies on Jan. 13 alleging that they intentionally increased insulin prices. The university claims the price hikes forced its self-funded healthcare system, which covers staff, faculty, retirees and their dependents, to pay artificially high costs for diabetes medications.

The average cost of some diabetes medication has risen more than ten times the amount average consumer goods and services have over the past two decades, according to court documents. The lawsuit alleges that the price increase is not a result of market-driven variables, but the medication was instead engineered by the companies in a way that would increase their profit.

Manufacturing defendants Sanofi, Eli Lilly and Novo Nordisk allegedly raised prices on purpose to maximize their profit margins within a “pay-to-play” rebate system. Pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) CVS Caremark, Express Scripts and OptumRx, along with their parent companies Aetna, Cigna and UnitedHealthcare, allegedly created the financial incentives that increased the price.

The companies are being sued for fraudulent concealment, violating Pennsylvania unfair trade practices and consumer protection law, civil conspiracy and unjust enrichment.

Insulin prices have been quickly increasing over the last twenty years, however, the process of manufacturing the drug has decreased, according to court documents. In 1990, a vial cost as little as $2 to produce, and was priced at $20. Now, the same vials range anywhere from $300 to over $700. The relevant period for the alleged claims is 2008 through the present.

The defendants’ continuous contacts and conduct within the Commonwealth established a strong nexus among defendants, this forum and the claims at issue, making the exercise of jurisdiction proper and fair.

The defendants’ listed above were active in Pennsylvania, and their actions directly impacted residents, so the case is to be handled by a court and a requested jury.

The defendants’ listed above were actively selling insulin in Pennsylvania, and their actions directly impacted residents, including those at the Pennsylvania State University. Penn State demands trial by jury on all issues that are triable.

Penn State is seeking restitution and damages, among other legal and equitable monetary remedies available under the state laws.

The university declined to comment on the ongoing litigation.

MORE CRIME AND COURTS COVERAGE

title: Weekly Recap | No. 4 women’s hockey sweeps Delaware in historic hockey weekend
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following a seven-game road trip, No. 4 women’s hockey returned to Pegula Ice Arena for the final stretch of conference games before the end of the season.

This past weekend, the Nittany Lions hosted the Delaware Fightin’ Blue Hens, completing the first season series against the newest AHA team. With a 5-0 on Friday followed by a 7-0 win on Saturday, Penn State took the season series 4-0.

Over the four games played, the blue-and-white outscored Delaware 24-0 and outshot them 191-30.

Penn State extended its win streak to five games and kept its record at home perfect, sitting at 11-0.

Hockey history

With the 5-0 win in Friday’s contest, Penn State coach Jeff Kampersal became the fifth coach in Division-I women’s hockey to earn 500 wins in his career.

Sitting fifth on the all-time list, Kampersal now chases Katey Stone, the Harvard coach who earned 523 wins while leading the crimson-and-white over 28 seasons.

After stopping all 12 shots she faced on Saturday, Katie DeSa recorded her eighth shutout of the season and the 21st of her career, passing Josie Bothun, a member of the 2024 squad, for the most shutouts by any goalie in Penn State hockey history.

DeSa’s eight shutouts are tied for the most in the nation with Quinnipiac’s Felicia Frank.

Maddy Campbell also recorded a shutout on Friday, her fourth of the season, giving her a tie for the most single-season shutouts by a freshman in program history.

Conference champs

For the fourth consecutive season, Penn State is the AHA Regular Season Champion. The Nittany Lions secured the title in their win over Delaware on Saturday, earning them home-ice advantage in the upcoming AHA Tournament beginning in February.

Penn State joined the Mercyhurst Lakers as the only two teams in conference history to win the regular season championship in at least four consecutive seasons.

With six conference games remaining, the Kampersal and the Nittany Lions are now two wins shy of tying their program record of 19 wins set just last season.

Seniors shine

On Saturday, Penn State took the time to honor those who will be graduating in the Class of 2026 with a postgame ceremony for the following seniors: Kendall Butze, Maddy Christian, DeSa, Taylor Lum, Katelyn Roberts, Leah Stecker and Mya Vaslet.

With five points over the weekend from two goals and three assists, Butze tied Lyndie Lobdell, 2025, for the Penn State record for most career points by a defenseman with 84.

Janecke, with three points over the weekend, scored two goals on Saturday and extended her point streak to eight games. The captain totaled 13 points on eight goals and five assists during her streak.

Christian and Vaslet each accumulated three points over the two games. Lum, Roberts and Stecker each recorded two.

Outwater on a roll

Grace Outwater’s goal on Saturday gave the Nittany Lions a 5-0 lead in the second period. The sophomore winger has scored in each of her last five games and extended her point streak to six games.

Her goal on Saturday was also her 18th of the year, breaking Janecke’s record for goals by a sophomore set during the 2023-24 season.

Second line shooters

The second line of forwards Christian, Mikah Keller and Outwater set a goal for their line to have all three score a goal in Friday’s contest, and they did that and more. The three skaters combined for six points, with each tallying a goal and an assist.

Outwater opened the scoring with Keller notching an assist. With under three minutes remaining in the second period, Christian assisted on a Keller goal to give Penn State a 3-0 lead. With less than a minute left, Outwater sent a one-timer that Christian fired into the back of the net, completing their goal.

For Christian, it was the 15th time in her career she finished a game with at least one goal and one assist, tying her with Natalie Heising of 2022 for the third-most games in Penn State history.

With first-line center Janecke headed to Milano-Cortina for the Winter Olympics, the second line could look a little different when they take on the Robert Morris Colonials in the first-ever outdoor hockey game at Beaver Stadium on Friday at 1 p.m.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE
