title: ‘We need to wrestle with it’ | Professors discuss AI usage at Penn State
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become increasingly integrated into everyday life with virtually every Google search conducted today coming with AI overviews and access to Large Language Models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT or DeepSeek not being far behind.

Stuart Selber, a professor of English and director of the Program of Writing and Rhetoric (PWR) in the College of Liberal Arts, said academic integrity cases involving AI usage are often “black-and-white” due to representing a blatant cheating attempt.

“We do have people just treating AI like an answering machine, feeding the assignment sheet in and asking for a finished assignment and handing it in,” Selber said.

He said there are various AI usage policies across the different academic colleges and that allows professors to make their own decisions regarding how AI can be used in their classroom.

“I might have a teacher who teaches in the writing program who wants to ban AI, that's up to them,” Selber said. “I don't think that's a good idea, myself, because I think we should wrestle with it because we're trying to prepare you to wrestle with it in the workplace so we need to wrestle with it in the classroom.”

Ibukun Osunbunmi, an assistant research professor in the College of Engineering, said it was important for professors to be transparent with their AI usage policies and believed such discussions would cause a reduction in academic integrity violations.

When advising a colleague about how AI can be used in their course, Osunbunmi said it was important for students to first learn lesson materials without AI before they are given access to it, as a way to assist in solving complex problems.

“I told him one of my mantras that ‘If you cannot do it without AI, there's no (way) you can verify AI output,’” Osunbunmi, an assessment and instructional support specialist within the Leonhard Center for Enhancement of Engineering Education, said. “I said ‘Now that your students have mastered the fundamentals, now they know that AI can go wrong. They'll be careful not to use it or, even if they use it, they will check it and they have done it in a safe space where they are being guided.’”

Osunbunmi said he’s currently working on a website resource for Penn State faculty to learn about how AI can be used in their courses. He said there needs to be more accessible resources and frequent discussion on how to effectively use AI in higher education.

“Why there's some pushback to AI integration is because it's disrupting how we teach, it’s disrupting how we learn,” Osunbumni said. “Ultimately, it has a lot of potentials for use but the outcome will be based on deliberate, inflectional design and I perceive it's going to be a collection of people sitting together in a room and having these hardcore conversations.”

Mark Morrisson said he and several of his colleagues are currently investigating how to broaden the ways students can leverage AI through a Bachelor of Arts to complement existing Bachelor of Science degrees already being taught in the Colleges of Engineering and Information Science and Technology (IST).

“The engineering one is about how to make AI, how to understand AI, and the IST one is more use apps, things like that, but what we wanted to achieve with a BA was thinking more about ethical, social, cultural implications of emerging technologies,” Morrisson, a professor of English, said. “Liberal art students fit this kind of thinking very, very well and so we wanted something that would draw students … to be thinking more capaciously about how to understand impacts and dynamics of emerging technologies.”

He said Penn State stands to benefit from providing ways to increase AI literacy among students.

“There is a lot of disruption going on right now over AI and there's the kind of Luddite perspective of ‘Let's just rewind and not use this,’” Morrisson said. “Well, it's not possible to do that anymore so instead, whether just uncritically consuming it or hoping it'll just go away, there's a middle ground which is understanding it and really thinking it through like we do with all education at Penn State.”

David Fusco said he instructs his students to use AI as a tool to help them rather than a crutch to rely on.

“In the world of technology that most of my students end up going into, people are using AI in their technology-based jobs,” Fusco, an associate teaching professor in the College of Information Science and Technology, said. “From my own personal experience and the courses I teach, I think it's a disservice to students to not understand how to use AI properly.”

He said he thinks it important that students learn how to effectively use AI due to it becoming an increasingly necessary skill in several industries.

Gregg Rogers, an associate teaching professor of English and PWR’s associate director, said Penn State has a “responsibility” to teach students about AI so they are both provided with a useful skill and inspired to pursue new ways in which the technology can be applied.

He said changes in Penn State’s stances toward AI in recent years is the result of beginning to consider how to overcome its drawbacks — such as hallucinations, where LLMs generate faulty outputs — as well as its potential for misuse.

“None of these problems are going to be solved by not looking at it,” Rogers said. “We are all still learning about this thing which is what we're supposed to be doing — we're a university.”

MORE CAMPUS CONTENT

title: Column | Lost in Translation: The issues with book-to-film adaptations
author: Emma Strickling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Since it was released in late November, “Heated Rivalry” has snowballed into the sensation that it is today. Whether you’ve seen it or not, you’ve probably come across some aspect of the hockey romance online. But before it became such a worldwide phenomenon, its story was housed in the 368-page book of the same title written by Rachel Reid.

Whether there’s a creative drought or not, Hollywood has always seemed to turn to their local library to find their latest project. Adaptations have been part of the movie industry since the beginning of film’s history. Today, it’s no different. Academy Award-nominated films “Hamnet” and “Frankenstein”, which were released last year, both came from books.

Emerald Fennell’s controversial adaptation of “Wuthering Heights” will be released next month. The trailer of the movie suggests the film will frame the story as an erotic romance rather than focusing on the intensity, obsession, and at times cruelty that’s present in Emily Bronte’s novel.

Even the film’s depiction of Heathcliff based on the casting choice, seems to directly contrast with the descriptions established within the book.

Evidently, book-to-movie adaptations can be difficult. But if the base story already exists, why is it so hard to produce a good adaptation?

I think, primarily, it lies within the film industry’s fondness for capitalizing on stories that already exist. A recent survey revealed 63% of Americans are more likely to see a movie if it was based on a successful book, according to People Magazine. Basically, these adaptations are an easy way to make money, because people are familiar with the name.

With a well-known name comes expectations surrounding the film. People are going to want to see the characters in the world that has been described to them. However, creative control (and perhaps some arrogance as well) can end up steering the project further and further away from its origins, in an attempt at making the film something more palatable for the screen.

For those who aren’t familiar with the original, it doesn’t make much difference. But for those who are familiar, they end up feeling disappointed, repeating their mantra of “the book was better” on the way out of the theater.

Time constraints don’t help either. Generally speaking, the average book is around 200-400 pages, which is difficult to try and fit into a two-hour time frame. This leads to important plot lines being cut, leaving viewers feeling like something is missing.

This issue is probably why we’re seeing more books turn into TV shows, which can sometimes be a better alternative to film, as there’s more room to go in-depth into the story.

Perhaps these films shouldn’t be solely looked at as “adaptations.” Yes, they are being adapted to fit the screen format. However, they are more of a translation of the source into TV shows or movies. Like any translation, there are versions that translate well and some that don’t, but regardless of whether or not it’s translated well, something will get lost in the process.

Tone and nuance are things that can be left omitted, leaving the material unlike the original and not quite right. Even if you read a book that was translated from a different language, it still wouldn’t be exactly the same as the original because there’s no such thing as an exact translation. This is the same for a book to movie adaptations as it’s being translated from one language (literature) into another (film).

I caution filmmakers — because I know they are avid readers of my column — that, in order to make an adaptation, one must have an incredible familiarity with the source text. While no adaptation is 100% perfect, it could be close if there’s an awareness, understanding and reverence of the book it comes from.

While some people aren’t sticklers about every detail being exactly how it’s written, if trying to equate a movie with the book it came from, then the adaptation should be as faithful as possible. If the source material is altered significantly in terms of plot, characters and setting then it shouldn’t attempt to be passed off as a direct version of its origin.

While I do love both film and literature, I think their interaction with one another should be much more limited than we have seen and continue to see. Because honestly, how many film versions of one book do we need?

MORE COLUMNS

title: Penn State men’s basketball heads to Ohio State with clash against former Nittany Lion
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Things haven’t been great in Happy Valley recently, as Penn State endured a cold stretch fitting in magnitude to the nearly two feet of snow that hit the region.

The Nittany Lions face Ohio State on Monday, with a whole emphasis on the athletic portion of their student-athlete duties. With both schools canceling classes, the contest against the Buckeyes seems as essential as ever, despite the rivalry implications.

Penn State dropped its last six and sits as one of two winless teams in the Big Ten, but the blue and white hit the road to Columbus with a chance to heat up along the way.

By the numbers

Both Penn State and Ohio State excelled in certain areas of play but also have their shortcomings, and they are actually similar in many of those metrics. Obviously, the 13-6 Buckeyes outperform the 9-10 Nittany Lions heavily across most categories, scoring offense, team defense, rebounding and scoring efficiency inside the arc.

Despite these stats suggesting Ohio State cruises to victory due to those fundamental advantages, there are also intangibles where Penn State actually holds surprising favorability.

Beyond the arc, both are mediocre, if even that, shooters, and have comparable possession and assist averages.

Building on where the squads are similar is crucial for Mike Rhoades’ Penn State team to find success, and they can also find optimism in the fact that the blue and white typically generate more steals and turn the ball over less than Ohio State.

This metric could result in Penn State opting to press for those turnovers, where it can create an advantage, which actually isn’t a terrible idea. According to Evan Miyakawa’s tempo ratings, they both rank similarly, with Penn State taking the edge and also playing more comfortably in faster-paced games than the Buckeyes.

Player personnel

When taking an analytical and literal approach, the Buckeyes again hold the advantage, with only the margins favoring Penn State.

Bruce Thornton leads Ohio State behind his over 20 points per game average, joined by two other upperclassmen and sophomore John Mobley Jr., the second-leading scorer, as the Buckeyes top offensive contributors.

The scarlet and gray possess a roster efficient at all levels, whether it's just a duo or trio or an overall five-man unit. However, the Nittany Lions, which largely tinkered with starting groups due to injury and a young core, actually possess a more efficient five-man lineup of Freddie Dilione V, Kayden Mingo, Josh Reed, Eli Rice and Ivan Jurić.

That's a group for Penn State that Rhoades doesn’t typically appear altogether, with Dilione and Mingo rotating in the backcourt, yet Rhoades may need to change that, as the unit posts a better observed efficiency rating.

Oh, hello again

Penn State enters Ohio State’s campus for the first time this year, and for most of the roster, the first time.

Only Dilione and Dom Stewart returned for Penn State in last year's clash with the Buckeyes in State College, where it received a thumping in Rec Hall. On the contrary, Ohio State retained three starters, but most of its second unit is made up of new arrivals.

The player most familiar with this occasion will be former Penn State forward and current Buckeye sixth-year, Puff Johnson, who received a temporary waiver to return to action. Johnson will make his second appearance since his return against his old squad, after playing four minutes in a loss to Michigan.

Johnson is a key storyline to watch, and especially how he’s handled by both squads in this one. Ohio State may opt to use his services due to his familiarity with Rhoades’ scheme, while Penn State may know just the way to counter its former star.

Both squads face off in a primetime FS1 matchup on Monday at 7:00 p.m., and both have a chance to make a statement. For Penn State, it's to show it isn’t done fighting or improving despite a difficult season.

At the same time, Ohio State has a chance to differentiate itself from the middle of the pack in the conference in emphatic fashion.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State cancels Monday classes due to snowstorm
author: Neel Ved | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State has canceled all campus classes and activities from 5 a.m. Monday to 5 a.m. Tuesday due to the snowstorm. The only people who should report to campus are essential employees, according to a Penn State News Release.

State College remains under a Winter Storm Warning until 1 p.m. Monday as issued by the National Weather Service.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: No. 8 Penn State men’s hockey secures series sweep of No. 5 Wisconsin in comeback win
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 8 Penn State began a gauntlet of Big Ten contests Friday night, facing three of the top-five teams in the next trio of series, starting with No. 5 Wisconsin.

After the Nittany Lions’ dominant 7-2 win in their first meeting with the Badgers, the two were back for a Saturday night rematch at the Kohl Center.

Penn State secured the series sweep with a 3-1 comeback win Saturday night.

The physicality of Big Ten contests is nothing new.

Following a five-penalty first period on Friday night, the blue and white’s rematch with the Badgers began with the same theme.

The Nittany Lions were first to the power play. Wisconsin’s Jack Horbach laid a high hit on defenseman Nick Fascia, and although immediately reviewed for a major penalty, the forward was only awarded a two-minute minor.

Penn State’s powerplay came inches from an early score, but a tic-tac-toe passing play captained by Gavin McKenna was eventually stuffed at the doorstep by Wisconsin goaltender Daniel Hauser.

The prime opportunity quickly dissolved for the Nittany Lions, and after a bouncing puck was intercepted off forward Matt DiMarsico’s stick, Wisconsin’s Tyson Dyck sent Christian Fitzgerald on a shorthanded breakaway.

Fitzgerald snuck his shot through the five-hole of goaltender Kevin Riedler, and gave the Badgers a 1-0 lead just under seven minutes into the first period.

Penn State’s early momentum stalled after Wisconsin’s goal, and the remaining minutes of the first frame were a back-and-forth effort.

With just over a minute to go in the period, the Nittany Lions were given a second chance on the man-advantage after one of the Badgers’ top producers, Quinn Finley, was called for hooking.

The blue and white couldn’t get one through as the buzzer rang in the first period.

Although starting the middle frame with almost a minute remaining on the power play, Penn State remained scoreless and was still chasing a goal.

Like Friday’s matchup, the Nittany Lions began the middle frame trailing the Badgers, but unlike the first meeting, there was no three-goal performance to erase the deficit.

The two top-10 ranked teams continued their evenly matched battle. Wisconsin held the slight 11-9 edge in shots, and each had an opportunity on the man-advantage, but neither could capitalize and add to the scoring.

The Badgers thought they doubled their lead with about three minutes to go after forward Ryan Botterill found the back of the net, but the officials immediately waived it off for goaltender interference.

A challenge by the Wisconsin bench led to a short review, which confirmed a defender colliding with Reidler before the score, and the first-period goal was still the only score heading into the final 20 minutes.

After 45 minutes of scoreless play, sophomore JJ Wiebusch found the equalizer for the blue and white.

The Verona, Wisconsin, native got the Nittany Lions on the board in his hometown arena, after firing a shot from the high slot that found its way through traffic and into the back of the Badgers' net.

The blue and white picked up some momentum after Wiebusch’s score, and just over eight minutes later, forward Reese Laubach doubled the lead.

An initial shot from DiMarsico sent a rebound out to Laubach, who finished the shot over a diving Hauser, and gave Penn State its first lead of the night with about seven minutes to play.

The Nittany Lions sealed the 3-1 comeback win and series sweep after McKenna potted an empty net goal in the remaining seconds of the third period.

Up Next

Penn State is back at home hosting No. 2 Michigan State, first slated for a 6 p.m. puck drop at Pegula Ice Arena on Jan. 30, before hitting the ice for the outdoor game at Beaver Stadium.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

description:
The Centre Area Transportation Authority (CATA) announced in a press release Saturday night that they will suspend all CATABUS and CATARIDE services on Sunday due to the incoming snowstorm.

CATA will continue to monitor weather conditions and will resume service once the situation is deemed safe enough to do so, the press release said.

CATA encourages riders to visit its online rider and service alerts page for further updates.

title: Penn State ties with Illinois, falls behind EVO at Sam Mikulak Invitational
author: Caroline Riley | The Daily Collegian
description:
Escaping frigid State College, Penn State men’s gymnastics competed for the first time at the Sam Mikulak Invitational in Sarasota, Florida, named after the three-time Olympian and six-time U.S. national all-around champion.

The Nittany Lions faced off against two collegiate teams, Illinois and Florida Storm, as well as the EVO Senior Men’s Elite Team featuring two former Nittany Lions, Michael Jaroh and Josh Karnes.

Despite a still rings rotation which featured the two highest scores in the country this season, the blue and white tied for second with Illinois with a 317.650 behind EVO’s 326.150

Rotation One

Brayden Erickson got the meet started on the floor, but was unable to showcase much control on his landings. He had a hop on his opening front double tuck and underrotated his full twisting double back dismount, taking a big step to the front and side for a 13.050.

Matt Underhill was cleaner in the second spot. He had small hops throughout, including on his double layout and front double pike, but just a small shuffle on his full twisting double back gave him a 13.550.

In his first floor routine of 2026, Luke Esparo put up a big 13.700. He had a hop in the wrong direction on his opening combination front double pike, but stuck his double twist along the side. He was underrotated on his dismount but had a solid effort overall.

Shaun Smith closed out the rotation with a flat 13.00 following a bounding step forward on his front double tuck and big hops on his full twisting double layout.

Rotation Two

Bobby Alessio opened the rotation with a hit. His entire routine was packed with flair elements, and he managed to fly up into a handstand on his dismount for a 12.850.

Ritam Malik followed the redshirt sophomore with a 13.800. He had some form issues with leg separation after his one pommel work, but stayed on the horse and landed his dismount.

Ricky Perez kept the momentum moving. He competes in a tricky routine with Russian elements. The freshman was a bit slow to get up to his handstand, but dismounted cleanly for a 13.650.

Landson Simpson also put up a hit routine in the anchor position. He was dynamic and quick with his Thomas flairs, flying up to handstand for a season-high 13.850.

Rotation Three

Bobby Haberstock opened the rotation with a low 11.550. He had some control issues throughout his strength elements, and then was unable to get his dismount around to his feet, landing on his stomach.

Akseli Karsikas got the team back on track with a 13.750. He also stumbled a bit on his dismount, taking a large step forward, but putting it to his feet.

Needing a big score, elite rings competitor Underhill came through in a huge way, putting up the best score in the nation so far this season. He was steady throughout, sticking his dismount cold for a massive 14.700.

Esparo closed out the rotation with a 14.300, the second-best score in the nation behind his teammate. The junior bent his elbow a bit on his final strength element and took two hops on his dismount, but helped Penn State bounce back after the fall in a big way.

At the halfway point, and despite Haberstock’s fall, Penn State skyrocketed to the top of the pack with a 161.850. EVO trailed with a 161.100, followed by Illinois’ 160.000 and Florida Storm’s 136.900.

Rotation Four

Penn State moved to the vault, where all four gymnasts competed a Tsuk two and a half with varying degrees of success.

Kellen Ryan started the rotation with a massive step to the right for a 13.750. Simpson underrotated his vault, sitting it down for a low 12.800.

Underhill bounced back with just a small hop on his landing for a 13.800. However, the highlight of the rotation was Smith, who stuck the blind landing cold for a rotation-high and season-high 14.150.

Penn State extended its lead over EVO to a full point heading into the final two rotations.

Rotation Five

Malik led off the parallel bars rotation cleanly. He had a few unnecessary hand movements early and took a big step to the side on his piked dismount, but scored a solid 12.900.

Esparo continued his big day for the Nittany Lions with a 13.500 after just a small hop back on his double pike dismount.

Kacper Garnczarek competed in the first routine of the day in the third slot. He opened strong but was unable to cleanly hit his handstand after a giant need to adjust both his hands to regain balance. He also took two hops on his double front dismount, which lowered his score to a 13.150.

Simpson anchored the rotation cleanly despite a big arch in his final handstand position and a large step forward on his dismount. He scored a 13.700 as Penn State dropped its lead, trailing EVO 269.600-270.500 into the final rotation.

Rotation Six

Ryan opened the highbar rotation. He caught his Coleman and Kovacs taking a small step forward on his dismount for a 12.750.

Esparo was unable to finish his day on a high note. He was too far away from the bar on his Kovacs and was unable to grab it. He caught the rest of his releases but had a huge hop back on his dismount, scoring a low 11.750.

Garnczarek got the team back on track with a 12.350. He caught his Coleman but had a big form break late in the routine, separating his legs on top of the bar. However, the senior did stick his dismount.

Simpson began his routine, falling the wrong way on his handstand, and then couldn’t regroup in time to grab the bar on his Coleman, suffering a fall. He got back on the bar and finished his routine with a stick, but the damage was done as he scored an 11.200.

Up Next

Penn State welcomes Illinois to Rec Hall on Sunday, February 1, at 1 p.m. for its THON meet.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: SEE IT: Penn State football legend Micah Parsons visits men's hockey team in Wisconsin
author: Chase Fisher | The Daily Collegian
description:
A former Penn State football great visited the Nittany Lions in Wisconsin.

Micah Parsons, who played in Happy Valley from 2018-20, was seen with Penn State men’s hockey in the visiting locker room at the Kohl Center on Saturday night.

Micah Parsons B1G Hockey Guy! 😤#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/ftiBoUc4tE— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 25, 2026

Parsons was repping a No. 11 Nittany Lions’ hockey jersey, the same number he wore in college.

title: Senior class dominates in No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey’s Senior Day win over Delaware
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State closed out a two-game series against Delaware at 1 p.m on Saturday with its annual Senior Day tradition. Six seniors and a pair of graduate students were honored in lieu of the pre-game starting lineup announcement.

Members of the graduating class include captain Tessa Janecke, assistant captains Katelyn Roberts, Mya Vaslet, Leah Stecker, Kendall Butze, Maddy Christian, as well as Taylor Lum and goaltender Katie DeSa.

“They're pros,” coach Jeff Kampersal said. “The way that they approach everything here, from school to hockey to the community, they do everything the right way. They're super connected. And I think it's a group that, years down the years down the road, will stay connected.”

The Nittany Lions, regardless of graduation status, showed up to play on the special day. Backed by the supportive Roar Zone, Penn State posted a clean 7-0 scoreline to sweep the series over the Fightin’ Blue Hens. With this victory, Penn State clinched the AHA Regular Season Championship, improving to 24-4 overall and 17-1 in the conference.

And it didn’t take long for the senior class to get moving.

In the first period, Janecke tallied a pair of goals that sandwiched Lum’s score. In her last series before heading overseas to play in the Milano-Cortina Winter Olympic Games for Team USA, Janecke lasered a shot through three defenders off the post and into the back of the net 16 seconds into the game, assisted by Christian and Butze.

“That was really cool that we scored 15 seconds in with those six players on the ice,” Kampersal said. “They've obviously had terrific careers, and that was a nice touch for Senior Day, and that got us going.”

Lum scored three minutes later, picking up a bounce off the end boards on a shot by Danica Maynard. She ripped the puck into a wide-open net for her fourth goal of the season, increasing Penn State’s lead to 2-0.

Janecke’s second came from the same spot in the high slot for Penn State’s third goal, assisted by Roberts, who sent the primary feed to Janecke.

The second period saw Butze and Vaslet linking up to assist on Nicole Hall’s goal to further the gap to 6-0. Although she didn’t score, Vaslet rang a shot off the iron on a breakaway. Janecke had a breakaway of her own, but she was dragged down before she was able to deke.

“(The seniors) have been so helpful,” Hall said. “All of them are so kind and helpful every day. They're an awesome group, and it's not going to be the same without them here next year.”

Butze capped off the afternoon in the third period with Penn State’s seventh unanswered goal, when she fired a wrist shot from the point that found an opening over goaltender Mattie Robitzer’s shoulder. Butze’s four-point game puts her at 23 points on the season and 84 in her career, which tied Lyndie Lobdell for Penn State’s all-time assists by a defenseman.

DeSa made history as the final horn blared, as her 21st career shutout broke the program-record for all-time shutouts set by Josie Bothun in the 2023-24 season.

“(DeSa) was behind Josie at that time, but she stayed the course and exceeded all expectations of her,” Kampersal said. “She did an amazing job again. Today wasn’t the easiest game; she gets called in in different flurries for her to get called back to lock-in down the stretch.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s basketball drops 10th straight game in second half collapse against Oregon
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
After falling to Washington 81-65 on Wednesday, Penn State took a trip to Eugene to face Oregon. Both teams entered the game with a chance to break a losing streak: the 7-13 Lady Lions had dropped their last nine, and the Ducks lost their last four, entering at 14-7.

The blue and white couldn’t build off its fast start, falling 89-59.

Penn State got the party started with a 7-0 scoring run, forcing Oregon coach Kelly Graves to burn a timeout less than two minutes into the game

Both teams went scoreless for two minutes after the break, until Sarah Rambus netted a layup for the Ducks’ first points of the game.

After a three-pointer from Vitória Santana, the Lady Lions went cold as Oregon turned up the defensive pressure, but the Ducks kept quacking. Graves’ squad went on an 8-0 run to tie the game up at 10 with three minutes to play in the opening frame.

The blue and white ended its scoring drought with a layup from freshman guard Viktoria Ranisavljevic, but nonetheless, Oregon surged to take a 16-12 lead after the first quarter.

Both teams traded 5-0 scoring runs to start the second frame, but Avary Cain nailed back-to-back threes to give the Ducks a 28-19 lead heading into the first media timeout.

Oregon wasted no time coming out of the pause, with Katie Fiso charging the paint for two points. Fiso’s attempt was quickly matched by Tèa Clèante to put Penn State’s deficit back to single digits.

Rambus and Kiyomi McMiller, each team's leading scorers for the game, seemed to be the only ones able to put the ball in the basket. That was until Ranisavljevic went on a 6-0 run by herself to cut the Ducks’ lead to 38-34 with under a minute left in the quarter.

Ari Long nailed a two-point jumper with 30 seconds left, but the Lady Lions were unable to respond, giving Oregon a six-point lead heading into the locker room.

It was a sloppy first half, with both teams combining for 11 turnovers. With the absence of Gracie Merkle due to injury, the Ducks were able to net 20 points in the paint in the opening half, as opposed to the blue and white’s 16.

Clèante got fouled to start the quarter, but only came away with one free throw. Ehis Etute answered with a quick two on the other end.

It was raining threes in Matthew Knight Arena for Oregon in the first portion of the third frame as the Ducks went three-for-three from beyond the arc right before a much-needed timeout was called by coach Carolyn Kieger.

Even with a timeout, the quarter remained all Oregon. The Ducks stormed for a 14-0 to take a 61-40 lead with just under four minutes to go in the frame. The run was ended with a two-pointer from McMiller, but momentum remained with the home team.

In a nearly flawless third quarter, Oregon outscored Penn State 34-11 to carry a 74-45 lead into the final frame. The Ducks shot 4-for-6 from three-point range and forced the Lady Lions to turn the ball over five times in the third.

After a quiet third quarter, McMiller netted the first points of the fourth for the blue and white with a layup. Fiso matched right away on the other end with a drive to the basket.

Even after McMillers’ bucket, Penn State continued to struggle finding the hoop, missing four straight field goals and going on a two-minute scoring drought.

The drought ended when freshman Nyla McFadden was rewarded two points from the foul line. McFadden went on to score the next four points for the Lady Lions, but Oregon still held a comfortable 82-52 lead with just over five minutes to play.

As the clock fell just under two minutes, Kieger used her final timeout with the Ducks up 87-55. McFadden continued to show out in the fourth, with seven of her team-high 15 points coming in the frame.

The absence of Merkle was evident as points in the paint continued to plague Penn State. Oregon finished with 50 points from the inside and four Ducks scored in double figures.

Injury Report

Amiya Evans remains listed as out for the Lady Lions. Leading scorer Gracie Merkle was also sidelined after suffering a head injury against Washington.

Up Next

Penn State returns home to host Minnesota at 6 p.m. Wednesday.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling beats the snow, and Maryland en route to undefeated weekend
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Due to the Saturday night arrival of winter storm Fern, No. 1 Penn State faced a quick turnaround to hit the road against Maryland.

The Nittany Lions breezed through the Terrapins, moving faster than the wind in College Park, Maryland, en route to a 51-0 victory quick enough to beat the snow back to Pennsylvania.

Here’s how it happened.

125: No. 1 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs. Abram Cline (UMD)

Luke Lilledahl opened the match with wrist control for the first minute, leading to a takedown 60 seconds into the match. That was the only takedown Abram Cline let up in the first period, but Lilledahl took over in the second.

After keeping Cline down for over a minute, he secured two more takedowns before narrowly missing a pin as time expired on the second round.

Cline’s defensive stance and Lilledahl’s aggressive push led to two-stall calls against the Terrapin, and a match contested largely on the edge of the mat. Two more takedowns on the border and over two minutes of riding time secured the 19-4 tech fall for Lilledahl.

Penn State 5, Maryland 0

133: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs. No. 15 Braxton Brown (UMD)

The pair of 133-pounders spent a majority of the first round locked in a collar-and-elbow tie up, only breaking after a mad scramble that resulted in Marcus Blaze taking Braxton Brown down from the legs. The second period saw a similar scramble, where Brown attempted to push Blaze, only to have the momentum turned against him.

The third period saw Brown go defensive, allowing a takedown and a stall call to bring the match to major-decision territory for Blaze. The Nittany Lion was awarded on final takedown as the buzzer sounded while both men were in an apparent stalemate on the ground, extending the win to 15-3.

Penn State 9, Maryland 0

141: No. 11 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs. Dario Lemus (UMD)

Much like Friday night, Braeden Davis was working at a faster pace than prior weeks as he took on Dario Lemus. He rushed Lemus and secured the first takedown one minute in. He landed a second takedown a minute later and rode out the frame trying to flip a prone Lemus.

After Lemus chose to start the second period on the bottom, Davis held onto him until his riding time crossed over a minute, then took him down again soon after the escape. Davis landed his fourth takedown after prying Lemus’ hands off of his ankle with seconds to spare in the period.

Davis got another takedown with a minute remaining and worked on a near fall to secure a tech fall. He couldn’t turn him, but secured a stalling point. However, Lemus escaped with seven seconds to ensure the bout ended as an 18-4 major decision.

Penn State 13, Maryland 0

149: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs. No. 7 Carter Young (UMD)

Carter Young was undefeated in dual matches entering Saturday and was Shayne Van Ness’ toughest matchup of the season.

Van Ness started the aggression with an attack, but Young kept Van Ness staggered before reversing the takedown. He locked Van Ness into a cradle and received four-nearfall points before Van Ness escaped. After the first period, Young led Van Ness, 7-1.

Van Ness turned the tide in the second period, escaping and launching two quick takedowns to draw even. Two more takedowns in a matter of seconds had Van Ness up 14-10. He kept letting Young escape to launch more attacks. The Nittany Lion led 17-11 after Round 2.

Van Ness kept pushing Young down by the neck while on top in the third period, resulting in a stall call. Van Ness got two more takedowns before the clock passed 60 seconds remaining, entering major-decision territory. He finished off a tech fall with 30 seconds left, winning by an absurd score of 31-15.

Penn State 18, Maryland 0

157: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs. Mekhi Neal (UMD)

Mekhi Neal made the first minute difficult for PJ Duke, scampering away from multiple shot attempts and returned to his feet quickly after getting taken down. It only took Duke five seconds to take Neal down again.

One more quick takedown had Neal trapped in a cradle, and with a minute left in the first period, Duke was awarded the pin.

Penn State 24, Maryland 0

165: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs. AJ Rodrigues (UMD)

Mitchell Mesenbrink took down AJ Rodrigues quickly, and racked up 11-near fall points and over two minutes of riding time before the first period ended. He led 14-0 but appeared upset that he didn’t finish off the tech fall.

All he had to do was stand up in the second period to secure the 15-0 victory.

Penn State 29, Maryland 0

174: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs. Seth Digby (UMD)

Levi Haines was physically in control of Seth Digby throughout this bout, racking up riding time after two takedowns, and spent his time trying to cradle Digby. Haines only led 6-1 at the end of the first, but had two minutes of riding time under his name.

Haines got two more takedowns in Period 2, but Digby kept his center of gravity low to the mat, refusing to let Haines turn him for any back points.

Digby caught Haines by surprise to take him down at the start of Period 3, but Haines caught another gear after standing back up. Digby went on a defensive stand after that, unsuccessfully trying to keep Haines away from a tech fall. Haines crossed the 15-point threshold with 26 seconds remaining, winning 23-7.

Penn State 34, Maryland 0

184: No. 1 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs. Sepanta Ahanj-Elias (UMD)

Rocco Welsh followed the team trend of landing the first takedown right around the one-minute mark. His second score came via a double-leg slam that thumped Sepanta Ahnaj-Elias down to the mat for the rest of the period.

The second period opened with Welsh on the bottom, but he stood up and quickly pinned Ahanj-Elias before the frame reached its midpoint.

Penn State 40, Maryland 0

197: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. No. 13 Branson John (UMD)

Branson John used his height advantage to fend off Josh Barr for most of the first period, but after John mistimed an attack, Barr seized his leg and landed the first takedown.

He got one more takedown in the second period, then picked the ankle once more in the third, and quickly flipped John but over-spun to just miss the pin. Two more takedowns handed Barr the 19-4 victory and Penn State another tech fall.

Penn State 45, Maryland 0

285: No. 12 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs. Joey Schneck (UMD)

Mirasola got his next takedown one minute into Round 2 and impressively locked a standing cradle on Schneck, dropping him for the pin.

Penn State 51, Maryland 0

title: Penn State track and field continues success at Penn Elite
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
A week after dominating the record books at the Nittany Lion Challenge, Penn State returned for action on Saturday.

The Nittany Lions traveled to Philadelphia for the Penn 10 Team Elite, where they put on another dominant performance.

Penn State’s success began in the women’s weight throw, as senior Alex Pancoast and sophomore Gabby Cope threw for personal bests for second and third place.

In the women’s high jump, sophomore Hannah Riolo set an indoor personal best with a 1.76m jump as she took second place in the competition.

Junior Joe White had similar success in the men’s long jump, as he earned a third-place finish with a season-best 7.04m.

Despite being a multi-event athlete, Maddie Pitts experienced her second straight win in the long jump, breaking her personal best with a 5.98m jump.

The Nittany Lions earned their second win of the day in the men’s weight throw, led by graduate thrower Collin Burkhart. Burkhart threw for 20.26m, followed by Sam Engebretson’s 19.32m throw for second place.

Penn State’s success continued in the men’s 3000-meter as senior Logan Strawser led the way with a personal best 8:08.84.

In the men’s 60-meter dash, freshman Lucas Band was the only competitor for the Nittany Lions. However, he earned a personal best 6.90 and qualified for the finals in eighth place, followed by another personal best 6.87 for seventh place in the finals.

Sophomore Alexandria North continued her success from last weekend in the 400 meters, as she finished fifth with a time of 54.92.

In the men’s pole vault, senior Tristan McGarrah neared his season best with a second-place finish with 2.04 meters.

While junior Lizzie Schreiber didn’t compete in the long jump, she came back and won the men’s triple jump with a meet-record jump of 12.69m.

The women’s shot put saw a pair of personal bests come from Penn State’s two competitors, as sophomore Skye Petrie-Cameron finished third with a throw of 15.58m. Fellow sophomore Sasha Garnett threw 14.97 for fourth place.

After Strawser won the 3000m earlier in the day, junior Nick Sloff competed in the elite men’s 3000m, where he broke the school record. Sloff won the race in 7:48.56, breaking the Penn State record by nearly two seconds.

The Nittany Lions’ success continued into the men’s 200m, where Ajani Dwyer won his first 200m of the season with a personal best and No. 2 time in Penn State history of 20.52 — the current top mark in the NCAA.

Penn State wrapped up the action on the field with the men’s shot put, where Brady Mider and Sam Engebretson finished second and third. Mider threw a personal best 16.78m throw, while Engebretson threw for 16.75m.

Up next

The Nittany Lions will return home for the Penn State National Open on Friday at the Horace Ashenfelter III Indoor Track.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: Penn State track and field's Nick Sloff breaks 3000m school record
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another record is taken down by Penn State.

Sophomore Nick Sloff broke the men's 3000-meter record at the Penn Elite on Saturday, running 7:48.56.

Sloff's record breaks the former record held by Robby Creese in 2015 when he ran 7:48.55.

The State College native previously held the No. 4 time in school history with a time of 7:59.33.

MORE TRACK AND FIELD COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s volleyball falls in series sweep to No. 15 McKendree
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
After suffering a 3-0 sweep to McKendree last night, Penn State got another look at the Bearcats today, hoping to avoid a second-straight loss.

It was much of the same on Saturday, though, as the Nittany Lions fell to McKendree 3-1 for a series sweep.

Penn State was first on the board after a Miller Trubey service ace opened the scoring. The Nittany Lions went on a 4-0 scoring run until a Miller error got the Bearcats back into it.

After trading points back-and-forth, Penn State found itself down 19-14 after a Tyler Tripp kill put McKendree in a prime position to win the first set.

The Nittany Lions kept it interesting, but a Bryce Wetjen kill solidified it as the Bearcats captured the first set.

It couldn’t have been more different in the early running of the second set, though, as Penn State jumped ahead to an early 8-3 lead. Most of the points came from errors, though Miller, Gabriel Gaige and Sean Harvey recorded kills.

A 3-0 Bearcat scoring run forced Mark Pavlik and the Nittany Lions into a timeout, holding a 17-12 advantage.

McKendree stuck around, going on another 3-0 scoring run, but Penn State stole the second set, winning 25-19 with the help of another Miller kill.

With the match now tied at 1-1, the third set proved to be the tightest of the lot in the early bits with points being traded back and forth, but back-to-back Rolen Lively kills gave the Bearcats a 7-5 lead.

The action remained tight, with Penn State fighting for a score, cutting into McKendree’s lead with another Harvey kill that made the blue and white’s deficit just two points.

Back-to-back kills tied it up for the Nittany Lions at 17 apiece, but the Bearcats just kept putting it together, going on another scoring run to command a 21-18 lead.

With the end of the third set in sight, Tripp picked up his 11th kill of the day, which helped McKendree capture the third set 25-22.

Penn State was closing in right at the end of the set, with Harvey and Trubey picking up their eighth and ninth kills, but it just wasn’t enough, and the blue and white moved one set closer to a loss.

Now closer to suffering a series sweep, the Nittany Lions once again started off the scoring first, and Owen Rose matched a McKendree service ace with one of his own as the third set got off to a flying start.

Another Harvey kill, and a Tripp error on the attack made it a 6-5 advantage for the blue and white. Penn State temporarily held a two-point lead, but the play was overturned and ruled a Lively kill, tying it up for the Bearcats at 6-6.

A controversial score ruling gave McKendree a 15-11 lead, as the Bearcats were slowly pulling away and getting closer to sweeping the Nittany Lions. Rattled, Penn State used another timeout after a Harvey error.

The Bearcats, now putting the hurt on the blue and white, took a 19-15 lead, forcing another Pavlik timeout after a Gaige error.

Penn State was drawing dead but stayed alive with a Jaidyn Bethel kill effort, which was matched with another from Harvey and one from freshman Tristan Hassell, who recorded 13 kills against Lewis a week ago.

The Nittany Lions closed the gap and worked their deficit down to 21-20 after a Jack Morikawa service error silenced the Bearcat end of the floor.

Action was tied up at 24-24, but a Lively kill put McKendree back up in front as the game was coming to a head.

The Bearcats kept scoring but Penn State was resilient and not letting things end so easily. The blue and white effort was all for nothing, though, as a Sam Hoskin kill sealed the deal, winning the fourth and final set 28-26 for McKendree.

Up Next

Penn State returns to action this Friday to host No. 3 Hawaii at Rec Hall in the whiteout game.

Friday’s match is scheduled for 6 p.m.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey utilizes four-goal first period in series sweep over Delaware
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State returned to Pegula Ice Arena for its first home series since November. In a successful welcome back party, the Nittany Lions blanked Delaware 5-0 in Game 1 of the series. This game also marked the first game of senior weekend as eight students were honored throughout the series.

A four-goal first period quickly gave the Nittany Lions momentum that they didn’t lose the entire game, leading to a 7-0 win.

Coach Jeff Kampersal spoke briefly on the “slow start” following the 5-0 win. Kampersal alluded to the seven games on the road before returning to Pegula. However, the Nittany Lions didn’t take long to get on the board in Game 2 as Tessa Janecke found the net only 16 seconds into the game.

The Orangeville, Illinois, native quickly made her way into the offensive zone and ripped a wrist shot through two defensemen. An all-around gritty effort from the senior on senior day.

Janecke, along with Nicole Hall, played their last regular season series as they departed for the Olympics.

The early scoring didn’t stop there as Danica Maynard took the puck off the faceoff and shot a pass that bounced off the end boards and right onto Taylor Lum’s stick. Lum didn’t hesitate to bury the puck into the wide-open net.

This was Lum’s fourth goal of the season and a senior’s second of the game.

Abby Stonehouse had a perfect chance to add to the 2-0 lead as she was all alone with the goalie at the top of the crease. However, Mattie Robitzer decided this was a great time to flash the leather as she robbed Stonehouse with her glove.

Janecke wasn’t finished in the opening period as Penn State was on the power play. The senior took advantage after a wrist shot from the high slot quickly found the net.

Stonehouse quickly followed suit as she intercepted a shot in front of the net from Katelyn Roberts. The Blenheim, Ontario, native went from her forehand to backhand and beat Robitzer.

Although Penn State found success in the goal department, the opening period came to a close with it on the penalty kill.

Second-line magic opened the second period for Penn State. Mikah Keller sent a pass to Grace Outer from below the red line. Outwater took quick work of the puck as she found an opening in the top-right corner.

Nicole Hall then joined Janecke as olympians to score in this game as she sent a wrist shot from the high slot that was zipped by Robitzer.

The Nittany Lions spent the majority of the second period in its offensive zone, however they were caught being too aggressive at times. Both Janecke and Hall spent time in the penalty box for being a little too aggressive on the boards. The penalty kill for Penn State took this middle frame to shine as it killed both penalties.

The third period saw a slower tempo in its first 10 minutes as both teams had opportunities to add to the scoreboard. That was until Kendall Butze sent a slapshot from the point that found the back of the net.

Tempers began to flare after a heavy hit was laid on Outwater at center ice. The Picton, Ontario, native didn’t take too kindly to the hit and laid a return bodycheck post-whistle. Ultimately leading to four-four with two minutes to go.

No additions to the scoreboard were made after the late-game scuffle as Penn State swept the Blue Hens after back-to-back shutouts.

With this shutout, Katie Desa now holds the record for all-time shutouts in Penn State history.

Up Next

Penn State makes its way across the street for an outdoor game at Beaver Stadium against Robert Morris on Jan. 30 at 1 p.m. The Nittany Lions then return to Pegula Ice Arena for Game 2 on Jan. 31 at 6 p.m.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Goaltender Katie DeSa breaks women’s hockey’s all-time shutouts record
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Goaltender Katie DeSa has broken Penn State’s all-time career shutouts record.

The Pawcatuck, Connecticut, native tied Josie Bothun’s 20 career shutouts on Dec. 30 where she saved a season-high 32 shots in the Nittany Lions’ 1-0 victory over Cornell.

DeSa earned her history-making 21st career shutout on Jan. 24, making all 11 saves in Penn State’s 7-0 Senior Day victory over Delaware. Her eight shutouts on the season pace the nation, surpassing Quinnipiac’s Felicia Frank, with whom she was previously tied with.

The reigning AHA Goaltender of the Year currently stands at 18-2 on the season, 55-11-3 overall in her storied career.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State women's gymnastics defeats Maryland inside Rec Hall
author: Caroline Riley | The Daily Collegian
description:
With a winter storm warning ahead, Penn State brought a storm of its own to Rec Hall Saturday with its highest score this season.

Putting up an elite-level day, the Nittany Lions beat Maryland 197.250-196.675.

Rotation One

The Nittany Lions managed a big 49.150 on vault to open the meet, courtesy of senior Ava Piedrahita’s massive 9.900 in the anchor position on her unique half on, pike off.

Elizabeth Leary got the rotation off on the right foot with a stuck Yurchenko full for a 9.825. Allison Kaempfer was another standout in the rotation, scoring a career-high 9.850 on her Yuchenko 1.5, no longer struggling with under rotation.

Freshman Ava Cash got her chance, scoring a solid 9.800 on her Yurchenko full with a hop back. Jessica Johanson and Dani Latronica each struggled a bit, dipping below the 9.800 mark with a 9.725 and 9.775, with some hops on the landings.

However, with Johanson’s score dropping, the blue and white took an early, but small .075 lead.

On the bars, Maryland was solid, only counting one score below the 9.800-plus range. The highlight of the rotation was Aine Reade’s 9.850; however, without a big 9.900, the Terps had some catching up to do.

Rotation Two

Penn State gave the fans in Rec Hall a show to watch on the bars, scoring a huge 49.450 to extend its lead over Maryland to 98.600-98.050 at the halfway point.

Ellie Monahan opened the rotation off with 9.850. She nailed her handstands throughout and stuck her full twisting double back dismount to get the team started. Johanson was short on her pirouette handstand on the low bar and took a hop back on her double layout, scoring a 9.800.

In the third slot, Leary got the scores rising again. Nailing her release sequence and sticking her double back dismount, she managed a 9.875.

Cash followed her with another 9.875. She got a beautiful height on her piked jaegar. She was short on her final handstand, but as the sticky feet were contagious, she nailed her dismount as well.

Piedrahita tied her own score from the vault with another 9.900 and a stuck landing, paving the way for the event-winner Latronica.

The sophomore anchor put up a massive 9.950 in the anchor position. Her piked jaeger was massive, and she hit her overshoot to handstand right on top of the bar. Keeping up with her teammates, she stuck her landing.

On the vault, Maryland could not keep up with Penn State’s pace. The Terrapins managed only one vault better than a 9.800 courtesy of Taylor Rech’s 9.850. Maryland opened the door for Penn State to extend its lead and the Nittany Lions did just that.

Rotation Three

Penn State was unable to keep the same momentum on bars, but put together a solid rotation on beam with a 49.175. Monahan kicked things off with a huge routine. Nailing her front-toss combination and sticking her 1.5 dismount for a 9.850.

Alyssa Kramer kept the steady performance going with her back handspring back layout acro series and another stuck dismount to improve on her two previous 9.775s with a 9.850.

Ashley Maul began the string of triple acro series off with a bang. She was slightly underrotated on her dismount, having to take a hop in the wrong direction, which dipped her score to a 9.775

Kalea McElligott got the scores back on track with a 9.825 courtesy of her triple series, followed by a stuck dismount.

Leary had a big wobble on her series. She took a small hop on her dismount as well, finishing off a shaky routine with a low 9.675.

Latronica, with pressure to drop the 9.75, ended the rotation on a high note. Nailing her series and difficult leaps, the sophomore stuck her gainer full to bounce back with a 9.875.

On the floor, Maryland got its momentum back in a huge way. Madeline Komoroski and Reade both had an event-winning 9.975, meaning one judge gave them each a perfect 10.0. That massive score alongside a few other 9.900s helped Maryland put up a 49.575 on the event to cut Penn State’s lead down to 147.775-147.625.

Rotation Four

With the Terrapins on their heels, the Nittany Lions managed to score a 49.475 on the floor to keep them at bay.

Maul, the usual leadoff, brought big energy to open the rotation with a solid two passes, including a strong double back for a 9.850.

Monahan had too much momentum on her front double full, not fully controlling her lunge forward. She reeled in the power on her second pass for a matching 9.850.

Bella Misiura opened her only routine of the day with another front double full and a really controlled landing on her second pass to begin building the scores with a 9.900.

Johanson struggled on her double pike, landing a bit straight-legged for a pogo-stick-type hop but cleaned up the landing on her second pass for a 9.825.

Not to be outdone, Kramer showcased control on both of her passes to manage a 9.975 of her own to a co-champion of the event alongside Komoroski and Reade.

Having already clinched the win, McElligott only widened Penn State’s victory. Her 9.900 capped off an incredible day for the blue and white.

Maryland was solid on the beam, but with no massive 9.900+ scores, the Terrapins were unable to carry their momentum into a win.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling faces unexpectedly quick turnaround against Maryland
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
After shutting out Indiana inside of Rec Hall on Friday, No. 1 Penn State faces a quick turnaround to College Park, Maryland, for a Saturday evening showdown with the No. 29 Terrapins.

The dual was originally scheduled for Sunday afternoon, but due to the impending arrival of Winter Storm Fern, the contest at the Schanwald Center was moved to 5 p.m. on Saturday.

As a result of the rescheduling, the broadcast has been moved from Big Ten Network to Big Ten Plus, which is free to watch all weekend throughout the snowstorm.

Maryland is a similar opponent to Indiana in that it’s a lower-tier Big Ten opponent that a Penn State lineup, featuring six No. 1 wrestlers, should be expected to cruise through in time to beat the snow back to State College.

125: No. 1 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs. Presden Sanchez (UMD)

Both Luke Lilledahl and Presden Sanchez are coming off matches with Indiana’s Jacob Moran. Sanchez suffered a tech fall in his bout, while Lilledahl secured a pin.

Sanchez is 0-4 in his redshirt freshman campaign while Lilledahl doesn’t have an official loss on his record this season. Lilledahl should make quick work of the opening match.

133: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs. No. 15 Braxton Brown (UMD)

One of three ranked matches on the card sees freshman sensation Marcus Blaze challenge three-time NCAA qualifier Braxton Brown.

Brown is 13-4 on the season, but none of his wins have come against top-16 opponents. Blaze is arguably the best competition he’s faced this season.

Blaze is looking to continue his perfect season against Brown. The freshman is 3-0 with two-bonus point matches against opponents ranked higher than Brown this season.

141: No. 11 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs. Dario Lemus (UMD)

Similarly to Brown, Dario Lemus has yet to defeat a top-16 opponent this season. Lemus is 12-7 and is on pace for his first year wrestling attached with a record above .500.

However, Braeden Davis has been improving rapidly since returning to the lineup for Penn State and scored 24 points in a victory on Friday. Davis should control the pace in this match.

149: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs. No. 7 Carter Young (UMD)

The highest ranked match of the dual comes at 149 pounds between Shayne Van Ness and Carter Young. This is the only top-10 match on the card.

Young transferred into Maryland from Oklahoma State after going 10-10 in his first season under head coach David Taylor. He has upped his output to an 8-1 record in 2025-26.

Young has also beat both top-16 competitors he’s faced and now tests himself against the top-ranked athlete in the weight class.

Van Ness is undefeated on the season, but Young is a higher level of competition than he has faced. Van Ness’ pace can be matched by Young, so expect a lower-scoring match than Van Ness is accustomed to.

157: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs. Michael Pizzuto (UMD)

Michael Pizzuto is a redshirt sophomore with multiple accolades off the mat, including academic all-Big Ten honors. However, on the mat, Pizzuto is .500 in his collegiate career and hasn’t shown the ability to compete with world-class opponents.

Duke is just that, especially after receiving his World Championship ring on Friday from USA wrestling after competing in the U20 World Championship event this past summer. His last two matches have ended prior to the third round and that trend should continue against Maryland.

165: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs. AJ Rodriguez (UMD)

What more needs to be said about Mitchell Mesenbrink other than he is a bonus-point machine. He secured a pin on Friday night and will look to match that effort Saturday.

AJ Rodriguez is another Terrapin whose record is floating narrowly above an even showing and has yet to face a top-20 opponent. Mesenbrink will be an evening wake up call for Rodriguez.

174: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs. Seth Digby (UMD)

Continuing up Penn state’s murderers row is another mismatch for U23 World Champion Levi Haines. Haines hasn’t lost since last season’s NCAA finals, and 2-7 freshman Seth Digby isn’t likely to break that trend.

184: No. 1 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs. Sepanta Ahanj-Elias (UMD)

Another freshman for the Terrapins, Sepanta Ahanj-Elias bounces between 184 and 197 for Maryland. Going up against the No. 1 in a weight class that involves a heavy cut is a bad sign for the red singlet.

Ahnaj-Elias is coming off of a major-decision loss to Sam Goin, who Rocco Welsh defeated on Friday. Welsh should have an easy Saturday retaining his No. 1 spot.

197: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. No. 13 Branson John (UMD)

This match features more intrigue than expected at the start of the year, as Branson John has become Maryland’s most improved competitor this season.

After scratching into the NCAA tournament last season, John is firmly in contention with a 19-3 record. While he doesn’t have any major victories on his record, he has won via bonus points in half of his matches this year.

Josh Barr immediately regained his No. 1 ranking since returning and has been churning ever since. He’s seen close matchups as of late and this has the makings of another tense affair.

285: No. 12 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs. Joey Schneck (UMD)

Closing out the dual will be Cole Mirasola against Joey Schneck. So far, every time Mirasola faces an unranked opponent, he completes the job in the blink of an eye. Schneck fits that mold perfectly at 5-5.

Mirasola shouldn’t struggle against Schneck.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Coach Jeff Kampersal earns career win No. 500 in No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey win over Delaware
author: Daniel Studer | The Daily Collegian
description:
Mark Johnson, Mike Sisti, Brad Frost, Katey Stone and now, Jeff Kampersal. The only coaches in the history of Division-I college women’s hockey to achieve 500 career wins.

With a 5-0 win over the Delaware Fightin’ Blue Hens, Penn State recorded its 23rd overall win, 16th conference win, maintained its perfect 10-0 record at Pegula Ice Arena, and Kampersal joined an exclusive list in women’s hockey history.

After a rare appearance in the Friday night primetime slot, the ninth-year head coach said he wasn’t aware of the achievement until it was brought up in a meeting.

“Honestly, I didn’t know until we had a coaches conference call and they were going over (Mercyhurst Lakers coach Mike Sisti) got 600, and these random people that are close to a milestone, and then they mentioned it,” Kampersal said.

Sisti became the second Division I head coach, Johnson, University of Wisconsin, to reach 600 wins with a 6-1 over Stonehill.

Kampersal’s all-time record now sits at 500-350-99. In 21 seasons with Princeton, he finished 327-26-58 with his alma mater before joining the Nittany Lions in June 2017. Thus far at Penn State, he is 173-89-42 and counting.

Another milestone for @jkampy #500Wins pic.twitter.com/l4zphbBKI1— Penn State Women’s Hockey (@PennStateWHKY) January 24, 2026

“I was just thinking I’ve been fortunate to coach with really good people,” Kampersal said.

He then listed his staff of Makenna Newkirk, Jennifer Wakefield, Moe Bradley and also two members of the Delaware coaching staff, head coach Allison Coomey and assistant coach Melissa Samoskevich.

Coomey served as an assistant under Kampersal at Penn State for seven seasons from 2017-2024 before being named the inaugural head coach of Delaware’s women’s hockey program. Samoskevich served as an assistant for two seasons from 2020 to 2022.

Never one to take the spotlight, the Beverly, Massachusetts, native revealed that he took a dive to see how many games players from the graduating class of 2026, such as Katelyn Roberts and Tessa Janecke, won during their time in the blue-and-white, an appropriate statistic to research on the eve of Saturday’s “Senior Day” festivities.

“It’s easy to tap them on the shoulders and tell them to go out there and they’re good,” Kampersal said. “Our bus of players when they show up is usually better than the other bus of players.”

In total, Kampersal has led this group of seniors to 103 wins thus far with still seven regular-season games remaining, plus the AHA conference tournament and NCAA women’s ice hockey tournament.

The Nittany Lion coach is known for making the right decisions, with one of those decisions being the formation of the second line: Maddy Christian, Mikah Keller and Grace Outwater. The three combined for six points, each registering a goal and an assist.

“I think he’s just really supportive and he believes in us,” Outwater said. “Going out there knowing that he believes in me to score or work hard. Just a great feeling.”

Keller shared her insight from her perspective as a freshman playing for Kampersal for the first time.

“You can always know he’s trusting you. I feel like he never doubts us, and you can always just tell he wants what's best for each and every one of us, and it’s just nice to have that from him.”

Christian, who played the most for Kampersal of the trio, said that while he’s very competitive and loves to win, he knows how to play the supportive role as well.

“Makenna runs the practices, but he’ll be the one who comes up if you’re having a bad day like ‘Hey, this is what you’re good at’ and whatnot…he loves to win and loves knowing that we’re there to back him up as he backs us up.”

Kampersal will look for win No. 501 and begin his climb to pass Stone, who sits fourth on the all-time wins list with 523, when his Nittany Lions conclude their regular-season series against Delaware on Saturday at 2 p.m. at Pegula Ice Arena.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Despite an initial challenge, Penn State wrestling’s Braeden Davis finding comfort in move to 141 pounds
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Braeden Davis is a man of few words when it comes to speaking into a microphone — Davis prefers to do his talking on the mat.

He did just that in Penn State’s dual against Indiana Friday, dropping 24 points in a major-decision victory over No. 25 Henry Porter. The Hoosier scored 10 points against Davis, keeping him one point shy of a tech-fall finish, but Davis didn’t let the takedown shake his focus on the mat.

“I’ve always been taught that if something goes bad, just go and score another takedown,” Davis said. “I’m just glad I didn’t get thrown on my back.”

While Porter offered Davis a modicum of adversity, it was not a worry compared to the treacherous path the junior has walked this season. He’s the only Nittany Lion to have taken a loss in their last six dual matches.

That loss came to Iowa’s Nasir Bailey, a loss decided by one point, and in which Davis was seconds away from earning that point via riding time or stalling calls.

“There’s such a fine line between winning and losing,” Cael Sanderson said on Tuesday. “(Davis) will just keep getting better as we move forward.”

As Davis walked to the mat Friday, his new walkout song, “Bawitadaba” by Kid Rock, didn’t become audible until the final seconds before his match began, a fitting metaphor for a late-onset season for the defending All-American.

At the start of Penn State’s season, Davis was notified he’d be redshirting. Following an offseason that saw Davis mired in off-mat controversy, the additions of Marcus Blaze, Masanosuke Ono and the return of Aaron Nagao, Davis was the odd man out of the lineup.

“There was a little bit of confusion at the start of the year but it feels good.” Davis said about returning to the lineup.

Davis admittedly didn’t manage his weight with intention during the month-long period where he wasn’t expecting to compete. He only competed at the Kauffman Open in January to start the year. The Belleville, Michigan, native went 4-0 to win the tournament.

That week, Davis learned he would burn his expected redshirt after Nagao once again suffered a season-ending injury. Then the work started to get back into starting lineup worthy condition.

“At the time, I thought I was redshirting, so what do you expect?” Davis said. “So no, I definitely didn’t (manage weight) the best.”

Sanderson didn't hesitate to give his trusted lightweight the opportunity to hold his spot knowing that Nagao wasn’t likely to return this season.

“We kinda just threw him right in there and that decision is made as he’s a competitor,” Sanderson said. “He will just keep rolling with things.”

Getting in shape was easier for Davis than in past years as he moved closer to his natural weight. As a freshman, Davis wrestled down weight at 125 pounds, then bumped up to 133 pounds last season. Weight management is easier for the junior as he bumps up again into the 141-pound slot.

Davis’ pace has continued to improve as he works his way deeper into the season, peaking Friday with an eight-takedown performance against Porter. Rec Hall gave Davis a resounding ovation as he left the mat for his largest win of the season. The moment represented Davis finding his place back in Penn State’s starting lineup and finding his comfort in a fluctuating season.

“It was a little bit of a challenge at first, but now that I’m down to my normal shape, it’s quite comfortable.” Davis said. “(141-pounds) is probably the most comfortable out of all the weight classes I’ve wrestled so far.”

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Cael Sanderson cites daily grind for level of dominance, consistency for Penn State wrestling
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Mitchell Mesenbrink pumped his fist toward the crowd after winning via pin. After Braeden Davis’ commanding 24-10 victory by major decision, he was greeted by Vice President for Intercollegiate Athletics Pat Kraft, who gave him an emphatic high five with his left hand.

It was a commanding 48-0 win for Penn State over Indiana to make it 81 straight wins in dual matches, but for Cael Sanderson’s squad, it was another day in the office.

“We enjoy competing, and each individual's working on what they do and getting better in each match,” Cael Sanderson said. “Every time you step out there, it's an opportunity to compete and do something you love, and then also continue to get better.”

At intermission, Penn State had eight of its nine wrestlers receive championship rings from suiting up for Team USA this past summer in the U23 and U20 World Championships. Mesenbrink was the lone Nittany Lion who didn’t partake in the ceremony, as his bout was up next coming out of the half.

Sanderson often preaches how the goal for his wrestlers is to succeed beyond the collegiate stage. The success at the international level this past summer proved just that.

But then it again, it carries over to when his wrestlers suit up in the blue and white singlets. Entering the weekend Penn State had six guys ranked No. 1 in the InterMat rankings, but those top spots don’t really matter to Sanderson.

“I think we have a strong team, obviously, a lot of good kids,” Sanderson said. “We don't really focus or worry or think too much about rankings, right? It's the same boring process of getting better every day and every competition and remain grateful for the opportunities that we have, and all those other things will take care of themselves.”

With the win over the Hoosiers, Penn State moved to 10-0 on the year and 4-0 in Big Ten play. It was a dominant showing in front of a Rec Hall crowd that had over 6,200 people show up draped head to toe in the blue and white.

Sanderson said Indiana was “scrappy.” The No. 25 Hoosiers ended up recording more takedowns than what No. 4 Iowa recorded against the Nittany Lions a week ago, but Penn State still ended up with bonus points in nine of the 10 victories.

“They came out fighting, so it was good for us, and it's good that our guys were able to score a lot of points,” Sanderson said. “I think when you enjoy what you're doing, points are obviously a good thing, and it's good training and conditioning.”

Penn State returns to action on Saturday to face Maryland in College Park, as pending snowstorms had the dual moved from Sunday. Sanderson said wrestling in consecutive days will be great preparation for the postseason, where the wrestlers will have to do just that.

After blowing out Indiana, the Nittany Lions will face a similar caliber opponent in the Terrapins. Despite blowing out the Hoosiers, and the outcome likely to be very similar against Maryland, Sanderson is expecting his squad to fine-tune mistakes from Friday as it hits the road.

That’s to be expected from a coach who has led Penn State to 12 national titles as a head coach, because finding miscues in a 48-0 victory is what it takes to create a dynasty like he has.

“We weren't at our best at every weight, but we're excited to keep pushing forward here and get right back on the mat,” Sanderson said.

title: Second line shines, totals six points combined in win over Delaware
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State hasn’t played a home series since November of last year. What happened in that game, you may ask? Second line dominance from the three forwards: Maddy Christian, Mikah Keller and Grace Outwater.

In their return to Pegula Ice Arena, the forwards continued to shine as three of the five goals for the Nittany Lions came from the second line. The three forwards scored a goal apiece while racking up their points through assists. Ultimately, the line as a whole produced six total points in a 5-0 conference victory over Delaware

What makes a line continue production like they have, falls on the players doing their respective parts on a continuous basis. This is seen nearly every shift, especially from their coach, Jeff Kampersal.

“Maddy (Christian) has speed and the same skill, Mikah (Keller) has the vision, Grace (Outwater) scores goals and you don’t have to tell her twice to shoot,” Kampersal said. “They are going to carry the load moving forward for sure.”

As Kampersal describes how each player contributes to a talented forward trio, it paints the picture of a three-headed monster. A unit's defensemen don’t want to see skating down the ice on a forecheck.

The three have been grouped together for nearly the whole season. Due to this, their chemistry has evolved into bonds never forgotten. As seniors soon depart, such as Christian, forming a bond with her teammates gives her the utmost gratitude as she is more than halfway done with her season.

“As a senior, knowing that I have this group, I love it because I know I feel like we all just chem together,” Christian said. “We all have our different attributes that make us great, and it’s heartwarming to know that I’m there for Mikah and Mikah is there for Grace.”

The idea of all three forwards being there for each other was portrayed in a two-on-one opportunity for Outwater and Christian in the game against the Blue Hens. As Outwater received a pass from Leah Stecker from the other end of the ice, it was up to the Picton, Ontario, native to shoot the puck herself or feed a pass to her linemate for the fourth goal of the game.

With both possibilities playing in her mind, the forward dished the puck across the crease for a wrist shot from Christian that gave the Nittany Lions a 4-0 lead late in the second period. As testament to the trio being there for each other, Outwater revealed her mindset as she got closer to the net.

“That was the perfect opportunity to shoot, and then last second I saw Maddy, and I was like ‘oh my gosh, pass it,’” Outwater said. “She got it, and it was a really good goal. So, it was nice.”

title: McKenna’s hat trick propels No. 8 Penn State to comeback victory over No. 5 Wisconsin
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State coach Guy Gadowsky cited his team’s fast starts as a key to its five-game winning streak. His group had scored first in four of its last five games.

The No. 8 Nittany Lions’ start to Friday’s contest at the Kohl Center was anything but fast after three first-period penalties put them in an early hole. But behind a pair of hat tricks from Dane Dowiak and Gavin McKenna, plus 39 saves from Josh Fleming, Penn State scored seven unanswered goals to stun No. 5 Wisconsin, 7-2.

The comeback victory marked the longest Big Ten winning streak in program history, according to the Big Ten Plus broadcast.

Alex Servagno started the game in the penalty box after Penn State’s warm-up infraction. And after Nolan Collins played a puck with a broken stick, the Nittany Lions were down two men just one minute into the period.

Enter Fleming, a 2026 Hobey Baker Award nominee, who denied two point-blank chances to keep the game scoreless.

Shea Van Olm, who returned from a four-game absence, checked a Wisconsin forward from behind and into the boards. The freshman forward was handed a five-minute major and a game misconduct, which ended his return after just 10 minutes.

And while Fleming’s heroism held the Badgers scoreless on their first power play, his first blunder awaited on the ensuing penalty kill. The freshman goaltender denied Tyson Dyck’s initial shot but failed to corral the rebound, which Dyck tapped home for a 1-0 lead.

Oliver Tulk later sniped a shot past Fleming’s blocker to make it two Wisconsin tallies on its lengthy power play. The Badgers led 18-4 in shots and held a 2-0 advantage at the first intermission — a lead that could’ve been extended if not for Fleming’s 16 saves.

Fleming’s resolve was rewarded two minutes into the second period when Mac Gadowsky backhanded a slot feed to Dowiak, who snapped it top shelf to cut Penn State’s deficit in half. It was a one-score game despite Wisconsin’s 22-7 shots advantage.

Following interference and cross-checking calls on the Badgers, it was Penn State’s turn on the 5-on-3. And like its opponent, the Nittany Lions struck twice.

McKenna struck first when he skated patiently into the slot before rifling a wrist shot through traffic for his seventh goal of the season. Dowiak followed with a rebound tally, his second goal of the contest, to give Penn State a 3-2 advantage.

Shots were 18-18 in the second period. The difference: Fleming stopped all 18 to give himself 34 saves entering the final period.

After an abysmal start, the Nittany Lions had silenced the Kohl Center crowd, which went from quiet to stunned when Jackson Smith scored 15 seconds into the third period.

Standing near the blue line, the heavy-hitting defenseman threw a wrist shot on goal, hoping to get a deflection and nothing more. But the traffic blocked Daniel Hauser’s vision, and Smith’s shot hit the net to give Penn State a 4-2 lead.

Smith’s tally provided some insurance, but McKenna wasn’t satisfied. At the halfway point of the period, Penn State’s No. 72 again skated patiently into the offensive zone, this time wristing a shot far side and beyond Hauser’s outstretched blocker for his second goal of the game.

Dowiak seemingly took exception to McKenna matching his goal total and raised him one better when he poked a loose puck between Hauser’s five-hole to complete his hat trick. Fleming’s acrobatic pad save to spark Dowiak’s shorthanded tally was a fitting close to a dominant final two periods for the Nittany Lions.

McKenna added a late tally to complete his first collegiate hat trick, as the Nittany Lions improved to 17-6 and extended their winning streak to six games.
